questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin​ shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

  • J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: The transvaginal sonogram of a 45-year-old woman with heavy menstrual bleeding revealed a globally enlarged uterus with striated projections from the endometrium into the myometrium. She has completed her family but does not want a hysterectomy, and requests medical management of her symptoms. Which among the following is unlikely to be effective in this case?
questions.solution:
A multiparous woman> 40yrs, presenting with heavy menstrual bleeding, and the mentioned sonographic findings, point towards a diagnosis of adenomyosis. SERMs(Selective estrogen receptor modulators) like tamoxifen are associated with an increase in the risk of developing adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis refers to the growth of the endometrium (both stromal and glandular components) directly into the myometrium. Patients generally present with heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, and sometimes dyspareunia.

Risk Factors:

  • Increasing age
  • Multiparty
  • SERMs such as tamoxifen

A definitive diagnosis is usually made by histopathological examination of the specimen after hysterectomy. Transvaginal sonography may show global uterine enlargement with ill-defined hypoechoic areas, heterogeneous echoes in the myometrium, and endometrial infiltration into the myometrium.

MR imaging is superior to sonography and is considered when the diagnosis is inconclusive.

Management of adenomyosis:

Hysterectomy is the definitive management. Endometrial ablation or resection using hysteroscopy is also effective.

Medical management is aimed at reducing symptoms of pain and bleeding. It includes:

  • Cyclic NSAIDs at the time of the menses
  • Combined oral contraceptives and progestin-only regimens - bring about endometrial atrophy and reduce endometrial prostaglandin secretion
  • Levonorgestrel intrauterine device- reduces bleeding
  • GnRH agonists - are used in cases of subfertility or for relief just prior to surgery.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in order of the demographic cycle.

1. Early expanding population

2. Declining population 

3. Low stationary population 

4. Late expanding population

5. High stationary population
questions.solution:
The correct order according to the demographic cycle is high stationary population (5) --> early expanding population  (1) --> late expanding population (4) --> low stationary population (3) --> contracting population  (2).

The demographic cycle has 5 stages:

  • Stage 1: High stationary population 
  • Stage 2: Early expanding population 
  • Stage 3: Late expanding population 
  • Stage 4: Low stationary population 
  • Stage 5: Contracting population

In a high stationary population, there is a high birth rate and a high death rate that cancel each other and the population remains stationary.

The early expanding population is marked by a decline in the death rate but the birth rate stays constant. Many countries in South Asia and Africa are in this phase. 

In the late expanding population there is a further fall in the death rate, with the birth rate beginning to fall. The population is still increasing due to a net increase in births. India has entered this phase. 

A low stationary population is characterized by low birth and low death rate, and this can result in a stationary population. It has occurred in most industrialized countries as a demographic transition shifting from high birth and high death rates to low birth and low death rates.

A declining population is one where the birth rate is lower than the death rate, causing population decline. Examples include East European countries like Germany and Hungary.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: An elderly man presented with a painful and swollen right knee, and difficulty in walking. After examining the knee joint, aspiration is done. The following image is seen on the examination of synovial fluid using compensated polarized microscopy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image of weakly positive birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals are suggestive of pseudogout.

Pseudogout is a condition that occurs due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals (CPPD). It presents with features similar to acute gout and predominantly affects the elderly. This is attributable to the increased levels of inorganic pyrophosphate in diseased or aging cartilage which promotes CPP crystal nucleation and their deposition.

Acute attacks of CPPD presents with joint swelling and pain, affecting the knee (most common), wrist, shoulders, elbows, and hands. It also has systemic features of inflammation including fever, chills, and elevated CRP. Chronic CPPD commonly presents as polyarticular arthritis resembling osteoarthritis (pseudo-osteoarthritis). It affects atypical joints such as metacarpophalangeal, wrist, elbow, and ankle joints causing severe damage.

X-ray or ultrasonography of the joint shows chondrocalcinosis, which is punctate or linear radiodense deposits in the joint menisci or articular cartilage. Detection of rod-like or rhomboid crystals in synovial fluid or articular cartilage is diagnostic of pseudogout.

Other options :

Option A: Osteoarthritis also affects the elderly. Commonly involved joints are the hip, knee, and first metatarsal phalangeal joint (MTP). The synovial fluid in osteoarthritis is non-inflammatory. If the synovial fluid white blood cell count is >1000/μL, it is likely to be due to inflammatory arthritis, gout, or pseudogout.

Option C: Gouty arthritis is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals (MSU) crystals which are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent. They appear yellowish when observed under polarized light. Below image shows needle-shaped, monosodium urate crystal in gout.

Option D: Psoriatic arthritis usually occurs after the development of skin lesions in a patient with psoriasis. It usually presents with dactylitis (involving the distal interphalangeal joint) and enthesitis. It is diagnosed by X-ray features of pencil-in-cup deformity, marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation (whiskering) and telescoping of digits.

questions.text: The given image shows the strength of muscle contraction with successive stimulation. What is the cause of the phenomenon shown?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon and occurs because of increased intracellular calcium.

When a muscle begins to contract after a long period of rest, the strength of muscle contraction during each twitch increases successively with each stimulus. After this, the strength of contraction in each twitch reaches a plateau. This phenomenon is called the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon. It is caused primarily by the increasing calcium ions in the cytosol. Each successive muscle contraction causes more and more calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and these ions cannot be recaptured back immediately.

As the frequency of contractions further increases, a new contraction begins to occur before the previous one is over. Thus, the second contraction is added to the first one and the strength of the contraction increases. As this phenomenon progresses, the frequency reaches a critical level and the contractions become so rapid that they fuse together into a smooth and continuous contraction. This phenomenon is known as frequency summation and tetanization (options B and C).

 

Length-tension relationship (option A) refers to the relationship between the length of the muscle fiber and the active tension that it develops. As the length of the muscle is increased, there is an increase in the active tension which develops in a muscle due to more overlapping between the actin filaments and the myosin cross-bridges. However, this increase in tension only occurs till a limit. The optimum length at which the maximum tension develops is 2.0 to 2.2 μm of length.

questions.text: An 11-month-old baby boy with right side undescended testis is referred by a pediatrician to your urology outpatient.  Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals an empty scrotum on the right side with normal left testis. But a mass was palpable on the right inguinal canal. Ultrasonography revealed the right testicle under the subcutaneous fat near the right inguinal canal with a normal left testis. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of cryptorchidism and the next best step is to perform an orchidopexy.

Orchidopexy is the treatment of choice for incompletely palpable unilateral undescended testis. Orchidopexy is usually performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age.

About 4% of boys are born with one or both testes incompletely descended. About two-thirds of these reach the scrotum during the first 3 months of life, but full descent after that is uncommon.

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis, and this descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac, and this phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown; however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. 

Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: 

  1. Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
  2. Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
  3. Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells 
Other options:

Option A: Cryptorchidism is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma). Thus, observation is never the policy.
 
Option B: When the testis is not palpable, ultrasound may be helpful in identifying the intracanalicular testis, while laparoscopy may be needed to differentiate between the abdominal testis and a truly absent testis. Since here testis is made out in the inguinal region, laparoscopy is not the next best line of management.
 
Option D: Orchidectomy should be considered if the incompletely descended testis is atrophic, particularly in the postpubertal boy if the other testis is normal.

Hence, orchidopexy is usually performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age to avoid the following complications remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

  • T- Torsion

  • E- Epididymorchitis

  • S- Sterility

  • T- Trauma (Increased risk)

  • I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)

  • S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

The given flowchart summarizes the treatment protocol for undescended testis.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown in the image?

choices.text: It is used to remove the products of conception
It is to be introduced with the blades open
Absence of catch minimizes uterine injury
It prevents the crushing of the conceptus

questions.solution:
The given image shows ovum forceps. It is to be introduced with the blades closed, to open up inside the uterine cavity, to grasp the products, and to take out the instrument with a slight rotatory movement.

The rotatory movements not only facilitate detachment of the products from the uterine wall but also minimize the injury of the uterine wall if accidentally grasped.

Ovum Forceps

Identification - has got no catch and the blades are slightly bent and fenestrated. The absence of catch minimizes uterine injury if accidentally caught.

It prevents the crushing of the conceptus.

The image given below shows a sponge holding forceps. It is used to:

  • Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during all operations
  • Removing the laminated membrane and the daughter cysts during operation of the Hydatid cyst.
  • Hold the fundus and Hartmann’s pouch of gall bladder during cholecystectomy
  • Swab an abscess cavity.

questions.text: A 28-years-old female patient came to the psychiatric OPD with a sad mood and decreased appetite for a month. She had a breakup with her boyfriend 1 month ago. She says, "I do not feel like myself anymore. I can't live without him" She said she always did what he told her and they even got a cat together although she is allergic. Her two previous relationships ended on a similar note that she was nice but "too clingy". She works as a receptionist and has been going to work to distract herself from her remnant feelings for her boyfriend. She enjoys binge-watching shows on weekends. She is thinking to have a roommate. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
History of clingy, passive, and submissive (doing everything partner says, getting cat even if allergic) behavior are suggestive of dependent personality disorder.

A dependent personality disorder is characterized by passive and submissive behavior, the person is unsure of himself/herself and becomes entirely dependent on others (her thinking of getting a roommate after the breakup).

It comes under Cluster C personality disorders.

Other options:

Major Depressive Disorder: MDD is characterized by 5 or more of the following diagnostic symptoms lasting 2 or more weeks (must include one of the first two) - (DIGS SPACE- Mnemonic)

  • Depressed Mood
  • Loss of Interest (Anhedonia)
  • Guilt or feeling of worthlessness
  • Sleep disturbance
  • Suicidal Ideation
  • Psychomotor retardation or agitation
  • Appetite/Weight changes
  • Concentration problems
  • Energy loss or fatigue

This patient does not meet the criteria for MDD.

Adjustment disorder:  The patient develops behavioral or emotional symptoms within 3 months of the onset of stressors. The distress is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor. Once the stressor has been eliminated, the symptoms do not last for more than 6 months. This patient has a sad mood that is in proportion to the break up which is not affecting her work (she is going to work and enjoys shows)

Borderline personality disorder: is characterized by impulsiveness, instability, feeling of emptiness and boredom, unpredictability, temperamental, and self-damaging concerning sex, money, and substance use.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with growth over the nasal aspect of the left eye. Initially, it was small but has now progressed to the size shown in the image below. The vision was 6/12 in the left eye and refraction examination revealed astigmatism. Choose the correct statement regarding the management of this case.

choices.text: It is best left alone for spontaneous resolution
Only medical management is sufficient at this stage
Limbal conjunctival tissue from the same eye can be used for grafting
Application of mitomycin C drops reduces recurrence with no complications

questions.solution:
The clinical case and image point to a diagnosis of pterygium with astigmatism, for which conjunctival autografting is an effective method of treatment after excision. Conjunctival tissue can be taken from the limbus on the same side or from the other eye for grafting.

A pterygium is a degenerative subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is most commonly seen on the nasal aspect of the eye. It is made up of three parts:

  • cap (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge)
  • head
  • body

Patients may be asymptomatic or present with irritation, grittiness, or episodes of inflammation. As they enlarge, it may obstruct vision and lead to astigmatism.

Treatment: 

  • A pterygium is best left alone unless:
    • It is progressing towards the pupillary area
    • Causes excessive astigmatism
    • Restricts ocular motility
    • Causes disfigurement.
  • Excision: Simple excision of the pterygium is associated with a high recurrence rate, and should be combined with:
    • Mitomycin C drops- applied pre-operatively/ intra-operatively or post-operatively to prevent a recurrence. However, it may lead to complications like scleral necrosis, cataract, and iritis and should be used judiciously. 
    • Beta irradiation
    • Conjunctival autografting- limbal tissue from the same or other eye is grafted and secured with fibrin glue or sutures.
    • Amniotic membrane graft
    • Peripheral lamellar keratoplasty if the lesion is deep.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male patient came to the physician due to chronic fatigue. On examination, generalized painless lymphadenopathy is noted. The findings of lymph node biopsy are shown in the image below. On immunohistochemistry, the lymphoma cells expressed CD5, CD20, and cyclin D1. Laboratory findings are given below. Which translocation is responsible for this patient's pathology?

Lab findings:

Hb: 10 g/dL

TLC: 1,40,00/mm3

Platelet: 2,26,000/mm3
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image and laboratory findings are suggestive of mantle cell lymphoma, a type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Mantle cell lymphomas have (11;14) translocation.

Mantle cell lymphoma is a rare subtype of B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma and is usually identified by a translocation of the CCND1 gene. It presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life and shows a male predominance. The tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers.

Clinical features:

  • Extensive painless lymphadenopathy
  • B-symptoms like fevers, night sweats, and weight loss symptoms
  • Splenomegaly-related discomfort
  • Blood count abnormalities due to bone marrow involvement
  • Symptoms related to extranodal organ involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, spleen, liver, and bone marrow
  • Mucosal involvement of the small bowel or colon produces polyp-like lesions called lymphomatoid polyposis

Histopathological features:

  • There is a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft nuclear contours.
  • The nuclear chromatin is condensed, nucleoli are inconspicuous, and the cytoplasm is scant. 

The image given below shows a histopathology slide depicting nodular mantle cell lymphoma:

 

Mantle cell lymphomas have (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 that leads to overexpression of cyclin D1. These cells are positive for CD19 to CD22.

The prognosis is poor with a median survival of 3 to 4 years.

Other options:

Option B: t(8;14) is seen in Burkitt lymphoma. Patients usually will be adolescents or young adults presenting with extranodal masses. It may sometimes present as leukemia.

Option C: t(11;22) is seen in Ewing sarcoma. It is a bone tumor presenting with swelling and tenderness over the site. Radiological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance

Option D: t(14;18) is seen in follicular lymphoma. They present with multiple areas of painless lymphadenopathy. Histopathology of the enlarged nodes would show nodular expansion of tumor cells, composed of small cells with cleaved nuclei (centrocytes) and larger cells with more cytoplasm (centroblasts).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with chronic kidney disease comes to the hospital with chest pain. ECG reveals ventricular tachycardia. The patient is suspected to have hyperkalemia. In addition to serum potassium, you decide to check the level of other electrolytes due to the patient's history of chronic kidney disease.  Which of the following is the best anticoagulant to be used while collecting this patient's blood?
questions.solution:
Lithium heparin is the best anticoagulant to use for electrolyte estimation.

Heparin:

  • It is the anticoagulant causing the least interference with the test.
  • It is the best anticoagulant to use when minimal hemolysis is desired e.g. for sodium and potassium.
  • Heparin accelerates the action of antithrombin III which neutralizes thrombin and thus prevents the formation of fibrin from fibrinogen.
  • Heparin is added (0.2 mg /mL of blood) or a drop of heparin is drawn into the syringe.
  • Usually found as Green Top tubes
  • Drawbacks:
    • It inhibits the acid phosphatase activity.
    • It gives a blue background for Wright’s stain smears so not good for peripheral blood smear interpretation.
    • It also affects the binding of triiodothyronine and thyroxine to their carrier protein and produces a higher free concentration of these hormones.
    • It interferes with binding of calcium to EDTA.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis. His fasting triglyceride levels were 1100 mg/dL. He mentions that his mother was diagnosed with a deficiency of lipoprotein lipase and on further investigation, he too was diagnosed with the same condition. Which of the following lipoproteins will be elevated in this patient's plasma?

VLDL- very low density lipoprotein

LDL- low density lipoprotein

HDL- high density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the presence of lipoprotein lipase deficiency indicate a diagnosis of type I hyperlipoproteinemia, where chylomicron, triglycerides and VLDL levels will be elevated.

Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as familial chylomicronemia syndrome or familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency is due to lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency, abnormal LPL, or apo C-II deficiency causing inactivation of LPL. It is an autosomal recessive condition. 

These patients show slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL, low levels of LDL and HDL. 

Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, eruptive/ pruritic xanthomas on the back, buttocks, and extensor surfaces, and recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. On funduscopic examination, the retinal blood vessels may appear opalescent, known as lipemia retinalis. The diagnosis should be suspected if the fasting triglyceride levels are greater than 750 mg/dL.

Lipoprotein lipase is required for the hydrolysis of triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol in circulating chylomicrons, that transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. Therefore, patients who are deficient in lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma after a fatty meal.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient with no significant past medical history presented with palpitations and associated dizziness for one month. She also complains of mild fever, fatigue, and breathlessness that occurs on sitting upright but is relieved on lying down. On examination, cyanosis is noted. On auscultation, a mid-diastolic "plop" is heard. Echocardiogram shows the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with platypnea (breathlessness on sitting upright), cyanosis, fever, mid-diastolic "plop", and an echocardiogram featuring a mass in the left atrium is suggestive of an atrial myxoma.

Myxomas are the most common type of primary cardiac tumor in adults.
  • They occur at all ages, but mostly in the 3rd to 6th decades of life.
  • They show a female predilection.

Atrial myxoma is most commonly located in the left atrium.

  • The region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum is the favored site of origin.
  • Mobile tumors exert a “wrecking-ball” effect, causing damage to the valve leaflets.
  • They can be sporadic (90%) or familial with an autosomal dominant trait.
Features Sporadic Type Myxoma Familial Type Myxoma
Incidence Single Multiple
Postoperative recurrence  NIL Present
Most common site Left atria  Ventricular 
Age   Younger age
  • The familial myxomas usually occur as part of a syndrome known as Carney complex, which includes the following:
    • Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast
    • Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi
    • Endocrine overactivity - (primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly)

Presentation:

  • Sudden in onset; positional in nature owing to the effect of gravity (platypnea- breathlessness on sitting upright)
  • Presents with obstructive signs and symptoms mimicking valvular heart diseases (palpitation, dizziness)
  • Embolic phenomenon: Embolization of tumor thrombi leading to stroke, MI, pulmonary embolism, DIC, etc.
  • Constitutional symptoms: Fever, weight loss, cachexia, malaise, arthralgia, rash, digital clubbing, Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Characteristic mid-diastolic "tumor plop" with loud S1 at the apex is heard on auscultation
  • Laboratory reports: Anemia, polycythemia, leukocytosis, elevated ESR and CRP, thrombocytopenia, thrombocytosis

Transesophageal/Transthoracic echocardiography is the diagnostic investigation. CT/MRI angiography can also be done.

Treatment: Surgical excision using cardiopulmonary bypass 

The image below shows a picture of an atrial cardiac myxoma arising from the region of the fossa ovalis and extending to the mitral valve orifice

Histopathology: Myxomas are composed of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. Peculiar vessel-like or gland-like structures are characteristically seen. Hemorrhage and mononuclear inflammation can be present

The image below shows abundant amorphous extracellular matrix containing scattered multinucleate myxoma cells in various groupings, including abnormal vessel-like formations.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option B: Fibromas are most common in children. They are usually single and ventricular in location. They are often calcified and tend to grow and cause arrhythmias and obstructive symptoms and should be completely resected when possible.

Option C: Rhabdomyomas are the most common cardiac tumors in infants and children and usually occur in the ventricles. They are hamartomatous growths, and the majority are multiple and are strongly associated with tuberous sclerosis. These tumors have a tendency to regress completely or partially; only tumors that cause obstruction require surgical resection.

Option D: Infective endocarditis is characterized by vegetation, which is a mass of platelets, fibrin, microorganisms, and scant inflammatory cells. On gross examination, the vegetations in infective endocarditis appear as large irregular masses on the valve cusps that extend into the chordae tendinae. Infection most commonly involves heart valves but may also occur on the low-pressure side of a ventricular septal defect, on mural endocardium damaged by aberrant jets of blood or foreign bodies, or on intracardiac devices themselves. The most common clinical manifestation is fever with a new-onset murmur.

questions.text:
A young boy who underwent an ileal resection developed bilateral centrocecal scotomas. Which of the following enzymes are dependent on the vitamin that is deficient in this condition?

1. Methylmalonyl CoA mutase
2. Cystathionine synthase
3. Folate reductase
4. Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
The clinical stem of bilateral centrocecal scotomas in a patient who had an ileal resection is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase and methionine synthase (1 and 4) are vitamin B12–dependent enzymes.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed by the terminal ileum. Thus, after ileal resection as in this patient, the development of vitamin B12 deficiency is likely. 

The vitamin B12–dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): It catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine.
  • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase: It catalyzes the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. The activity of this enzyme is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonyl-CoA and urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid, which is used to assess vitamin B12 nutritional status.

Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Other options:

Option 2- Cystathionine synthase is involved in the production of cystathionine from homocysteine and serine. Pyridoxal phosphate (the active form of vitamin B6) is required for this reaction. Hence, in vitamin B6 deficiency, homocysteine levels are elevated.

Option 3- Dihydrofolate reductase catalyzes the conversion of dihydrofolate and tetrahydrofolate. It is an NADPH-dependent reaction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was posted for surgery and the OT technician is preparing the operation theatre after an exhausting day. He was ordered to change the oxygen cylinder in the theatre. He brought the cylinder and when trying to connect it, he couldn't connect the pin index system and saw that he was trying to connect in the wrong pin index system as shown below. Which of the following gas cylinders is connected in this pin index system?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Pin index system (3,5) of Nitrous oxide. 

Pin index system (PISS) is a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment.

  • Each gas cylinder has two holes (except entonox) in its cylinder valve that fits the corresponding pins in the yoke of the anesthesia machine. The relative positioning of the pins and holes is unique for each gas which constitutes the pin index system.
  • The PISS should only be considered as partial protection because pin index failures have been reported due to bent or broken pins.

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2P1 presents in her 28th week of pregnancy. She has no significant medical history. Her blood group is B negative. She says that she did not receive the Anti-D immunoglobulin after her previous delivery. A Doppler ultrasonography was done and the peak systolic velocity of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) was found to correspond to 1.6 multiples of the median (MoM).  Identify the correct statement regarding this method of monitoring.

choices.text: If MOM is 1.5-1.7, she should be monitored with weekly MCA Doppler
MCA peak velocimetry after 34 weeks gestation gives increased false negative results
Middle cerebral artery velocimetry increases the risk of alloimmunization
If MOM is 1.7 prior to 34 weeks gestation, fetal blood transfusion is considered

questions.solution:
Middle Cerebral Artery  Doppler peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV) is used for the monitoring of fetuses of Rh-negative sensitized mothers, and if it exceeds 1.5 MoM and the gestational age less than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling followed by transfu­sion is considered.

Serial mea­surements of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal MCA is reliable, noninvasive, and the recommended test to detect fetal anemia. Blood gets shunted to the brain to maintain adequate oxy­genation. A rise in cardiac out­put and a fall in blood viscosity enhance the peak systolic velocity in the MCA.

The threshold value to identify fetuses with anemia is 1.5 multiples of the median (MoM) for gestational age and is 100% sensitive. 

For an MCA PSV between 1.0 and 1.5 MoM, weekly Doppler monitoring to be done. If MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM and the gestational age is lesser than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling followed by fetal transfusion to be done if needed. 

Beyond 34 weeks, the false-positive rate of MCA peak systolic velocity increases due to the normal increase in cardiac output that develops at this gestational age.

Middle cerebral artery velocimetry is more accurate than and has replaced amnionic fluid spectral analysis and is not associated with the risks of increased alloimmunization and amniocentesis. It is also applied clinically to evaluate fetal growth restriction.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with hypoglycemia and muscle weakness. On examination, he had hepatomegaly and growth restriction. Investigations revealed the accumulation of characteristic branched polysaccharides on enzyme assay and distention of hepatocytes with glycogen in the liver. Which enzyme is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of growth restriction, hypoglycemia and muscle weakness with the accumulation of branched polysaccharides(limit dextrin) and glycogen deposition in the liver suggests a diagnosis of Cori disease, which occurs due to the deficiency of a debranching enzyme. Hypoglycemia and muscle weakness indicate debranching enzyme deficiency in both the liver and muscles.

Glycogen debrancher deficiency (Glycogen Storage Disease III) is also known as Cori disease, Forbes disease, and limit dextrinosis. When the debranching enzyme is defective, there is incomplete glycogen breakdown with an accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branch chains, resembling limit dextrin.

It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. When both the liver and muscle are involved, it is termed type IIIa GSD, while if only the liver is involved (15% of cases), it is classified as type IIIb.

The disease presents in infancy and childhood with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, short stature, variable skeletal myopathy, and variable cardiomyopathy. Hepatic symptoms in type III GSD usually improve with age, however, progressive liver cirrhosis and failure can occur. Hepatocellular carcinoma may develop. Hypoglycemia is associated with other features:

  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Fasting ketosis
  • Elevated liver transaminases
  • Normal blood lactate and uric acid levels 

It may be clinically indistinguishable from von Gierke’s disease (Type I GSD). However, the accumulation of limit dextrins (branched polysaccharides) is unique to Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through liver, muscle, or both enzyme assays.

Treatment is mainly by preventing hypoglycemia. Frequent high-carbohydrate meals with cornstarch supplements or nocturnal gastric drip feedings are effective. A high-protein diet during the day plus overnight protein enteral infusion is also effective. A hepatic transplant may be done for patients with progressive cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B. Glucose 6-phosphatase deficiency of this leads to Type 1 GSD or Von Gierke's disease. It presents with growth retardation, glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, ketosis, hyperlipemia, and elevated uric acid levels.

Option C. Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to Type V GSD or Mc Ardle disease. It presents with poor exercise tolerance,  myoglobinuria on strenuous exercise, and increased levels of creatinine kinase.

Option D. Lysosomal acid α-glucosidase deficiency leads to Type II GSD or Pompe's disease. In infants, it presents as hypotonia, muscle weakness, cardiac enlargement, and failure, fatal early. Late-onset presentation is with progressive muscle weakness and atrophy.

questions.text: A  patient presented with fever, sore throat, dysphagia, and a tonsillar pseudomembrane. A throat swab was taken and sent for culture on potassium tellurite agar. A characteristic culture pattern was noticed as shown below. Which of the following is true about the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever, sore throat, dysphagia, and a tonsillar pseudomembrane is suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria. The given picture shows the presence of daisy-head colonies on tellurite blood agar and is suggestive of Corynebacterium diphtheria gravis which ferments glycogen and starch.

McLeod classified diphtheria bacilli into three groups-gravis, intermedius, and mitis based on colony morphology on tellurite blood agar. Tellurite blood agar is a selective medium for the culture of diphtheria bacilli. The colonies have a grey or black color due to tellurite being reduced to metallic tellurium by the bacilli.

questions.text: The reaction below summarises the formation of an end product of arginine. Identify the enzyme X.
questions.solution:
The enzyme X is nitric oxide synthase (NO synthase). Nitric oxide is synthesised from arginine by a calcium-dependent reaction catalysed by NO synthase. 

Arginine, O2, and NADPH are substrates for cytosolic NO synthase. The co-enzymes of NO synthase include flavin mononucleotide (FMN), flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), heme, and tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4).

There are three types of NO synthases. Two are Ca2+-calmodulin-dependent enzymes found in vascular endothelium and neural tissue, and one is a Ca2+-independent enzyme that is expressed in cells such as hepatocytes, macrophages, monocytes, and neutrophils.

Functions of NO:

  • Vasodilator: NO activates the cytosolic form of guanylate cyclase. This increases cGMP, and activates protein kinase G, inactivates myosin light-chain kinase and thereby decreases smooth muscle contraction.
  • Macrophage bactericidal activity: Production of NO synthase is stimulated by bacterial lipopolysaccharide and γ-interferon released in response to infection. The NO formed combines with superoxide radicals from macrophages to form the OH radical which is highly bactericidal. 
  • Inhibitor of platelet aggre­gation (by activating the cGMP pathway)
  • Neurotransmitters in the brain

Other options:

Option B: Arginase catalyzes the cleavage of L-arginine, forming urea and L-ornithine. Defective arginase leads to the inherited metabolic defect hyperargininemia.

Option C: Arginine-glycine amidinotransferase acts on glycine and arginine producing guanidinoacetate, which is a step in the biosynthesis of creatine and creatinine.

Option D: Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I is involved in the synthesis of citrulline from Carbamoyl Phosphate in the urea cycle.

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2 P1 lady at her 20th week of gestation presents to the clinic. Her anomaly scan is suggestive of bilateral renal agenesis. On examination, her fundal height is 15 cm. Which among the following parameters is likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Bilateral renal agenesis leads to decreased production of amniotic fluid or oligohydramnios, and the single deepest vertical pocket will be less than 2 cm. (option D).

Oligohydramnios refers to an abnormally decreased amount of amnionic fluid. A diagnosis of oligohydramnios is made when amniotic fluid index (AFI) is less than 5 cm or a single deepest vertical pocket (DVP) of amniotic fluid is less than 2 cm.

Causes of oligohydraminios:

  • Placental abnormalities
  • Maternal complications leading to uteroplacental insufficiency: Pre-eclampsia, vascular disease
  • Renal anomalies:
    • Bilateral renal agenesis
    • Bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Unilateral renal agenesis with contralateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Infantile form of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney dis­ease
    • Fetal bladder outlet obstruction - posterior urethral valves, urethral atresia, or stenosis
  • Complex fetal anomalies: persistent cloaca and sireno­melia 
  • Drugs: ACE inhibitors, ARBs, NSAIDs when taken in the 2nd or 3rd trimester

Other options:

Options A and B imply polyhydramnios since the AFI is greater than 24 cm, and the single deepest vertical pocket (DVP) is greater than 8 cm.

Option C: AFI = 10 cm indicates normal AFI (5–25 cm)

questions.text:
A patient is undergoing the estimation of p-aminohippuric acid (PAH) clearance. He was infused with PAH and the plasma and urinary concentration were measured. It shows the following values-
  • Concentration of PAH in urine: 14 mg/mL
  • Urine flow : 0.7 mL/min
  • Concentration of PAH in plasma- 0.02mg/mL

Which of the following is the correct conclusion? (GFR- glomerular filtration rate, ERPF- Effective renal plasma flow)
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the effective renal plasma flow (RPF) is 490mL/min. 

Clearance is defined as the volume of plasma from which a particular substance is completely removed by the kidney in a given amount of time (usually minutes). Para aminohippuric acid (PAH) is filtered by the glomeruli and secreted by the tubular cells. Therefore, the amount of the PAH that enters the kidney is almost completely removed. It means that the entire renal plasma is cleared from PAH in a given time. Because of this reason, PAH clearance measures the renal plasma flow.

The formula used to calculate PAH clearance (CPAH) is:

 UPAH × V ⁄ PPAH  where,

UPAH - Concentration of PAH in urine- 14mg/mL

PPAH - Concentration of PAH in plasma- 0.02mg/mL

V - Urine flow- 0.7 mL/min

Substituting the values given in the question, we get:

PAH clearance =  UPAH × V ⁄ PPAH ,

= (14 x 0.7)/0.02

= 9.8 / 0.02

= 490 mL/min.

In an actual scenario, about 90% of the PAH is removed by the kidney. Therefore this is called effective renal plasma flow. Actual renal plasma flow is calculated by dividing the PAH clearance with an extraction ratio. The extraction ratio is arterial concentration minus renal venous concentration divided by arterial concentration. Normally the extraction ratio is 0.9.

If we consider the extraction ratio to be 0.9 in this scenario, the actual renal plasma flow will be

= 490/0.9

= ~544 mL/min

Similarly, inulin and creatine clearance is used in the measurement of the glomerular filtration rate.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient presented with hematuria, pedal edema, and hypertension. He also gives a history of episodes of hemoptysis in the past. His renal biopsy showed crescent formation and a linear pattern of staining on immunofluorescence. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the renal biopsy findings suggest Goodpasture syndrome/anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) disease. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Type II hypersensitivity is characterized by an antigen-antibody reaction on the cell surface or in the extracellular matrix, leading to the destruction of the cells and consequent inflammation. The antibody against a specific antigen can lead to cellular destruction by either opsonization and phagocytosis or by complement activation. 

In Goodpasture syndrome, antibodies directed against the GBM also cross-react with the basement membrane of the lung's alveoli. This causes the characteristic clinical picture of pulmonary hemorrhage associated with renal failure. The antibodies are targetted against a peptide in the non-collagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV. In the kidney, anti-GBM antibodies lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, characterized by the formation of crescents. On immunofluorescence, deposition of IgG and C3 is seen in a linear pattern along the GBM. 

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A patient presents with a lower gastrointestinal bleed. Sigmoidoscopy shows ulcers in the sigmoid colon. The histopathological image of the biopsy from the ulcer is given below.  Which of the following is the infective form of this organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing flask-shaped ulcers are suggestive of intestinal amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of E. histolytica.

In amebiasis, amoeba attach themselves to the colonic epithelium, induces apoptosis, invade crypts and burrow laterally into the lamina propria. This recruits neutrophils and causes tissue damage, resulting in flask-shaped ulcers with a narrow neck and broad base.

The following are the characteristic features of the various life stages of E. histolytica.

Trophozoite:

  • It is found only in tissues.
  • Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance.
  • The nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called the linin network, thus giving a cartwheel appearance.
  • Pseudopodia are present, which exhibit gliding motility.

The image given below shows the trophozoite form of E. histolytica.

Precystic stage:

  • It has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars.
  • It secretes a refractile cyst wall to become a cyst.

Cystic stage:

  • The mature cyst has 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.
  • Chromatid bars disappear.

The image given below shows the cyst form of E. histolytica.

Treatment involves three classes of drugs: 

  • Luminal amebicides like diloxanide furoate, paromomycin which act in the lumen
  • Tissue amebicides like emetine and chloroquine
  • Both luminal and tissue amebicides like metronidazole and tinidazole.

The following image shows the life cycle and complications of E. histolytica.

questions.text: You are the autopsy surgeon posted in a community health centre. You receive a case of a young man alleged with a history of road traffic accident with the deceased body found on the sides of the roads. On opening the scalp you notice the following finding as shown in the image. Identify the finding seen in this case.
questions.solution:
The given image of a victim of a road traffic accident shows subgaleal haemorrhage. It is bleeding in the potential space between the skull periosteum and the scalp galea aponeurosis.

The image depicts a collection of blood mass just below the galeal apoenurosis which is best appreciated after reflection of scalp. 

Contusions may occur in the superficial fascia, in the temporalis muscles, or in the loose areolar tissue between the galea aponeurotica and the pericranium. Subgaleal haematoma does not show any colour change in general. It is generally seen when the vault of the skull is fractured and when the blood extravasates into the scalp tissues from the ruptured diploic veins. It is better felt than seen. Rarely multiple contusions of the scalp may join together and in such cases, it is often difficult to determine the number of blows inflicted. 

It can also be confused with a depressed and longitudinal fracture of the skull bones or with an extradural haemorrhage. 

Extradural haemorrhage (EDH) is bleeding in the space between the dura mater and the skull vault. The image below shows EDH. The image clearly depicts an intact dura mater along with a concavity of the external brain matter and a sharply defined clot mass.

The clot presses the dura inward and causes a localised concavity on the external surface of the brain. The clot is generally oval or circular, of a rubbery consistency, and reddish-purple. It is usually seen in the temperoparietal area or the fronto-temporal or parieto-occipital region.

 

Cerebral haemorrhage traumatic intracerebral haemorrhage results from the coup-contrecoup mechanism. It is mostly seen in the frontotemporal region and is often associated with a fracture of the skull. Large haemorrhage may occur in the inferior part of the head of the caudate nucleus and pallidum. These are generally from the tears of small branches of the anterior choroid artery. 

The given image shows cerebral haemorrhage with bleeding into the right corpus striatum.

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is the hemorrhage in the subarachnoid space between the arachnoid and pia mater, mixed with CSF. It is mostly arterial in origin secondary to rupture of Berry's aneurysm. SAH is extensive because CSF and unclotted subarachnoid blood flow freely in the subarachnoid space. When the brain is removed at autopsy, the arachnoid membrane remains to cover the brain.

Note:

As per the textbooks in forensic, SAH is believed to be venous in origin. But as per Harrisons and Bailey, it is arterial in origin.

The image shows subarachnoid haemorrhage below the dura mater. Generally, once the dura layer is removed SAH can be appreciated. 

 

The image shown below sums up the locations of various hematomas and the layers involved in the same.

questions.text: You are a new intern posted in the department of ophthalmology. In the case file of a patient who had undergone a total penetrating keratoplasty, you see the ophthalmic examination findings saying that  'Khodadoust lines' are seen. In which of the conditions would you notice this finding?
questions.solution:
Khodadoust lines following penetrating keratoplasty are seen in a case of endothelial graft rejection. Khodadoust lines refer to a linear pattern of keratic precipitates associated with an area of inflammation at the graft margin.

Corneal graft rejection

The corneal graft is immunologically privileged, with an absence of blood vessels and lymphatics and the presence of relatively few antigen-presenting cells. Thus, they seldom are subject to graft failure or rejection. Predisposing factors for rejection include larger grafts >8 mm, infection, glaucoma, and previous keratoplasty.

Patients may have blurred vision, redness, photophobia, and pain. However, many patients remain asymptomatic until rejection is established. Corneal graft rejection can be of four types:

  • Epithelial rejection - elevated level of epithelium is noticed. 
  • Sub-epithelial rejection - usually due to residual adenoviral infection. These form infiltrative opacities called Krachmer spots. 
  • Stromal rejection - these present with deeper haziness.
  • Endothelial rejection - These are characterized by Khodadoust lines. It is the most common form of graft rejection leading to failure.

Stromal edema is indicative of graft failure and the presentation is almost always akin to anterior uveitis.

 

The other signs of anterior uveitis are as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the area marked on the visceral surface of the spleen?
questions.solution:
The area marked on the visceral surface of the spleen is related to the left kidney.

The visceral surface of the spleen as shown here faces inferomedially. It has three important surface impressions i.e. the gastric impression, the renal impression, and the colic impression.  The superolateral surface is in relation to the diaphragm, and this area is separated from the gastric impression by the anterosuperior border as shown in the above diagram. The anterosuperior surface has 1-2 notches, which are thought to be remnants of the lobulated form of the spleen during embryological development. The renal impression is the area that is related to the left kidney. This impression is separated from the diaphragmatic surface by the posteroinferior border of the spleen. It is separated from the gastric impression by the splenic hilum and a small ridge of tissue. 

The spleen has two poles. The superior pole is more angulated than the inferior pole, which is broader. The superior pole is the poster-most part of the spleen, close to the vertebral column. The inferior pole is related to the colic impression, which is close to the splenic flexure of the large colon, as well as the phrenicocolic ligament (the ligament connecting the diaphragm and the colon). The inferior pole is also most likely to be injured during blunt abdominal trauma. 

The hilum of the spleen in the middle of the visceral surface is the part of the spleen where the splenic vessels, nerves, and lymphatics penetrate the splenic tissue. The tail of the pancreas has its visceral impression between the hilum and colic impression.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with gestational diabetes is undergoing vaginal delivery. After the delivery of the head, the obstetrician is unable to deliver the shoulders and classifies it as shoulder dystocia. She performs the following maneuver for delivery. It achieves all of the following except:

choices.text: Rotation of symphysis pubis towards the maternal head
Decrease in angle of pelvic inclination

questions.solution:
The image depicts the McRoberts maneuvre. It does not increase the pelvic dimensions.

McRoberts manoeuvre consists of forceful abduction and flexion of maternal hips and positioning the maternal thighs on to the abdomen. Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.

It is used to free the impacted anterior shoulder through the following:

  • Straightening of the sacrum relative to lumbar vertebrae.
  • Rotation of symphysis pubis towards the maternal head.
  • A decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination.

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.

questions.text: Which of the following does not suggest a diagnosis of septate uterus?

choices.text: Absence of sagittal notching on USG

questions.solution:
The absence of the uterine fundus makes a septate uterus less likely and is suggestive of a bicornuate uterus.

Septate uterus is associated with the following findings:

  • Absence of sagittal notching on ultrasonography
  • Inter-cornual distance < 4 cm on ultrasonography
  • Angle of divergence between uterine cavities ≤ 75° on hysterosalpingography
  • Presence of uterine fundus seen on laparoscopy or in an MRI scan
  • The fundal midpoint is more than 5 mm above the line joining the ostia of the fallopian tubes

The absence of these findings with an angle of divergence ≥105° makes a bicornuate uterus more likely. An absent uterine fundus would also be suggestive of a bicornuate uterus.

questions.text: A newborn child presents with the following finding in the right eye as shown in the image below. The left eye is normal. What is the ideal age to take this patient up for elective surgery?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dense unilateral congenital cataract. Ideally, unilateral dense cataract merits urgent surgery and it is at 6 weeks when elective surgery should be performed.

Generally, it is not advisable to operate on lamellar cataracts until the child is 1 or preferably 2 years old. But when the lens is completely opaque, or the pupil will not dilate, and when squint or nystagmus is developing, it is wise to operate at an earlier age. Moreover, the results of surgery in unilateral cataracts in children are universally poor, unless the operation is carried out within the first 6 weeks of birth.

This is because the critical period for developing the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visual deprivation disorders is between 2 and 4 months of age. Thus, any cataract dense enough to impair vision must be dealt with before this age and the earliest possible time is preferred. 

Surgery involves anterior capsulorhexis, aspiration of lens matter, capsulorhexis of the posterior capsule, limited anterior vitrectomy, and IOL implantation, if appropriate. It is important to correct associated refractive errors.

Related Pearl: Types of Congenital Cataract

Punctate cataract: Blue-dot cataract, most common congenital cataract

 

Zonular/Lamellar cataract: Most common congenital cataract with diminished vision; Spokes of a wheel appearance (Rider’s Cataract) A, B, and C

 

Fusiform/coralliform cataract: Anteroposterior spindle shaped appearance. 

 

Nuclear cataract: Most common type of cataract seen in congenital rubella syndrome

 

Coronary cataract: Appears as a corona of club-shaped opacities near the periphery of the lens.

 

Anterior polar cataract: May arise either due to delayed development of anterior chamber or due to corneal perforation

 

Posterior polar cataract: Progressive form of posterior polar cataract, which typically shows an "onion whorl appearance"

questions.text: A study found that the incidence of bladder carcinoma is 5 times higher in smokers than in non smokers. Calculate the attributable risk.
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the attributable risk (AR) is 80%.

Taking the incidence of disease in non-exposed as x, the incidence of disease in exposed would be 5x. 

Attributable risk (AR) would be given as [(5x - x)/5x] x 100 = 80%.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where,

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A patient with a known history of peptic ulcers comes with hematemesis. The urea breath test is positive. The patient's gastric biopsy is taken, and the slide is shown below. The patient is at the highest risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and gastric biopsy showing curved bacteria filling the lumen of a gastric foveola is indicative of Helicobacter pylori infection. This patient is at the highest risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma.

H. pylori is a gram-negative bacillus that lives in gastric mucus and duodenum. It is acid-resistant and motile due to its spiral shape and flagella.

H. pylori is a known risk factor for peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, gastric adenocarcinoma, and gastric lymphoma. However, the risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma is much more than the risk of developing gastric lymphoma.

Many studies have shown H. pylori is protective against peptic esophageal diseases, including esophageal adenocarcinoma and GERD. It is due to H. pylori-induced hypochlorhydria. 

Diagnosis of H. pylori is by:

  • Tests based on endoscopic biopsy - biopsy urease test, histology, and culture of the biopsy specimen.
  • Non-invasive tests - 13C Urea breath test and stool antigen test is useful for follow-up after treatment. H. pylori contains an enzyme called urease. It splits urea into carbon dioxide and ammonium ions. In urea breath test, 13C is ingested by the patient. If H. pylori is present, the urease activity generates 13C-labeled CO2 that then can be detected in the patient’s exhaled breath.

The given image shows Helicobacter pylori on gastric mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain.

questions.text: The given ECG depicts which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a premature ventricular complex (PVC) that occurs every second beat (ventricular bigeminy).

PVCs exhibit premature timing by arising before the anticipated occurrence of the subsequent regular heartbeat. They display an aberrant QRS-T appearance, where the QRS complex appears unusually wide (0.12 sec or longer), and the T wave and QRS complex point in opposite orientations (discordant).

Frequent PVCs can manifest in different patterns. When two PVCs occur consecutively, they are termed a pair or couplet.

If three or more PVCs occur in succession (triplet), it is classified as ventricular tachycardia (VT). The repetitive pattern of one normal beat followed by one PVC is known as ventricular bigeminy.

When the repeating sequence involves two normal beats followed by a PVC, it is called ventricular trigeminy. Similarly, if three normal beats are followed by a PVC, it is referred to as ventricular quadrigeminy.

questions.text: The following finding is seen in a 3-day-old newborn. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: The palms and soles are usually spared
It is a benign finding in newborns
They are neutrophil laden sterile lesions
Lesions usually persists for only a week

questions.solution:
The lesions seen in the given image indicate erythema toxicum. The false statement is option C as these lesions predominantly contain eosinophils.

Erythema toxicum is a benign finding in a newborn that resolves on its own (Option B). It presents with papular lesions on an erythematous base, predominantly distributed over the trunk and face. The palms and soles are usually spared (Option A). This condition is seen 1-3 days after birth and may persist for 1 week (Option D). The lesions resolve spontaneously and do not require any treatment.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A newborn developed cyanosis soon after birth. Chest x-ray showed the characteristic egg-on-a-string appearance, as shown in the below image. Which of the following options indicates the relation of the aorta with respect to the pulmonary artery in the given condition?

choices.text: Aorta lies posterior and to the left of pulmonary artery
Aorta lies anterior and to the left of pulmonary artery
Aorta lies posterior and to the right of pulmonary artery
Aorta lies anterior and to the right of pulmonary artery

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an x-ray showing egg on a string appearance is characteristic of transposition of great arteries (TGA). In TGA, the aorta generally lies anterior and to the right of the Pulmonary artery. Therefore it is also referred as D-TGA.

TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood which can occur:

  • At atrial level: Through atrial septal defect (ASD)
  • At ventricle level: Through ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • At great vessel level: Through patent ductus arteriosus

Treatment: Here, prostaglandin E1 administration and septostomy help initial stabilization by creating a communication between the right and left atria, thereby facilitating the mixing of systemic and pulmonary circulations.

questions.text: A 38-year-old multigravida at 34 weeks of gestation presented to the outpatient department with a history of painless vaginal bleeding. On examination, there is a fall in fetal heart rate when the fetal head is pushed into the pelvis. Identify the true statement about the condition associated with the sign described.

choices.text: Transabdominal sonography is the most accurate method of assessment.
MR imaging has replaced sonography in diagnosis.
Per vaginal examination should be avoided.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of painless vaginal bleeding with positive Stallworthy's sign is suggestive of placenta previa and the true statement associated with it is per vaginal examination should be avoided, as it can lead to torrential hemorrhage.

Stallworthy's sign refers to the slowing of the fetal heart rate when the head is pressed down into the pelvis. It recovers as soon as the pressure is released. It is suggestive of the presence of a low-lying placenta, particularly if located on the posterior wall of the uterus. 

Placenta previa is characterized by abnormal implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. 

Common risk factors for placenta previa include

  • Previous cesarian section
  • Myomectomy
  • Advanced maternal age (>35 years)
  • Smoking
  • multiple gestation
  • Multiparity
  • Prior curettage

Diagnosis :

  • Transabdominal sonography: A quick and accurate localization can be accomplished if the placenta clearly overlies the cervix or if it lies away from the lower uterine segment. Its limitations include:
    • Poor visualization in obese women
    • A full bladder may give a false impression that the placenta is overlying the cervix.
  • Transvaginal sonography: The most accurate method to assess the placental location. It is not contraindicated in placenta previa and is safe even when there is bleeding.
  • MRI: Localizes placental location excellently, gold standard but does not replace sonography in routine diagnosis.
  • In case of inconclusive USG reports or USG revealed type 1 placenta, a vaginal examination is done in operation theatre under anesthesia. This is done with preparation for an immediate cesarean section. 

There are four types of placenta previa depending upon the degree of extension of the placenta to the lower segment.

  • Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the internal os.
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

Note: For clinical purpose, the types are graded into,

  • Mild degree (Type-I and II anterior) and
  • Major degree (Type-II posterior, III, and IV).

Planning and implementation of their own individual healthcare is a right and duty of the people
Health requires collective effort from the social, economic and healthcare sector

questions.solution:
Rights of the individuals seeking healthcare and freedom of choice was not part of the Alma-Ata Declaration. It was part of the Declaration of Lisbon. 

The Alma-Ata Declaration was made of the following affirmations-

  1. Health, in its definition, is a world-wide social goal that requires a collective effort of social and economic sectors along with the healthcare sector.  
  2. The existing health status gap between people of the developed and developing world is socially, politically, economically unacceptable and is a common worldwide concern 
  3. For the fullest attainment of health for all, there must be an equivocal economic and social development. It is essential to protect the health of people to maintain economic and social growth. This leads to a better quality of life and world peace.
  4. Planning and implementation of their individual healthcare is a right and duty of the people 
  5. Provision of adequate health and social measures is a responsibility of the government towards the health of its population. The concept of primary health care was begun as a part of attaining this target as part in the spirit of social justice.
  6. The concept of primary health care is based on catering to essential healthcare needs based on practical, scientifically sound and socially acceptable methods and technology. Provision of universally accessible healthcare for all through community participation at an affordable cost with the spirit of self-reliaince and determination aids in the overall development of the country. Primary health care forms the grassroot level of contact of communication with the population, thereby making it an important tool for management and development of healthcare services. 
  7. Primary health care:
    1. Economic, political and socio-cultural characteristics of the country are reflected and evolved from each of its communities. Application of the relevant results of social, biomedical and health services research and public health experience aids in improvement of the healthcare system.
    2. Promoting healthcare in the community- preventive, curative and rehabilitative services and addressing the main health problems in the community
    3. Following provisions are to be included- Health education on existing problems, prevention and control; Nutrition and food supply; Proper sanitation and supply of safe water; Maternal and child health- family planning and immunization; Knowledge about locally endemic diseases- prevention and control; Treatment of common diseases and injuries; and Essential drugs; 
    4. Involves and demands coordinated efforts of other sectors such as- agriculture, animal husbandry, food, industry, education, housing, public works, communications, etc along with the health sector, in aspects of national and community development. 
    5. Promotes maximum community and individual self-reliance. Education and participation of community in the planning, organization, operation and control of primary health care, making fullest use of local, national and other available resources. 
    6. Sustained by integrated, functional and mutually supportive referral systems, allowing for improvement of comprehensive health care for all, prioritizing those with the greatest need  
    7. Work force including at local and referral levels includes- health workers, including physicians, nurses, midwives, auxiliaries and community workers as applicable, traditional practitioners who are suitably trained socially and technically to work as a health team
  8. Formulation of national policies, strategies and plans of action to launch and sustain primary health care as part of a comprehensive national health system and in coordination with other sectors by the governments by exercising political will to mobilize and utilize all available resources- national and international.  
  9. Global Cooperation in the spirit of partnership and service to ensure primary health care for all. Attainment of health by people in any one country directly concerns and benefits every other country. 
  10. An acceptable level of health for all the people of the world by the year 2000 can be attained through a fuller and better use of the world's resources along with a reduction in the amounts spent on armaments and military conflicts.
    A policy of independence, peace, détente and disarmament could and should release additional resources that could well be devoted to peaceful aims and in particular to the acceleration of social and economic development 

Related Pearl: Health-related International Declarations:

  1. Declaration of Alma-Ata (1978): Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All.
  2. Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion (1986): The aim of the conference was to continue to  achieve the objectives of the World Health Organization (WHO) Health for all by the year 2000.

3. Declaration of Oslo (1970): Related to therapeutic abortion.

4. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): Guidelines for medical doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment. (T – Tokyo – Torture)

5. Declaration of Helsinki (1975): Related to human experimentation. (H – Helsinki – Human experimentation)

6. Declaration of Geneva (1948): Most recent amendment was done on October 14, 2017 in Chicago. It gives the modern version of the 2500-year-old Hippocratic Oath which laid down the fundamental principles of medical ethics that any physician should follow.

7. Declaration of Malta (1991, revised in 1992): Related to hunger strikes.

8. Declaration of Lisbon: Related to rights of the patients like right to information, confidentiality, dignity, freedom of choice etc.

9. Declaration of Sydney on human death: It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasising the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.

The statement also recommended that two or more physicians should make the diagnosis of death when organs were removed for transplantation.

10. Declaration of Istanbul: To address the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

11. Declaration of Taipei: Related to ethical considerations regarding health databases and biobanks.
