questions.text: A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his coworkers due to agitated behavior. He says he is seeing the air and seems to be talking to invisible stimuli. When the nurse was taking vitals, he lashed out at her and started throwing things in the emergency. He has no history of psychiatric illness. Vitals recorded show: Temp (99F), BP: 160/90, HR (130/min), Respiratory rate (18/min). On examination, the patient is confused, agitated, and sweating. Pupils are dilated bilaterally and nystagmus is noted. There is increased muscle tone and mild motor incoordination. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+. Intoxication of which of the following is responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with agitation, hallucinations, confusion, nystagmus, and violent behavior. These features point towards Phencyclidine intoxication. 

Phencyclidine is a hallucinogen that can cause agitation, confusion, hallucinations, dissociative feelings, tachycardia, nystagmus. In many cases, violent behavior is also seen. Nystagmus, hypertension, and hyperthermia are common effects of PCP. Muscle rigidity is also sometimes observed.

Physiological changes from hallucinogens include:

  • Pupillary dilation
  • Tachycardia
  • Sweating
  • Palpitations
  • Blurring of vision
  • Tremors
  • Incoordination

NO physical dependence is noted for Phencyclidine even after repeated use.

Other Options:

Opiate Intoxication: It presents as altered mood, psychomotor retardation, drowsiness, slurred speech, impaired memory and attention, miosis and decreased bowel sounds. It causes dependence and withdrawal. Features like nystagmus, ataxia, and violent agitation are not seen.

Cannabis: It is characterized by red eye, mild tachycardia, increased appetite ("the munchies"), dry mouth. However, nystagmus, ataxia, and violent agitation are not seen.

Cocaine Intoxication: It is characterized by compulsive behavior, severe insomnia, weight loss, irritability, impaired ability to concentrate with elevated HR. But nystagmus, ataxia, and violent agitation are not seen.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with primary infertility. She has no other complaints. On the hysterosalpingogram, the right fallopian tube has a tobacco pouch appearance. Which part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in this underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario of primary infertility and a hysterosalpingogram finding of the "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube is suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The ampullary part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in genital tuberculosis.     

The fallopian tubes are almost always involved in genital tuberculosis. The lesions are generally bilateral. The mode of spread of the disease is hematogenous, arising from a primary infective focus in the lung. The ampulla is most commonly affected, while the fimbriae and interstitium are spared. 

Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to a primary focus elsewhere. The most frequent location is the lungs (50%), although it can also come from lymph nodes (40%), kidneys, joints, the gastrointestinal system, or as part of a broad miliary infection. It mostly spreads via the haematogenous route or lymphatics sometimes. 

In Genital tuberculosis, the leading presenting complaints include infertility, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm. 10-15% of women are found to be asymptomatic as well. 

Hysterosalpingogram may reveal the following: 

  • Tobacco pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Lead pipe appearance (rigid, nonperistaltic pipe)
  • Beading and variation due to filling defects
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Jagged fluffiness of tubal outline

Hysteroscopy will reveal the presence of synechiae, partial obliteration of the cavity, the golf-hole appearance of the tubal ostia, and the presence of ulcers.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with incoordination, tremors, and impaired concentration. On examination, the abdomen is distended and the liver is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. The ophthalmic examination is shown in the picture.  Which of the following is the gold standard test for the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wilson's disease with the ophthalmic examination showing a typical sunflower cataract and the gold standard test for the diagnosis of this patient is liver biopsy.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper transport, primarily affecting the liver and brain (hence, it is also known as hepatolenticular disease). It occurs due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene. This gene encodes ATP7B, a copper-transporting ATPase, which is responsible for biliary copper excretion and incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin.

Clinical features of Wilson's disease are:

  • Hepatic: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, ascites, cirrhosis, anorexia
  • Neurologic: Dystonia, dysarthria, dysphagia, rigidity, tremors, abnormal gait, uncoordinated handwriting
  • Psychiatric: Decreased scholastic performance, irritability, depression, and anxiety
  • Ophthalmic:
    • Kayser-Fleischer rings: These are golden-brown rings formed due to the deposition of copper in descemet’s membrane of the cornea. They are present in 95% of patients with neurologic/psychiatric symptoms and 65% of patients with hepatic symptoms.
    • Sunflower cataracts: These are formed due to the deposition of copper in the lens.
  • Autonomic: Orthostatic hypotension; sweating; bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction
  • Endocrine: Delayed puberty, amenorrhea
  • Hemolytic anemia (due to the release of copper from necrosed hepatocytes into the bloodstream)
  • Osteoporosis and rickets
  • Renal Fanconi syndrome

Laboratory findings show low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels and elevated hepatic enzymes. Increased urinary excretion of copper (>100 μg/24 h) is also an important diagnostic test. However, percutaneous needle liver biopsy to measure hepatic copper remains the gold standard. Hepatic copper values >200 μg/g of dry weight indicate Wilson’s disease.  DNA testing for mutations in ATP7B can be done and can make a definitive diagnosis in about 50–75% of patients.

Treatment of Wilson's disease includes:

  • Copper chelation:
    • D-penicillamine: It increases urinary excretion of copper and prevents copper overload. Pyridoxine (vitamin B6 ) is administered along with it to counter pyridoxine deficiency that occurs due to penicillamine.
    • Triethylenetetramine dihydrochloride: This chelating agent is given in patients intolerant to D-penicillamine and those with severe neurologic manifestations (D-penicillamine worsens neurological status).
    • Tetrathiomolybdate: This fast-acting agent decreases copper absorption and circulating free copper. It is currently under clinical trials.
  • Zinc acetate: This is used to reduce copper absorption. Zinc is beneficial in pregnancy (lower teratogenic effects) and as a maintenance therapy.
  • Liver transplantation: This is considered in advanced stages of irreversible hepatic damage or poor compliance with medical therapy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with a history of gestational diabetes was admitted to the labor room at her 38th week of gestation. Just prior to the crowning of the head, a mediolateral episiotomy was performed after administering local anesthesia. Which among the following methods is ineffective in providing analgesia for episiotomy?

choices.text: Local infiltration of the fourchette, perineum and vagina

questions.solution:
The paracervical block is ineffective in providing analgesia for episiotomy.  

Analgesia can be provided by bilateral pudendal nerve block or local infiltration of 1% lidocaine into the fourchette, perineum, and vagina. 2.5% lidocaine-prilocaine cream (EMLA cream) can also be used if applied 1 hour before expected delivery. Pain with vaginal delivery arises from stimuli from the lower genital tract which are transmitted mainly through the pudendal nerve.

Episiotomy refers to a surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor, at the time of crowning. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

The other types of episiotomy include median (midline), lateral, and J-shaped episiotomy.

Structures cut : 

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering these muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

The image shows the histological section of the epidermis. The structures marked are respectively:

  4.  Stratum basale

questions.text: A researcher in pathology is conducting experiments related to chemical carcinogenesis. Which of the following chemical carcinogens requires metabolic activation for conversion into active carcinogens?
questions.solution:
Benzidine requires metabolic activation for conversion into an active carcinogen.

All initiating chemical carcinogens are highly reactive electrophiles that may target the DNA, RNA, or proteins. Initiation occurs after cells are exposed to a sufficient dose of a carcinogen. It causes DNA mutations which are passed on to daughter cells. Chemicals that can cause the initiation of carcinogenesis are of two types:

  • Direct-acting carcinogens require no metabolic conversion to become carcinogenic. Most are weak carcinogens, but some are important because they are cancer chemotherapeutic drugs. Examples include:
    • Dimethyl sulfate
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Chlorambucil
    • Nitrosoureas
    • Dimethylcarbamyl chloride
  • Indirect-acting carcinogens or procarcinogens are chemicals that require metabolic conversion to become active carcinogens. The carcinogenic product of metabolism is called an ultimate carcinogen. Examples include:
    • Benzanthracene
    • Benzopyrene
    • β-naphthylamine
    • Benzidine
    • Natural plant and microbial products like aflatoxin B1, griseofulvin, betel nuts
    • Nitrosamines and amides
    • Vinyl chloride, nickel, chromium

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who works in the glass manufacturing industry comes with complaints of abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and blueline on the gums. You suspect lead poisoning. Which among the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is a notifiable and compensatable disease
Lead sulphide is the most toxic lead compound
Inhalation is the mode of absorption in most cases
D-penicillamine as chelating agent is effective

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding lead poisoning is option B. Lead sulphide is considered the least toxic among the lead compounds.

Lead poisoning/plumbism is a notifiable and compensatable disease.

Industries that utilize lead are glass manufacturing, ship-building, printing and potteries, storage batteries, and rubber industries. All lead compounds are toxic - lead arsenate, lead oxide, and lead carbonate are the most dangerous; lead sulphide is the least toxic.

Inhalation of fumes and dust of lead is the mode of absorption seen in most cases. Other modes are ingestion and absorption through the skin.

Management: D-penicillamine is reported to be an effective chelating agent.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food for the past 7 months. He also complains of a feeling of food getting stuck in his throat. Serial images of barium swallow are given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: It occurs between the oblique and horizontal fibres of inferior constrictor

questions.solution:
The clinical features and the barium swallow images are suggestive of Zenker’s diverticulum, which is a false diverticulum.

A true diverticulum involves all the layers (mucosa, submucosa, muscularis). Since Zenker's diverticulum involves only the mucosa coming out through Killian's dehiscence, it is considered a false type of diverticulum. Furthermore, it is a pulsion type of diverticulum — that is, it develops due to the high pressure present inside the pharynx and not due to any pulling force from the outside.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A weight lifter presented with a swelling over the right side of the neck, which becomes prominent while lifting weights. While compressing over the swelling, a gurgling sound can be heard. Radiological investigations show an air-filled mass with an external component. Which of the following is the best management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with a positive Bryce sign is suggestive of external laryngocele. The treatment for external laryngocele is excision of the swelling. Bryce's sign is the gurgling/hissing sound heard on compression of the swelling.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule of the ventricle.

It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. It presents with hoarseness, cough, and if large, causes obstruction of the airway.

Types of laryngocoele are

  •  Internal - confined within the larynx and presents as distension of false cord and aryepiglottic fold.
  • External - the distended saccule herniates through the thyroid membrane and presents in the neck. It presents as a reducible swelling in the neck, increasing in size on coughing or performing Valsalva manoeuvres. 
  • Mixed - both external and internal compounds are seen.

Diagnosis is done by indirect laryngoscopy, soft tissue AP and lateral views of the neck x-ray with Valsalva. CT scan helps to find out the extent of the lesion. 

External type is managed by surgical excision through an external neck incision. Internal type is managed by marsupialization and endoscopic carbon dioxide laser resection.

questions.text: A 2 years old male child is brought with pellagra like symptoms and cutaneous photosensitivity. Elder sister has similar symptoms. Two siblings are normal. The child most likely has__________

choices.text: Branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase deficiency

questions.solution:
The above clinical history of pellagra like symptoms, photosensitivity in a 2 year old child with autosomal inheritance is suggestive of Hartnup disease. Hartnup disease (pellagra like dermatosis) is an autosomal recessive condition caused due to a single defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan and other monoamino monocarboxylic amino acids (neutral amino acids). This results in decreased availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis. Thus, manifesting as pellagra like symptoms.

Clinical features:

  • Most of the children are asymptomatic
  • However, major clinical manifestation in the rare symptomatic patient is, cutaneous photosensitivity
  • The skin becomes rough and red after moderate exposure to the sun and with greater exposure, a pellagra-like rash may develop. The rash maybe pruritic and chronic eczema may also appear.
  • Some patients may also have an intermittent ataxia, manifested as an unsteady wide based gait, which usually lasts for few days, and recovers spontaneously.

Diagnosis:

  • Urine testing for amino acids.
  • Diagnosis of Hartnup disease is made by showing the characteristic amino acid excretion pattern in urine. Indoles and other tryptophan degradation products in urine provide supplementary evidence of the disease.

Treatment:

  • Niacin or niacinamide supplements
  • Nicotinamide for attacks

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy comes with fever, malaise, and flaccid paraplegia of 4 days. How are the fecal samples for diagnosis transported?

choices.text: 4 samples, sent within 72 hours of collection
2 samples, sent within 48 hours of collection
2 samples, sent within 72 hours of collection
4 samples, sent within 48 hours of collection

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests acute flaccid paralysis. 

Fecal samples of all cases of acute flaccid paralysis are obtained (2 samples) and transported to the laboratory within 72 hours of collection at 4–8 degree Celcius or frozen at -20 degree Celcius. This is known as the Reverse Cold Chain, done as a part of gold standard polio surveillance. 

‘Adequate’ stool specimens are two stool specimens of sufficient quantity for laboratory analysis, collected at least 24 hours apart, within 14 days after the onset of paralysis, and arriving in the laboratory by reverse cold chain and with proper documentation

There are fours steps under AFP surveillance:
  1.  Finding and reporting children with AFP: 
    • The staff in all health facilities should report every case of AFP in any child less than 15 years of age.
    • The surveillance system of the country should be able to detect at least one case of AFP for every 1,00,000 children under 15 years of age, even in the absence of polio.
  1. Transporting stool samples for analysis:
    • All children with AFP should be tested for wild poliovirus.
    • The fecal samples are used to test for polio.
    • The specimens should be collected within the first two weeks after the onset of paralysis since the highest concentration of the poliovirus is found during this period.
    • Two specimens taken 24-48 hours apart are required.
    • The specimens are stored at 4-8°C and the specimens should reach the laboratory within 72 hours of collection.
  1. Isolating poliovirus:
    • Isolation of the virus followed by distinguishing between wild and vaccine-related poliovirus.
    • If wild type is isolated, then the virologists identify which of the two surviving types is involved.
  1. Mapping the virus:
    • If the wild type of virus is found, the genetic makeup of the virus is further studied and is compared with the reference bank of known polioviruses to know about the geographical origin of the virus.
    • Once the geographical area is identified, the source of the importation virus can be known. Immunization strategies can be determined accordingly.

Environmental Surveillance involves testing sewage and other samples from the environment for poliovirus. It can confirm wild poliovirus infection in the absence of cases. It provided supplementary surveillance data. Ad-hoc environmental surveillance, especially in polio-free zones gives information on the international spread. 

Surveillance Indicators 

  • Completeness of reporting- At least 80% of expected routine (weekly or monthly) AFP surveillance reports should be received on time, including zero reports where no AFP cases are seen. The distribution of reporting sites should be representative of the geography and demography of the country
  • Sensitivity of surveillance- At least one case of non-polio AFP should be detected annually per 100000 population aged <15 years. In endemic regions, to ensure even higher sensitivity, this rate should be two per 100000.
  • Completeness of case investigation- All AFP cases should have a full clinical and virological investigation with at least 80% of AFP cases having ‘adequate’ stool specimens collected.
  • Completeness of follow-up- At least 80% of AFP cases should have a follow-up examination for residual paralysis 60 days after the onset of paralysis
  • Laboratory performance- All AFP case specimens must be processed in a WHO-accredited laboratory within the Global Polio Laboratory Network (GPLN)

 

The differential diagnosis for acute flaccid paralysis include the following:

  • Non-polio enteroviruses
  • West Nile virus
  • Guillan–Barre syndrome
  • Other neurotropic viruses: rabies, varicella-zoster, and Japanese encephalitis

questions.text: A young boy was brought by his parents with complaints of nausea, abdominal cramps, and watery diarrhea for 2 days. The parents mentioned that the family was away on a cruise ship, where they consumed raw oysters. The boy's younger brother also had watery diarrhea and had one episode of vomiting the same morning. Which of the following is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of acute gastroenteritis following the consumption of raw oysters on a cruise ship is most likely suggestive of infection with the Norwalk virus.

Norwalk virus is a small, rounded, non-enveloped single-stranded, positive RNA virus that accounts for more than half of nonbacterial acute gastroenteritis for all age groups in developed and underdeveloped countries. 

They occur in group settings such as banquet halls, cruise ships, dormitories, and campgrounds, where outbreak sources are usually contaminated food and/or water. Potential sources of contaminated food include shellfish such as clams and oysters, which are contaminated by water at the source.

Factors contributing to the rapid spread include feco-oral transmission, low infective dose, and high environmental stability of the virus.

Clinical features include nausea, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery diarrhea after 1-2 days of incubation period and continue for approximately 1-3 days. Vomiting is more common in children. Viral shedding can occur up to 2-3 weeks after cessation of clinical symptoms.

RT-PCR is widely used to identify infection. RT-PCR can also be used to detect the virus in environmental specimens such as drinking water or contaminated food or both. Treatment is supportive.

The image given below is of norovirus under electron microscopy.

Other options:

Option A: Orthomyxoviruses are enveloped, single-stranded, and have a negative-sense, segmented RNA. This group of viruses includes the influenza virus. It is a respiratory virus.

Option B: Adenovirus is a non-enveloped, double-stranded, DNA virus. Although adenovirus can cause gastroenteritis in children, however, the history of consumption of raw oysters on a cruise ship is most likely suggestive of infection with the Norwalk virus. Adenoviruses can also cause pharyngitis, pharyngoconjunctival fever, keratoconjunctivitis, pneumonia, hemorrhagic cystitis, and disseminated disease.

Option D: Reovirus is a non-enveloped, double-stranded, segmented RNA virus. Reoviruses have not been proven to cause any human disease.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is tasked with ensuring water treatment of the city's water sources using the Nalgonda technique. What is the Nalgonda technique used for?

choices.text: Defluoridation of water using lime and alum
Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal
Air floatation of grains to remove ergot

questions.solution:
The Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water. It involves the addition of alum (aluminum sulfate), lime (calcium oxide), and bleaching powder, followed by rapid mixing, flocculation, sedimentation, filtration, and disinfection.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5 mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Nalgonda, Prakasam), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu. 

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5 mg/L): This occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It is best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects only permanent teeth. It causes mottling on dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white patches on the teeth, and loss of shine in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and can even become brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance. 
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6 mg/L): This occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, and fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone; these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10 mg/L) Can lead to permanent disability. 

The given images show dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis (interosseous membrane calcification), respectively:

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • Chemical treatment in a water treatment plant can be moderately expensive. The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age.

Other options:

Superchlorination of water is the addition of large amounts of chlorine to the water, for disinfection. The excess is later removed. It is done for heavily polluted water with fluctuating quality.

Controlled super-chlorination is break-point chlorination. Chlorine is added to ammonia in water to produce chloramines, which do not have the same efficiency as free chlorine. If the chlorine dose is increased, there is a destruction of the chloramine causing a reduction in the residual chlorine and the end products formed do not represent any residual chlorine. With a further increase in the chlorine dose, there is a progressive fall in residual chlorine. When the combined chlorines have been destroyed, the residual chlorine begins to increase in proportion to the added dose of chlorine. This is the breakpoint dose. It achieves the same effects as super chlorination, but in a rational manner.

Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal is done for lathyrism. The toxin beta oxalyl amino alanine in its crystalline form is water-soluble. The pulse is soaked in boiling water for 2 hours and the water is drained off completely. It is then washed with clean water and dried. 

Air floatation of grains is done to remove ergot, which is a field fungus. It can be removed by floating the grains in 20% saltwater, air floatation, or hand-picking.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is being evaluated for precocious puberty. Pelvic ultrasound revealed a right-sided adnexal mass. Serum inhibin levels are elevated. The patient underwent staging laparotomy to remove the tumor and the histopathological image of the tumor is shown below. What is the finding in the given slide?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing features of precocious puberty in the presence of an ovarian tumor and elevated levels of inhibin is suggestive of granulosa cell tumor, an estrogen-secreting ovarian tumor. Histopathological image is showing characteristic Call-Exner bodies.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time it is seen in post-menopausal women. 

These tumors are usually unilateral. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. The presence of this tumor in prepubertal girls may lead to precocious puberty. The serum and tissue inhibin levels are elevated.

The cut section is soft and has a yellowish reticular or trabecular appearance with interstitial hemorrhage. On microscopy, Call- Exner bodies are seen which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material recall immature follicles. 

Other options:

Option B: Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is the second most common malignant ovarian tumor. Schiller -Duval bodies are pathognomonic on histopathology. This structure consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells.

The below image shows Schiller- Duval bodies.

Option C: Psammoma bodies are concentrically calcified structures seen in serous tumors of the ovary but are not specific for neoplasia. 

Option D: Signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. It is the carcinoma of the stomach metastasized to the ovary. 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)

  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma

  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary

questions.text: A baby is brought to the OPD with a deformity in the hip and lower limbs. On examination, there is an asymmetry of the groin crease and a click sound is heard on moving the left hip.  The following test is done and found to be positive. Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and a positive Galeazzi's test as shown in the above image are suggestive of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The female sex of the baby is a risk factor for developing this condition.

Galeazzi's test is done between 3 to 8-month-aged children in unilateral cases of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). To perform this test, the child is in the supine position with the hip and knee in flexion. The level of both knee joints is noted with respect to a horizontal line. Normally both knees should be at the same level. In DDH, the affected knee is seen at a lower level indicating femoral shortening.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip or congenital dysplasia of the hip is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. Risk factors for DDH include:

  • Sex of the baby- females are more susceptible to DDH due to the action of maternal relaxin on the fetal joints in-utero predisposing it to dislocation. It is 3-5 times more common in females.
  • Intrauterine positioning- breech position is associated with a higher incidence of DDH
  • Genetic predisposition- DDH is more common in children of parents who had DDH themselves.
  • First born child

Examination of the developmental dysplasia of the hip:

1) Newborn to 3 months of age. Tests to check instability of the hip:

  • Asymmetrical skin creases in the inguinal, gluteal, and thigh regions.
  • Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum producing a palpable "clunk". 
  • Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk".

2) At 3-6 months of age:

  • Galeazzi's test 
  • Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.
  • Decreased abduction on the affected side.

3) In children of walking age:

  • Trendelenburg gait
  • Positive tredelenburg sign
  • Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of DDH

AGE OF THE PATIENT                 MANAGEMENT

6-18 months Closed or open reduction followed by hip spica after reduction
18-36 months Open reduction with femoral shortening and pelvic osteotomy (Salter's osteotomy, Pemberton osteotomy, Steel osteotomy)
3-8 year Open reduction with femoral shortening and pelvic osteotomy 
8-18 year

Open procedure with femoral shortening with pelvic osteotomy or total hip replacement

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the boundaries of the nasal valve?

choices.text: Laterally by the lower border of upper lateral cartilage.
Caudally by the floor of the pyriform aperture.
Laterally by the anterior end of the middle turbinate.
Medially by the cartilaginous nasal septum.

questions.solution:
Nasal valve is bounded laterally by the anterior end of the inferior turbinate.

All the other 3 options form the boundaries of nasal valve.

Nasal valve area: It is the cross-sectional area bounded by the structures forming the nasal valve. It is the least cross-sectional area of the nose and regulates airflow and resistance on inspiration.

Related Pearl: Boundaries of the nasal valve

  • Laterally: Lower border of upper lateral cartilage and fibrofatty tissue and anterior end of inferior turbinate
  • Medially: Cartilaginous nasal septum
  • Caudally: Floor of the pyriform aperture

The nasal valve is the narrowest part and offers maximum resistance to airflow

questions.text: Which type of inquest is considered to be most superior in an investigation?
questions.solution:
Medical examiner's system is considered to be most superior in comparison to other forms of inquests.

Medical examiner's system:

  • This system is not followed in India. It is followed in certain states of the USA and Japan.
  • A board-certified Forensic pathologist or a practitioner is present in the team which conducts the inquest. 
  • He gets first-hand information on the investigation, scene of the crime, and this when correlated with autopsy findings, carves out a better picture.
  • Though he is not entitled to any judicial powers, the inquest conducted in the presence of a doctor makes it superior to any other method.

Inquest:

 An inquest is an inquiry or investigation into the cause of death. 

Types of inquest:

Those followed in India:

  1. Police inquest
  2. Magistrate inquest

Other types:

  1. Coroner's system - abolished in India in 1999.
  2. Medical examiner's system
  3. Procurator fiscal

Police Inquest:

  • Provision for the same as outlined in Sec.174 CrPC.
  • The inquest is held by a police officer (called Investigating Officer), not below the rank of Senior Head Constable only after approval from a first-class magistrate. It is practiced throughout India.

Magistrate Inquest:

  • Magistrate’s inquest is an inquest conducted by a District Magistrate, Subdivisional Magistrate, and magistrate of the first-class rank or any other magistrate as empowered by the State Government, such as Collector, Deputy Collector or Tehsildar (Executive Magistrates). 
  • Provision for the same as outlined in Sec.176 CrPC.

Special Magistrate’s inquest is held in cases of:

• Lock-up deaths

• Deaths while under police interrogation

• Deaths in prison

• Deaths in police custody

• Deaths due to police firing

• Exhumation

• Alleged dowry death

• In all cases where the police normally conduct inquests, the magistrate can hold an additional inquest, or in place of the police inquest.

Note: It is practiced throughout India. However, it is not held routinely but held only on special indications mentioned above. In any case of unnatural death, the magistrate may hold an inquest instead of or in addition to the police inquest.

Coroner's Inquest:

  • A coroner is usually a first-class magistrate or attorney.
  • He is appointed by the state government to handle suspicious cases.
  • He has quasi-judicial powers and can give out an open verdict.

Procurator Fiscal:

  • This system is followed in Scotland.
  • Fiscal is a person who would investigate cases of sudden, unexplained, or suspicious deaths.
  • He can also request for an autopsy to be conducted.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding and itching. What is the mutation associated with this disease?

choices.text: Mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase signalling pathway

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of basal cell carcinoma. Mutations in the hedgehog signaling pathway are associated with basal cell carcinoma.

Nodular basal cell carcinoma presents as a small, slowly growing pearly nodule with rolled borders, often having dilated telangiectatic vessels on its surface, and a central crust. The occasional presence of melanin in this variant of nodular BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

The most common site is the inner canthus of the eye.

Other options:

Mutations in cell cycle regulators (option A), receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway (option B), and those that activate telomerase (option C) are associated with melanomas. They typically appear as irregular, asymmetric macular lesions with variable pigmentation (shades of black, brown, red, dark blue, and gray). They are usually asymptomatic but occasionally are itchy or painful. Clinical signs include changes in the color, size, or shape of a pigmented lesion.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text: The vector in the following image can transmit all of the following diseases, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a hard tick. It transmits all the diseases mentioned above except rickettsial pox, which is transmitted by the house mice mite.

A hard tick's head is visible as it is situated at the anterior end, whereas a soft tick's head is not visible from above because it lies on the underside of the body. A chitinous shield covers the entire back in males and females have a small portion of scutum in the front.

The hard tick transmits the following diseases.

  • Tick typhus (Rickettsia conorii)
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Kyasanur forest disease
  • Tularemia, tick paralysis
  • Human babesiosis (Babesia microti)
  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (Rickettsia rickettsii).

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect action about the structure marked with '?' in the following clinical and cadaveric images.

choices.text: It enhances the economy of bipedal locomotion
It is active during the swing phase of gait
It is active during the stance phase of gait
It helps to effect eversion of the foot

questions.solution:
The '?' marked structure in the clinical and cadaveric image is peroneus tertius. It is not active during the stance phase of gait.

Peroneus tertius/ Fibularis tertius:

It is a part of the anterior compartment of the leg.

Attachments: It often appears to be part of the extensor digitorum longus and might be described as its ‘fifth tendon’. Its fibers arise from the distal third or more of the medial surface of the fibula, the adjoining anterior surface of the interosseous membrane, and the anterior intermuscular septum. It is inserted onto the medial part of the dorsal surface of the base of the fifth metatarsal; a thin expansion usually extends forwards along the medial border of the shaft of the bone.

Relations: It lies lateral to the extensor digitorum longus.

Innervation: It is innervated by the deep fibular nerve, L5, S1.

Actions: During the swing phase of gait, it acts with extensor digitorum longus and tibialis anterior to produce dorsiflexion of the foot, and with fibularis longus and fibularis brevis to effect eversion of the foot. This helps in improving efficiency and enhances the economy of bipedal locomotion. It is not active during the stance phase.

Testing: It cannot be tested in isolation, but its tendon can sometimes be seen and felt when the foot is dorsiflexed against resistance (as shown in the above image).

The animations below show a superior and inferior view of the peroneus muscles. The muscle marked with blue is the peroneus longus, red is the peroneus brevis, and green is the peroneus tertius.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient came to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of pain over the left ear. The image of his left ear is given below. What is the next line of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows a cauliflower ear deformity, which is likely due to auricular hematoma. It is treated by aspiration and tight pressure dressing.

Auricular hematoma is a collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium. It is often seen in boxers, wrestlers, and rugby players due to blunt trauma.

Extravasated blood may clot and then organize, resulting in a typical deformity called cauliflower ear. It is also called pugilistic or boxer’s ear.

If the hematoma gets infected, severe perichondritis may set in.

All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics.

OTHER OPTIONS:

  • Incision and drainage should be done only after aspiration fails.
  • Topical antifungals has no role in Boxer’s ear.
  • Rapid rewarming of ear is done in case of frost bite of the ear.

questions.text: According to DSM-5, which of the following is not a type of presentation of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder?
questions.solution:
According to the DSM-V, attention deficit and hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is diagnosed with one of three specifiers – predominantly inattentive, predominantly hyperactive/impulsive, or combined presentation with features of both.

For a diagnosis of ADHD, the following criteria have to be satisfied:

  • 6 out of 9 symptoms of inattention and/or hyperactivity with impulsivity have to be present for at least 6 months.
  • Symptoms should have started before the age of 12 years.
  • Symptoms must be present at least in two settings, such as home, school, work, etc.
  • Symptoms must have a negative impact on social and academic/occupational functioning.
  • Symptoms don’t occur exclusively during the course of a psychotic disorder and aren’t explained by any other mental disorder.

Note: For adults and adolescents aged 17 or older, 5 out of 9 symptoms are adequate for diagnosis.

questions.text: A mother brings her 7-year-old daughter with the complaint that the child wakes up at night screaming, sweating, and terrified. She does not respond to the comforting efforts by her parents. She does not recall the episode in the morning. In which stage of sleep do the episodes experienced by the daughter occur?
questions.solution:
The child who wakes up with intense fear and signs of arousal such as sweating, and does not recall the event in the morning is experiencing sleep terrors or night terrors. Night terrors occur in deep sleep (stages 3 and 4 of NREM sleep).

Sleep terror or night terror is an NREM sleep arousal disorder. In this condition, the patient experiences sudden arousal with intense fearfulness. They may have a piercing scream or cry with manifestations of intense anxiety.

On arousal, they sit up in bed, are unresponsive to stimuli, and are confused and disoriented on awakening. Autonomic disturbances may be present. If vocal, they are incoherent. The patient cannot generally be awakened and efforts to calm them are not successful.  

Sleep terrors only have brief frightening or vivid images, or may not have imagery at all. It can be provoked by sleep deprivation, fever, and central nervous system depressant withdrawal. 

Nightmares have elaborate dream sequences without autonomic disturbances. They occur in REM sleep. The patient can be aroused and typically remembers the dream.

The various stages of sleep and their appearance on EEG are summarized in the image below.

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient with chronic kidney disease comes for a routine follow-up. His chest radiograph is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a mitral annular calcification. It is a chronic degenerative process affecting the mitral valve ring and can be a rheumatic sequela. 

The clinical vignette gives clues towards the multiple co-morbidities and complications that may be associated with MAC. 

  • Stroke
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Chronic Kidney Disease 
  • Mitral Regurgitation 
  • Mitral Stenosis 
  • Arrhythmias, atrial fibrillation 
  • Endocarditis 
  • Aortic Stenosis 

Surgical treatment is indicated only if concomitant stenosis or regurgitation is to be corrected. Severe MAC makes the surgery difficult. Isolated MAC does not require endocarditis prophylaxis. Anti-coagulation and anti-platelet medications are recommended within the guidelines of treatment of the comorbid conditions. 

Other options:

Option A - In aortic sclerosis, there can be aortic valvular calcifications with cardiomegaly. Signs of heart failure such as pulmonary venous congestion and pulmonary interstitial/alveolar edema can be seen. 

Option C - Atrial Myxomas have non-specific x-ray findings- 

  • Cardiomegaly: left atrial enlargement
  • Intracardiac tumoral calcification
  • Mitral valve obstruction evidence 
  • Elevated left atrial pressure findings- pulmonary edema

Option D - A calcified atrial thrombus is a rare entity that may show up as calcified lesions in the cardiac shadow on a chest x-ray. They are usually discovered by transthoracic echocardiography.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are incorrectly matched with their imaging modality of choice?

choices.text: Hirschsprung’s disease- Plain x-ray abdomen with air contrast
Neonatal hepatitis- Nuclear medicine; hepatobiliary scintigraphy

questions.solution:
The imaging modality of choice in Hirschsprung's disease is a contrast radiograph with barium or gastrografin enema. 

The most important film is a lateral or oblique view of the rectum during slow filling. It typically shows a low bowel obstruction. The rectum is seen as a narrow tube and a cone-shaped transition zone, seen proximal to the dilated ganglionated bowel. 

 

Other options:

Transfontanel cranial ultrasonography or a neurosonogram reliably delineates ventricular size and anatomy in neonates. It is an excellent primary imaging technique for the evaluation of the many clinical problems related to ventricular dilatation. 

  1. Ventriculomegaly
  2. Differentiating nonobstructive ventricular dilatation from obstructive enlargement (hydrocephalus)
  3. Cause of hydrocephalus
  4. Temporary management of patients with hydrocephalus
  5. Aiding in the management of patients with permanent ventricular shunts

Ultrasound in pyloric stenosis will show a dilated, fluid-filled stomach and proximal duodenum with obstruction. A coexisting volvulus can show as a whirlpool sign. 

Hepatobiliary scintigraphy is a radionuclide imaging that shows metabolic activity in different cell types based on the substance taken up by the various cells.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the casualty department following a fall on an outstretched hand. He has pain, deformity, and swelling over his left elbow. The x-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the injuries and complications associated with this condition?

choices.text: Gunstock deformity due to cubitus valgus  is a complication.
Vascular injury commonly involves the brachial artery.
Ulnar nerve  is most commonly injured in flexion type fracture.
Anterior interosseous nerve is most commonly injured in extension type fracture.

questions.solution:
The clinical features and x-ray are suggestive of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus, and it is associated with cubitus varus deformity or gunstock deformity.

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

  • Most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years.
  • Most common type of supracondylar fracture: Extension type > Flexion type
  • Most common mechanism of injury: Fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension
  • Gartland classification is used for supracondylar fractures

Gartland classification (in children):

  • Type I: Undisplaced
  • Type II: Displaced but posterior cortex is intact
  • Type III: Displaced but no intact posterior cortex and distal fragment could be either displaced:
    • Posteromedial
    • Posterolateral
  • Type IV: Complete loss of anterior and posterior periosteal hinge making it unstable in both flexion and extension

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture. Three-point bony landmarks in the elbow are the tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and the olecranon.

Nerve injury:

  • Most common nerve to be injured in extension type - anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve > Ulnar nerve. (AMRU)
  • Most common nerve to be injured in flexion type - Ulnar nerve.

Vessel injury:

  • Most common vessel to be injured - brachial artery.

On examination:

  • There may be an S-shaped deformity at the elbow. If the proximal fracture fragment is sharp and has penetrated the muscles and fascia, a dimple may be seen on the skin above the elbow (dimple sign).

Radiology:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle (humeral-capitellar angle) can help in assessing the degree of medial angulation before reduction.

Complications:

  • Malunion - posteromedially displaced fracture tends to develop cubitus varus (gunstock deformity)
  • Nerve injury - usually neuropraxia, hence transient
  • Volkmann’s ischemic contracture and compartment syndrome 

Treatment of Supracondylar fracture:

  • Undisplaced fractures are immobilized at 90 degrees and neutral rotation with a cast and the arm is supported by a sling for 3 weeks.
  • Open fractures, severely displaced fractures, and fractures with vascular damage are fixed by open reduction and K-wire fixation.

Treatment of Cubitus Varus deformity includes:  

  • Lateral closed wedge osteotomy - French
  • Medial open wedge osteotomy - King's

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient with a history of smoking presented with a painless palpable mass in the parotid region. The biopsy of the mass is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation and histopathological slide showing epithelial elements with lymphoid infiltration are suggestive of a Warthin tumor (papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum) of the parotid gland.

Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor.

The gross appearance of these tumors shows round to oval encapsulated masses, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with an inner columnar layer and an outer cuboidal layer.

Other options:

Option A: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is poorly encapsulated infiltrative carcinoma involving minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells, organized in a cribriform growth pattern, resembling swiss cheese. The image is shown below.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Many are associated with a balanced (11;19) (q21;p13) chromosomal translocation. Histology shows mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles. Image is shown below.

Option D: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is most commonly involved. They are benign tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. Image is shown below.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: An African American man came to the clinic with the lesion shown below. He says it has been there for years and seems to increase in size. It recurred after surgery. What is the underlying abnormality of this patient's lesion?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a keloid scar. The underlying abnormality of keloid scars is the excessive accumulation of collagen with hypervascularity.

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and certain parts of the body such as the triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip. These are more common in African Americans and tend to be inherited.

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and the keloid scar's excision has a high recurrence rate.

Note: The same pathology is seen in hypertrophic scars but they tend to be within the margins of the wound and rarely grow beyond the margins of the original wound. 

Other options:

Option A: The exuberant proliferation of fibroblasts is seen in desmoid tumors, a low-grade neoplasm occurring due to exuberant proliferation of fibroblasts and other connec­tive tissue elements, following inci­sional scars or traumatic injuries.

Option B: Excessive accumulation of granulation tissue is seen in proud flesh, where excessive amounts of granulation tissue protrude above the level of the surrounding skin and block re-epithelialization.

Option D: Exaggerated wound contraction occurs in contractures, where excessive contraction leads to deformities of the wound and surrounding tissues.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with the lesions shown in the image. She also says that she has difficulty climbing the stairs and raising her arms above her head. The eyelids appear red in color. The probable diagnosis is _____.
questions.solution:
This image shows Gottron's papules, indicating a probable diagnosis of dermatomyositis, which is pathognomonic for this condition.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations.

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Gottron’s papules - erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles
  • Heliotrope rash - erythematous discolouration of eyelids with periorbital edema
  • Shawl sign, which is macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • V sign- rash on the sun-exposed anterior neck and chest
  • Nail bed telangiectasia
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Mechanic’s hands- non‐inflammatory hyperkeratosis occurring on the hands or feet, usually over the radial surfaces of the fingers and the outer border of the feet
  • Deposition of calcium in the tissues

The image below shows shawl sign.

questions.text: A 25-year-old singer has undergone a subtotal thyroidectomy for thyroid nodules. She presents to you one week later with complaints of difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice when she tries to reach high notes. There is no difficulty in her breathing and her voice is otherwise normal. Paralysis of which muscle is responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Paralysis of cricothyroid is responsible for the difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice. 

Cricothyroid is the main tensor of the vocal cords. It is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve (branch of the superior laryngeal nerve).

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness reduced muscle stretch reflexes, with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, there is atrophy of the muscles below the knee. The following clinical findings are seen. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The given image shows muscle atrophy, high arch of the foot, and hammer-toes, which, along with the other clinical features mentioned above, are suggestive of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (CMT) is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. CMT is a syndrome of many genetically distinct disorders.

CMT type 1 is the most common form of hereditary neuropathy. It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop. The following findings are seen:

  • No numbness or tingling
  • Reduced sensation to all modalities apparent on examination
  • Reduced muscle stretch reflexes
  • Atrophy of the muscles below the knee, leading to inverted champagne bottle legs 

Diabetic neuropathy, primary amyloidosis, neuropathy associated with Sjogren’s syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis are acquired forms of neuropathies.

Other options:

Option B- Refsum's disease is a hereditary disorder of lipid metabolism. They can manifest in infancy to early adulthood with classic tetrad of:

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Cerebellar ataxia
  • Elevated CSF protein concentration

They have elevated serum phytanic acid, and they are autosomal recessive. 

Option C- Sjogren syndrome is a chronic, slowly progressing autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. Predominately seen in middle-aged women. The majority of them present with impaired lacrimal and salivary gland function. Neuropathy associated with Sjogren's syndrome is either sensory or sensorimotor polyneuropathy like mononeuritis multiplex and myelitis.

Option D- Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. The incidence increases between the ages of 25 and 55 years. Chronic inflammation of the ankle and midtarsal regions leads to pes planovalgus or flat feet. Other deformities seen in RA are: 

  • Swan-neck deformity
  • Boutonniere deformity
  • Z-line deformity

Related Pearl: Neuropathic Disorders

  • Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (Most common hereditary neuropathy)
  • Tangier disease
  • Friedreich’s ataxia
  • Familial Amyloid Polyneuropathy
  • Hereditary Neuropathy with Liability to Pressure Palsies (HNPP)
  • Hereditary Neuralgic Amyotrophy (HNA)
  • Hereditary Sensory and Autonomic Neuropathy (HSAN)
  • Fabry’s disease (angiokeratoma corporis diffusum)
  • Refsum’s disease

  • Diabetic neuropathy
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
  • Scleroderma, Sarcoidosis
  • Infectious (VZV,CMV,EBV,Hepatitis, HIV, Diphtheria, Leprosy) 
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP)
 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with the limb in the position shown in the image.  Her mother mentions that she grabbed her daughter by the right wrist to prevent her from falling off the bed. There was no other trauma. No swelling or focal point tenderness is elicited but she cries when supination is attempted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?

choices.text: Casting of the elbow and forearm
Attempted reduction by sudden complete supination

questions.solution:
The image shows Nursemaid's Elbow/ Pulled Elbow. The history of lifting by holding the forearm and the child refusing to let anyone touch her hand is pointing towards the diagnosis of the pulled elbow.

Downward dislocation of the head of the radius from the annular ligament is a fairly common injury in children under the age of 6 years.

The mechanism of injury involves axial traction on the forearm with the elbow extended. ( child pulled, lifted, or swung by arm ) Characteristically the child holds the elbow in extension with the forearm pronated. No swelling, deformity, or focal tenderness.

The diagnosis is essentially clinical, though x-rays are usually obtained to exclude a fracture.

It is treated by fully supinating the forearm. While the child’s attention is diverted, the elbow is quickly supinated and then slightly flexed; the radial head is relocated with a snap.

 

Other options :

  • Casting or emergency surgical correction is not needed for radial head subluxation.
  • Observation would be inadequate at this point.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a dermatophytic infection. A scraping from the lesion was observed under the potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount. It revealed the macroconidia of the dermatophyte as shown in the image below. The species of this genera usually infects:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing spindle-shaped macroconidia point toward a diagnosis of Microsporum infection. The species of this genera usually infect skin and hair.

Dermatophytes involve only the superficial keratinized layer of skin, sparing the dermis. It should be differentiated from dermatomycosis which is the cutaneous involvement of systemic fungi.

Dermatophytes are classified into 3 types:

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair, and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but, not the nails. The species include M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails, not hair. Floccosum is the only species in this genus. Only Macroconidia.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum include:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellotape (cellotape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A young patient started neglecting one-half of his body after an accident. He uses only his right side of the body, trims his beard only on the right side of his face, and reads only the right half of the page. There are no apparent primary visual, auditory, or somatosensory defects. This occurs due to an injury in which of the following parts of the brain?

choices.text: Superior temporal gyrus of the categorical hemisphere
Inferior parietal lobule of the representational hemisphere
Superior part of the hippocampus and mammillary bodies
Angular gyrus of the representational hemisphere

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is neglecting one-half of his body. This is called unilateral inattention and neglect which occurs due to an injury to the inferior parietal lobule of the representational hemisphere.

In our human brain, one hemisphere is specialised for sequential-analytic processes (the categorical hemisphere or dominant hemisphere) and another is specialised for visuospatial relations (the representational hemisphere or the non-dominant hemisphere).

Lesions in the representational hemisphere lead to:

  • Astereognosis - the inability to identify objects by feeling them due to a lesion in the parietal lobe
  • Agnosia - inability to recognize objects by a particular sensory modality even though the sensory modality itself is intact. This commonly occurs due to a lesion in the parietal lobe. Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognise faces
  • Unilateral inattention and neglect - Patients neglect one-half of their bodies and may experience personal neglect syndrome. It occurs due to an injury to the inferior parietal lobule and a region of the posterior parietal cortex close to the occipital lobe.

The function of the non-dominant side of the parietal lobe is spatial orientation and constructional skills. Its lesion causes spatial disorientation, constructional apraxia, neglect of the non-dominant side, dressing apraxia, and homonymous hemianopia. 

The somatic sensory area and related parts of the posterior parietal lobe project to the premotor cortex. It is associated with aiming and manipulating the hands at an object and hand-eye coordination. Neurons in this posterior parietal cortex contribute to the descending pathways involved in motor control.

The functions of the dominant hemisphere are logical, analytical, sequential thinking, and verbal tasks, such as math, language forms, and philosophy. In this hemisphere, the parietal lobe is concerned with calculation, language, planned movement, and appreciation of size, shape, weight, and texture. A lesion here causes dyscalculia, dysphasia, dyslexia, apraxia, agnosia, and homonymous hemianopia. 

Other options:

Option A: Lesions in the superior temporal gyrus of the categorical hemisphere lead to Wernicke's aphasia. 

Option C: Lesions in the hippocampus, mamillary bodies, nucleus basalis of Meynert, and areas of the forebrain result in memory disturbances.

Option D: Lesions in the angular gyrus of the categorical hemisphere result in anomic aphasia.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student complains of an irresistible urge to move his legs, especially during his sleep. He is feeling comfortable only after doing so. He is also experiencing burning, itching, and cramp-like sensation in his legs. What is the ideal drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is restless leg syndrome. Ropinirole is a dopaminergic agonist approved for its treatment.

Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during periods of rest and especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of legs. In idiopathic cases, dopaminergic hypofunction is postulated.

Another dopamine agonist that can be used in the treatment of restless leg syndrome is pramipexole.

Other options:

Option A- Riluzole is a benzothiazole derivative that is used in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. They inhibit glutaminergic transmission.

Option C- Rilmenidine is an imidazoline receptor agonist that is used for the management of hypertension.

Option D- Rimonabant is an inverse agonist of the CB1 (cannabinoid receptor) that was used as an anti-obesity medication.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the condition shown below:

choices.text: It is also called as Pili incarnati
The incidence is higher in men of African descent
It is an acute condition that can be cured easily
It is a complication of hair removal

questions.solution:
The given image is that of Pseudofolliculitis barbae, Pili incarnati or Ingrowing hairs. Pseudofolliculitis is a chronic condition with a relapsing and remitting course.

Clinical Features:

  • The condition typically manifests as multiple small papules and pustules on shaven skin, particularly in the beard area. The skin of the neck and over the jaw is most commonly affected, although the cheeks may also be involved.
  • In cases where sites other than the beard area are affected, a history of shaving, plucking or waxing should help to clinch the diagnosis.
  • Pseudofolliculitis, particularly of the beard area, can result in hypertrophic or keloid scarring.
  • Men of African descent are particularly predisposed.

Pathophysiology:

  • Penetration of aberrant cut ends of the hair into the follicle or surrounding tissue results in acute inflammation, microabscesses and foreign‐body giant cell granuloma formation.
  • The condition is very common and more severe in those with tightly coiled curly hair.

Treatment:

  • The only certain cure is to stop shaving/waxing for a minimum of 4–6 weeks, to allow the inflammation to settle and allow the hairs to grow sufficiently long that ingrowth will not occur. Resumption of shaving or waxing will often, however, lead to relapse.
  • Some relief is possible with topical steroid–antimicrobial combinations combined with intensive use of emollients.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman was brought with complaints of confusion and agitation. Her husband reports that she drinks 2-3 beers a day and that she had taken excessive alcohol the previous day. On examination, she had difficulty in walking and horizontal nystagmus. The vitals and results of laboratory investigations are given below. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

Vitals and laboratory investigations:

  • BP: 138/90 mmHg
  • Pulse: 85 beats/min
  • Temp: 98.7 F
  • Hb: 11.3 g/dL
  • MCV: 110 fL
  • Fingerstick glucose (GRBS): 64 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient presents with confusion, agitation, and horizontal nystagmus. This clinical history along with the recent history of heavy alcohol intake is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine (vitamin B1) 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Chronic alcoholics have thiamine (B1) deficiency, which gets exacerbated with recent excessive intake.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :
    • Global confusion
    • Truncal ataxia
    • Ophthalmoplegia
    • Horizontal nystagmus 
  • Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:
    • Memory loss
    • Confabulation
  • Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

Hence, the initial treatment in a patient with high alcohol intake with new-onset ataxia should be emergent IV thiamine infusion to prevent the progression of Wernicke encephalopathy.

Other Options:

Option B- IV glucose: It should be given after IV thiamine in an alcoholic patient to treat hypoglycemia. Because if given before, it will worsen thiamine deficiency and will deteriorate this patient's condition.

Option C- IV naltrexone: It is given to abstain from alcohol use, not for treatment of Wernicke encephalopathy

Option D- IV vitamin B12: Although this patient has macrocytosis and difficulty walking, nystagmus is not a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency. Hence, it is not given. Macrocytosis in this patient is due to chronic alcohol use.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the Pediatrician with symptoms of common cold caused by rhinovirus. Which of the following receptors does this virus use to enter the cell?
questions.solution:
The receptor used by the rhinovirus to enter the cell is intercellular adhesion molecule 1 (ICAM-1).

Rhinoviruses are responsible for more than 50% of viral colds and have approximately 100 serotypes. Transmission is by contact with respiratory secretions.

Symptoms include profuse, watery nasal discharge frequently accompanied by symptoms of headache, malaise, sneezing, nasal congestion, sore throat, and cough. Illness generally lasts 10 days to 2 weeks. The infection is typically self-limiting.

Other options

Option B: CD21 is a complement receptor used by the Epstein-Barr virus.

Option C: Integrins are receptors interacting with the extracellular matrix that are used by the adenoviruses.

Option D: CD4, which is a part of the immunoglobulin superfamily, is utilized by HIV and human herpes 7 viruses to enter the cell.
