questions.text: Following an earthquake that shook the city of Delhi, multiple casualties are expected to arrive at the hospital requiring medical aid. You get a call from the field doctors asking you to clear out as many beds at the hospital for incoming casualties. What is this process called?
questions.solution:
Reverse triage is followed in this situation to discharge existing patients and to increase the surge capacity of the hospital to accommodate for the natural disaster. 

In reverse triage, non-emergent patients currently admitted to the hospital are discharged to allow for the acute increase in incoming patients. It allows for better utilization of resources. This is used in wars and military settings, where soldiers may need to return to the field of battle soon after treatment. It is also done when medical resources are scarce after a disaster.

Triage (Option B) consists of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of the severity of the injury and the likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention. It is carried out at the site of the disaster. Tagging is the identification of patients in a disaster with tags stating their name, age, place of origin, triage category, diagnosis, and initial treatment. Minor or moderate injuries can be treated at home to avoid social dislocation and reduce the resource drain that can occur by transporting them to central facilities. The seriously injured should be transported to specialized treatment facilities and hospitals.

During triage, there should be the highest optimization of resource allocation, and it should neither underestimate the injuries of a critical patient (undertriage) (Option A) nor should it divert unnecessary resources by overstating the patient’s condition (overtriage). Overtriage can actually worsen patient outcomes.

Telephone triage (Option D) is done by a nurse interacting with a caller (patient or caregiver) to identify the nature and urgency of the health care needs and determine an appropriate plan of care and disposition of the call. 

Color coding of triage is explained in the pearl given below.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman came with fever, headache, and vomiting for 3 days. On examination, her temperature is 101 F, pulse rate is 108 bpm, and BP is 80/60 mm of Hg. A maculopapular rash is seen over the trunk and extremities. She has neck stiffness and flexion of the neck causes flexion of the hips and knees. Which of the following media is used as transport media for the causative organism?

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination:

  • Reduced glucose
  • Increased protein
  • Increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with fever, maculopapular rash, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Brudzinski's sign) with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes levels is a typical presentation of bacterial meningitis. Among the given options Stuart's medium is recommended for the preservation and transportation of Neisseria species and other fastidious organisms from the clinic to the laboratory.

A nasopharyngeal swab from the patient is held in a Stuart transport medium till it is plated.

Composition of Stuart Medium:

  • Sodium glycerophosphate
  • Sodium thioglycollate
  • Calcium chloride
  • Methylene blue
  • Agar

Characteristics of Stuart medium:

  • This medium is a chemically defined, semisolid, non-nutrient medium that prevents microbial proliferation.
  • Because of this composition, the medium ensures that microorganisms present are able to survive for a sufficiently long period of time.
  • Sodium thioglycollate produces a reduced environment so as to improve the recovery of anaerobes.
  • Methylene blue acts as an oxidation-reduction indicator.
  • Calcium chloride maintains the permeability of bacterial cells and sodium glycerophosphate maintains the pH of the medium.
  • The medium appears colorless in the reduced state and blue in the oxidized state.

Meningococcal meningitis commonly presents with non-specific symptoms like fever, vomiting, headache, and irritability. Other features of bacterial meningitis include neck stiffness, photophobia, decreased consciousness, seizures, and focal neurologic signs. A non-blanching rash (petechial or purpuric) develops in >80% of cases.

Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. 

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

  Guidelines for prophylaxis:

  • All patients admitted to the hospital with meningitis should be placed on standard precautions.
  • Droplet precautions are recommended for patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis until they have received 24 hours of effective therapy. 
  • Chemoprophylaxis is indicated for the household and close contacts. The preferred antibiotics are rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone.
  • Monovalent, polyvalent, and conjugate vaccines are availbale.

Other options:

Options A, B, D- Cary Blair medium, Venkatraman Ramakrishnan medium, and autoclaved seawater are used as the transport mediums for Vibrio cholerae

questions.text: The following image shows the superior surface of the first cervical vertebra. The part of the bone marked as 1 gives attachment to:
questions.solution:
The part of the first cervical vertebra (C1) or Atlas that is marked as the number 1 is the posterior tubercle, and it gives attachment to ligamentum nuchae.

Atlas or C1 articulates with the occipital condyles of the skull above and with the axis (C2) below to form the atlantooccipital joint. The atlantooccipital joint allows for the nodding movement of the head on the vertebral column. There is no intervertebral disc between C1 and C2.

Features of the atlas:

  • No vertebral body
  • 2 lateral masses - with upper and lower articular facets
  • 2 arches- anterior and posterior arches 
  • 2 large transverse processes

Important attachments:

The anterior arch carries a roughened anterior tubercle on the anterior surface which attaches to the anterior longitudinal ligament. The posterior surface of the anterior arch articulates with the dens. The transverse ligament retains the dens against the anterior arch. The upper and lower borders provide attachment for the anterior atlantooccipital membrane and the diverging lateral parts of the anterior longitudinal ligament.

The superior border of the posterior arch attaches to the posterior atlantooccipital membrane. The inferior border is attached to ligamentum flavum. The posterior tubercle provides attachment for ligamentum nuchae.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man sustained a fracture of the left leg in a road traffic accident, for which he was managed conservatively with a cast for 6 weeks. After the cast was removed, a significant reduction in the girth of his left calf compared to the right was noticed. The pathogenesis of this reduction involves the degradation of proteins by a particular pathway. Identify the true statement about it.

choices.text: It is an ATP independent process
Regulatory proteins with short half lives are degraded

questions.solution:
The protein degradation pathway responsible is the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway, which involves the degradation of regulatory proteins having short half-lives in the cytosol. The clinical stem describes a case of disuse atrophy. Disuse activates ubiquitin ligases, which attach ubiquitin to cellular proteins, targetting these proteins for degradation in proteasomes. 

The degradation of ubiquitin-tagged proteins is an ATP dependant process that takes place in proteasomes in the cytosol.

A single ubiquitin molecule attaches to a misfolded or transmembrane protein and marks it for degradation. Soluble proteins get attached to four or more ubiquitin molecules. This is process is called polyubiquitination and is catalyzed by ligases. 

A proteasome is a macromolecule that consists of a cylindrical complex of proteins, with stacked rings forming a central pore. It contains proteolytic enzymes. The entry of proteins into the core is regulated by the two outer rings that recognize polyubiquitinated proteins. Proteasomes digest proteins into small (6 to 12 amino acids) fragments that can subsequently be degraded to their constituent amino acids and then recycled.

 

The accelerated proteolysis that is seen in catabolic conditions such as cancer cachexia also takes place by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway.

Protein degradation can be proteasomal or lysosomal. Cathepsins are enzymes that break down particles within phagolysosomes. The comparison between the lysosomal and proteasomal degradation of proteins is summarized in the table below. 

Proteasomal Degradation of Protein Lysosomal Degradation of Protein
ATP dependent ATP independent
Misfolded proteins Extracellular/Membrane proteins
Short-lived proteins Proteins with long half life

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with complaints of difficulty in initiating and maintaining the stream of urination. Ultrasonography reveals an increase in prostate size. You start him on tamsulosin. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and tamsulosin acts by selective α1 receptor antagonism.

Tamsulosin is a uroselective α1 blocker that acts by decreasing the tone of prostatic/ bladder neck muscles. This reduces the dynamic obstruction and increases the urinary flow rate. It is used in the treatment of BPH and acute urinary retention. It is taken once a day and preferred in cases with postural hypotension as it has very little effect on BP. Retrograde ejaculation and floppy iris during cataract surgery are the side effects of this drug.

  Other α1 antagonists used in BPH include

  • Terazosin - Apoptosis promoting effect on prostate
  • Doxazosin - Apoptosis promoting effect on prostate
  • Alfuzosin - Specifically created for BHP, not used as an antihypertensive

Other uses of α1 receptor antagonists include the management of hypertension and short-term management of congestive heart failure.

Other options:

Option B:  Selective α1 receptor agonists such as phenylephrine are used as nasal decongestants and also as a mydriatic agent. Midodrine has been used to treat patients with autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension. 

Option C: Nonselective α receptor antagonism can be seen in drugs such as phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine. They are administered prior to the surgical removal of pheochromocytoma to control the episodes of severe hypertension. They have also been used to manage the cheese reaction occurring in patients who take MAO inhibitors.

Option D: Selective α2 receptor agonists such as clonidine have been used in treating hypertension. 

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: A patient presented with severe chest pain. He has a history of fever, fatigue, shortness of breath, and palpitations. ECG showed no changes. On auscultation, no abnormality was detected. An endomyocardial biopsy was performed, and Dallas criteria were used to establish the diagnosis. Which of the following biopsy slides corresponds to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical picture appears to mimic MI, but the patient has a history of fever and no abnormal findings on auscultation and ECG. Also, Dallas criteria were used to establish the diagnosis. The clinical scenario is therefore suggestive of myocarditis, and Image A shows the histologic findings of myocarditis.

Myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with focal myocyte necrosis.

Viruses are the most common causes among infectious causes of myocarditis. Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis and it shows diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration as shown above. 

The Dallas criteria are used for the diagnosis of myocarditis on the basis of the findings of endomyocardial biopsy. 

They are treated with supportive management. 

Other Options:

Option A: Picture B shows irreversibly injured myocytes with contraction bands—intensely eosinophilic intracellular “stripes” composed of closely packed sarcomeres; these bands are suggestive of reperfusion injury after MI. The image is given below.

Option B: Picture D shows massive myocyte hypertrophy and myofiber disarray (haphazard disarray of bundles of myocytes and contractile elements in sarcomeres within cells), which are characteristic of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The image is given below.

Option C: Picture C shows hyaline eosinophilic deposits in the heart suggestive of amyloidosis, which can be confirmed by Congo red staining. The image is given below.

questions.text: Which of the following findings will be found in neuroimaging of a patient with Pick's disease?

choices.text: Atrophy of frontal and temporal lobes

questions.solution:
Atrophy of frontal and temporal lobes will be found in neuroimaging of a patient with Pick's disease

History of personality changes, compulsivity followed by issues of memory, later on, are seen in patients with frontotemporal dementias(FTD), including Pick’s disease. In the behavioral variant (bvFTD), the most common FTD syndrome, social and emotional systems dysfunction manifests as apathy, disinhibition, compulsivity, loss of empathy, and overeating, often but not always accompanied by deficits in executive control. When bvFTD is accompanied by motor neuron disease (MND), the term FTD-MND is applied.

Other Options:

Option A: Dilated ventricles are seen in Normal-pressure hydrocephalus. The patient presents with Ataxia, urinary incontinence, and dementia.

Option C: Atrophy of the medial temporal lobe is seen in Alzheimer's disease. Alzheimer’s patients present with short-term memory loss and develop personality changes later on.

Option D: Cortical microinfarcts are seen in Vascular dementia, which presents as step ladder decline of cognitive and behavioral function depending on the region involved.

questions.text: A five year old child present with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice for 3 months and stridor for 2 weeks. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this case scenario is Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis (RRP), also known as juvenile papillomatosis. This condition is caused by a viral infection, specifically linked to human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11.

RRP primarily affects the anterior part of the glottis, with the anterior commissure and vocal folds being the most common sites of involvement. It is more frequently observed in children under the age of 5.

The exact mode of transmission for RRP is not fully understood, but there is a recognized association between maternal genital warts and the development of recurrent laryngeal papillomatosis in offspring. The primary treatment for RRP is surgical removal, typically performed using endoscopic techniques. The CO2 laser is the most commonly used tool for this procedure. However, recurrence is common in RRP, often requiring multiple surgical interventions over time. Effective management is crucial due to the potential impact on the airway and vocal function.

Other options:

Option A: Vocal nodule develops after voice abuse which is unlikely here.

Option B: Croup presents acutely with fever.

Option C: Hoarseness of voice can be seen in hypothyroidism but not stridor.

questions.text:
A male patient presented with a bone fracture following a road traffic accident. After 2 days he developed dyspnea, petechiae involving the whole body, and a fall in oxygen saturation and appeared confused and restless. Which of the following is not a part of the management of his current condition?

ESR- Erythrocyte sedimentation rate.
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of fat embolism and intercostal drainage is not a part of the management of this condition.

Fat embolism is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of the long bone or other major trauma. Its pathogenesis can be related to 2 factors: the release of free fatty acids by the action of lipases on the neutral fats and actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

Clinical features:

  • Early signs are fever and tachycardia
  • Presenting features are of 2 types
    • Cerebral type: drowsiness, restlessness, disorientation
    • Pulmonary type: tachypnoea, tachycardia
  • Other features: petechial rash in front of neck/anterior axillary fold/ chest/ conjunctiva

The classical clinical triad consists of respiratory distress, neurological abnormalities, and petechial haemorrhages

Treatment of fat embolism is mainly supportive:

  • Respiratory support (oxygen)
  • Heparinization (increases lipoprotein lipase activity)
  • Intravenous low molecular weight dextran
  • Corticosteroids: To avoid pneumonitis
  • Prompt stabilization of long-bone fractures 

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: During your rural posting in a remote village, you were asked to help the community in the construction of a sanitary well. What are the recommended measurements of the marked structures in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a sanitary well. 

Marking 1 is the stone wall well which should be at least 6m deep. 
Marking 2 refers to the distance of the well from a human dwelling- 100m. 
Marking 3 is the distance from a possible source of contamination- 15m. 
Marking 4 is the parapet wall, which has to be at least 70-75cm. 

A sanitary well is one that is properly located, well-constructed, and protected against contamination in order to yield a supply of safe water. 

The well should be at least 15m away from a likely source of contamination and located at an elevated area with respect to the possible contaminant zone. The distance between the well and the houses of the users should be less than 100m.

The lining of the well should be built of bricks or stones set in cement up to a depth of at least 6m so that water enters from the bottom and not from the sides of the well. The lining should be carried 60-90cm above the ground level. 

The parapet wall should be up to a height of at least 70-75cms above the ground.

A cement-concrete platform, with a gentle outward slope and a drain, should extend at least 1m in all directions around the well. The pucca drain carries off spilled water to a public drain or a soakage pit.

The top of the well should be closed by a cement-concrete cover to prevent contamination from an open-top. It also improves the bacteriological quality of the water. 

Lifting the water from the well sanitarily requires a hand pump.

Consumer precautions are required at the individual and family level to prevent water-borne diseases. Hand hygiene should be followed. There should be a strict prohibition of washing of clothes, personal ablutions, animal exposure, and dumping of waste. 

Related Pearl: Wells

  • Wells are a source of ground water and are widely used across India.
  • The two main types of wells are the shallow and deep wells, the difference between which are:
  Shallow Wells Deep Wells
Description They tap subsoil water, i.e., water from above the first impervious layer in the ground They tap water from the water-bearing stratum which is below the first impervious layer of the ground
Chemical quality Moderately hard water Very hard water
Contamination Very often grossly contaminated and liable to pollution Low contamination levels and purer than water from shallow wells
Yield Generally dry in summer Provides constant water supply
Prevalence in India Very common Less common than shallow wells
  • An artesian well is a type of deep well in which the water rises to the surface due to the pressure with which it is held between two impervious/impermeable layers. There is no pump or other manual methods needed to bring the water to the surface. These are not common in India.
  • Wells can also be classified according to the method of construction as dug wells and tube wells.

i) Dug wells:

  • They are the most common type of wells in India.
  • In rural India, two types of dug wells exist, namely the unlined katcha wells and the masonry or pucca wells.
  • The katcha wells are just big holes dug into the sand.
  • The pucca wells are well built with walls or linings made of brick or stones.
  • Step wells are types of pucca dug wells that have steps. These steps can be used by people to descend into the well and come in contact with water. This increases the risk of water contamination.

ii) Tube wells:

  • Shallow tube wells are also called driven wells and deep tube wells are called bore wells.
  • They are safer sources of water compared to other wells, relatively cheaper to build and maintain.
  • Tube wells use strainers at the bottom and hand pumps at the top attached by a pipe in between.

The following are the considerations for building a safe and sanitary well:

Location Must be at least 15 m away from sources of contamination. Must not be >100 m from households.
Lining Must be made of brick or stones set in cement to a depth of 6 m, so that water enters from bottom and not sides. Height of lining above ground level must be 60 – 90 cm.
Parapet Wall Must be at least 70 – 75 cm (28 inches) from the ground level.
Platform Should stretch at least 1 m around the well in all directions.
Drain It should be a pucca drain to carry spilled water to a public drain beyond the cone of filtration of the well.
Covering There should be a cement concrete covering over the well.
Hand-pump Should be able to withstand rough handling.
Consumer responsibility Consumers must practice basic precautions before handling the well.
Quality The water standards in terms of quality must be conformed to.

questions.text: A case of legitimacy turns up in the court. The mother and father of the child had a divorce on 29/04/2021. The child was born on 08/02/2022 by normal vaginal delivery and was a healthy term child at 37 weeks of gestation. During the proceedings, it was noted that the child was born 285 days after the official date of declaration of divorce.  You would declare the child to be ________________ based on section _______ of the Indian Evidence Act.
questions.solution:
Section 112 gives information regarding the legitimacy of a child. A legitimate child is defined as been conceived and born during the continuance of a valid legal marriage or within 280 days of the dissolution of marriage by the death of the husband or divorce. In the given case the child is born after 280 days of the dissolution of a valid marriage and thus the child is illegitimate, since they were born 286 days after dissolution of the marriage.

Circumstances under which the question of legitimacy may arise are inheritance, affiliation cases and suppositious (fictitious) children.

Section 108 of IEA deals lays down that if it is shown that a person was alive for 30 years, and there is nothing to suggest the probability of their death, then they are presumed alive unless they have not been heard from for 7 years by those who would have naturally heard from them when they were alive.

questions.text:
An 18-year old girl was diagnosed with acute intermittent porphyria. She was told that attacks of the illness can be prevented by avoiding known precipitating drugs like griseofulvin and barbiturates. What is the biochemical basis for the precipitation of such an exacerbation?
(ALA synthase- Aminolevulinic acid synthase)
questions.solution:
The biochemical basis of precipitation of porphyria by barbiturates is the derepression of ALA synthase.(ALAS- 1)

Mechanism: Barbiturates increase the synthesis of CYP450, which increases the consumption of heme. This decrease in heme concentration in the liver leads to the de-repression or induction of ALA synthase. This increases the synthesis of heme precursors, which exacerbates the attacks.

Acute intermittent porphyria is due to a defect in HMB synthase, usually inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. Under conditions where heme synthesis is increased in the liver, HMB- synthase activity may become limiting. This leads to the accumulation and excretion of ALA, PBG, and other heme pathway intermediates. Precipitating factors include:

  • Endogenous and exogenous steroids, including oral contraceptives
  • Porphyrinogenic drugs - like barbiturates, griseofulvin, etc
  • Alcohol
  • Low-calorie diets for weight loss
  • Fasting
  • Infections
  • Surgery

It is a type of hepatic porphyria characterized by neurovisceral symptoms, abdominal pain, and peripheral neuropathies. Diagnosis is based on elevated ALA and porphobilinogen in the urine and plasma.

Types of porphyria

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.

questions.text:
A patient who tested positive for COVID-19 was prescribed remdesivir as a part of his treatment regimen. Which of the following statements are true regarding this drug?
  1. It is an RNA polymerase inhibitor
  2. It should be given in doses of 300 mg intravenously
  3. Patient has to be checked for hypersensitivity reactions
  4. It can decrease the levels of transaminases
  5. It is used in moderate to severe symptoms of Covid19 infection
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3, and 5 are true regarding remdesivir.

Remdesivir is a nucleoside analog. Inside the cells, it is converted to nucleoside monophosphate, which is subsequently converted to nucleoside triphosphate. This metabolite inhibits viral replication by inhibiting the enzyme RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

According to the latest ICMR and AIIMS guidelines, it can be used in patients with moderate to severe COVID-19 infection requiring supplemental oxygen within 10 days of the onset of symptoms with no renal or hepatic dysfunction. 

Recommended dose: 200 mg IV on day 1 followed by 100 mg IV once a day for the next 4 days.

Adverse effects:

Following adverse effects have been reported with remdesivir:

  • Hypersensitivity reactions- changes in heart rate, fever, shortness of breath, wheezing, swelling of the lips, face, or throat, rash, sweating, or shivering. Slower infusion rates can prevent this complication.
  • Increased risk of elevation of transaminases.
  • The antiviral activity of remdesivir can reduce if it is co-administered with chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl is brought for evaluation of intellectual disability. She also has difficulty in walking and balancing, and her speech is delayed for her age. The parents also say that she frequently has sudden bouts of laughter. She is a known case of seizure disorder since the age of 3. This condition is associated with which of the following chromosomal abnormalities?
  1. Deletion of paternal gene on chromosome 15
  2. Deletion of maternal gene on chromosome 15
  3. Uniparental disomy of paternal chromosome 15
  4. Uniparental disomy of maternal chromosome 15
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Angelman syndrome. It can occur due to one of the following genetic abnormalities:  

  • Deletion (most common) - band q12 on the long arm of maternal chromosome 15
  • Paternal uniparental disomy - inheritance of both chromosomes of a pair from the paternal pair of chromosomes 
  • Defective imprinting - defect in the resetting/maintaining of imprints during gametogenesis or after fertilization
  Prader-Willi syndrome  AngelMan syndrome

Deletion 

(most common)

Paternal chromosome 15

Maternal chromosome 15

Uniparental disomy 

(less common)

 Maternal disomy (duplication)  Paternal disomy (duplication) 
Clinical features

Elevated ghrelin levels - hyperphagia

Truncal obesity

Severe hypotonia

Short stature

Small hands and feet with hypotonia

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

Cognitive impairment

Short stature

Severe mental retardation with lack of speech

Stiff arm movements

Spastic, uncoordinated walk (ataxia)

Seizures

Inappropriate outbursts of laughter (happy puppets)

Chromosome 15 diseases (mnemonic - MAP):

  • M: Marfan syndrome
  • A: Angelman syndrome
  • P: Prader Willi syndrome

The following images show children suffering from Prader-Willi syndrome.

The following image shows a child suffering from Angelman syndrome.

questions.text:
The basis of which of the following processes is depicted in the image below?

DNA- Deoxyribonucleic acid

RNA- Ribonucleic acid

mRNA- messenger RNA
questions.solution:
The process in the given image is RNA editing. 

RNA editing is the process by which the coding sequence of the mRNA is changed before translation by post-transcriptional modification.  

As a result, the mRNA template differs from the DNA from which it was transcribed. This leads to the formation of a different protein. This occurs by the insertion of additional uracils at the 3’ end of the mRNA and proceeds in the 3’ to 5’ direction.

The process of apolipoprotein B48 synthesis involves RNA editing.

RNA editing in apoB synthesis:
  • In the liver, the apoB gene is transcribed to mRNA, which is then translated to apoB-100.
  • In the intestine, the same apoB gene is transcribed to the same mRNA. But now, the mRNA undergoes editing by an enzyme cytidine deaminase, which converts the CAA codon in the mRNA to UAA at a single specific site. This edited mRNA translates to apoB-48.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is the result of RNA editing in the intestine. Here, a sense codon is changed to a nonsense codon by posttranscriptional deamination of cytosine to uracil.

DNA rearrangement, transposition, and alternate splicing also alter the gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text: All of the following factors influence the accuracy of the thermodilution method of measuring cardiac output except?
questions.solution:
Aortic regurgitation does not influence the accuracy of thermodilution cardiac output measurement. All others influence the cardiac output measurement by thermodilution.

Other factors influencing the accuracy of thermodilution technique are:

  • Intracardiac shunts
  • Inadequate delivery of thermal indicator
  • Thermistor malfunction from fibrin or clot
  • Respiratory cycle influences

Cardiac output measurements technique:

  • Thermodilution
  • Dye dilution, using indocyanine green
  • Lithium dilution
  • Pulse contour devices
  • Esophageal doppler
  • Thoracic bioimpedance
  • Echocardiography

Note: Thermal dilution method uses a non-toxic liquid of temperature different from the blood. This fluid is injected into a vein and is detected on the arterial side using a catheter with a temperature sensor. The rate of flow of this liquid is used to calculate the cardiac output.

questions.text: You are assisting your first case of open abdominal surgery. The senior professor asked you to make the incision first. The nurse hands over a fresh set of sterilized instruments with various Bard-Parker blades. Which blade would you choose generally for making an abdominal incision?
questions.solution:
The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions. Essentially a larger version of the number 10, it has a flat, unsharpened back edge and a short, curved cutting edge. These blades are best for creating large incisions, often through thick skin.

Other options-

Option (A): 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy. This is also known as a stab knife. 

Option (C): 15-blade for minor surgical procedures 

Uses of 15-scalpel blade:

  • To make precise skin incisions in dermatosurgery
  • Minor surgical procedures
  • Select ocular procedures (15C blade)
  • Select plastic surgery procedures (15C blade)

Option (D): 12-blade is a small, pointed, crescent-shaped blade used typically as a suture cutter. It is most sharp on the inside edge of its curve.

questions.text: As a part of your clinical rotation, you are posted in the department of transfusion medicine and blood bank for fifteen days. At the phlebotomy room, you notice the senior resident flushing the freshly collected blood bags through this machine, storing the output in separate blood bags, and refrigerating them. Which of the following is an advantage of this method?

choices.text: Prevention of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR)
Prevention of febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR)
Prevention of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)
Prevention of bacterial contamination of platelets

questions.solution:
The image shows a leukoreduction filter, which is used for filtering out donor WBCs. Leukoreduction filters help in reducing the incidence of febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). They also remove microaggregates. 

These synthetic-fiber filters remove WBCs by a combination of mesh density, chemical attraction, and active adhesion. Leucocyte reduction of RBC components is most often performed by blood collection centers within the first few days after collection using an integral or sterilely connected filtration system. Filtration prior to storage reduces WBC breakdown products in the blood component. The optimum time for performing leukoreduction is before storage, although a less effective option is to perform leukoreduction after storage, just before transfusion. 

The rate of alloimmunization in patients receiving products that are leukoreduced, by either filtration or irradiation, is significantly lower than that in patients receiving non-leukoreduced products.

Potential benefits of leukoreduction include reduced risk of 

  • Sensitization to HLA antigens (important for transplant patients and preventing platelet refractoriness)
  • Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR)
  • CMV transmission

Leukoreduction may also reduce the risk of

  • Transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease (TA-GVHD) 
  • Transfusion-related immunomodulation (TRIM)
  • Transmitting variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

Bacterial contamination of platelets, transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), and acute hemolytic reactions (due to ABO incompatibility) cause more morbidity and mortality that would not be significantly helped by leukoreduction. 

Methods of leucodepletion:

  • Washing
  • Freezing
  • Buffy coat removal
  • Micro-aggregate filtration
  • Specific leucodepletion filters (most efficient)
  • Low leucocyte apheresis devices

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: Plaster was applied to the leg of a patient with a tibial shaft fracture. This patient now presents with severe pain in the leg. On examination, the distal pulses are absent and feels pain on passive stretching of the limb. On opening the plaster, the leg appears edematous and numerous blisters are seen. What would be the most appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Opening of the plaster is sufficient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests acute compartment syndrome, and it is treated immediately with fasciotomy.

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 Ps:

  • Pain: Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. Ischemic muscle is highly sensitive to touch. On the passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 
  • Paresthesia: Paresthesia and hypoesthesia may be noted due to compression of nerves traversing the affected compartment. They are the first signs of nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor: Pallor of the skin may not always be seen. The skin outside the compartment may be normally perfused, as only the intra-compartmental perfusion may be affected.
  • Paralysis: Paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness: Usually, the peripheral pulses and capillary return are intact in the early stages, unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as the differential pressure (ΔP). A differential pressure (ΔP) of less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals) is an indication for immediate compartment decompression.

The threatened compartment must be promptly decompressed, merely splitting the plaster is not helpful and the limb must be kept flat. This is because elevating the limb causes a further decrease in end capillary pressure and aggravates muscle ischemia. In the case of compartment syndrome in the leg, fasciotomy should be performed. This involves opening all four compartments via medial and lateral incisions. Wounds to be left open and inspected 2 days later, if tissues are healthy, the wounds can be sutured. If there is muscle necrosis, debridement to be carried out.

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 5-month-old child is brought to the physician by her father because the child appears pale and sickly. She is in the 10th percentile for length and 7th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows a pale infant with facial features of micrognathia, high arched palate, and hypertelorism. Radial pulse is absent and there is the presence of triphalangeal thumb bilaterally. On USG, only one kidney is seen. What other finding is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Short stature, craniofacial abnormalities, and triphalangeal thumb are common features of Diamond-Blackfan Anemia.

Diamond–Blackfan syndrome (congenital hypoplastic anemia) is a rare congenital bone marrow failure syndrome that usually becomes symptomatic in early infancy. Features include:

  • Normochromic and macrocytic anemia without hypersegmented neutrophils, reticulocytopenia
  • Absent RBC precursors in an otherwise normally cellular bone marrow
  • Range of Congenital Anomalies, most common is craniofacial
    • Hypertelorism, snub nose, and high-arched palate
    • Thumb abnormalities: flattening of the thenar eminence and triphalangeal thumb. Radial pulse may be absent.
  • Short stature
  • Urogenital anomalies: Absent kidney, horseshoe kidney
  • Ophthalmic anomalies: Congenital glaucoma, strabismus

Other Options:

Cafe-au-lait spots: These are seen in Fanconi anemia, a hereditary form of aplastic anemia. Patients with Fanconi Anemia have a hypoplastic or absent thumb. 

Target cells: These are seen in patients with thalassemia. Thalassemia is not associated with congenital craniofacial abnormalities.

Pancreatic Insufficiency: It is associated with Shwachman–Diamond syndrome, a type of autosomal recessive congenital aplastic anemia. It has features of pancreatic insufficiency like steatorrhea along with dysmorphic features and thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: An elderly patient was diagnosed with ischemic heart disease and was started on beta-blockers. However, the patient continued to have symptoms despite it's use. He was then started on ivabradine. This drug improves the symptoms of angina by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ivabradine decreases the automaticity in the sinoatrial node and thus reduces the heart rate. This reduction in the heart rate decreases the myocardial oxygen demand.

The oxygen requirement of the heart mainly depends on the work done by the heart. This work mainly depends on cardiac output and peripheral resistance. An increase in these parameters will increase the oxygen requirement of the heart.

Important determinants of cardiac output are:

Stroke volume- It is the amount of blood pumped out of the heart during each heartbeat. This stroke volume increases whenever, there is increased venous return to the heart, increased end-diastolic volume (preload), and increased contractility. Contractility further depends on the initial length of the cardiac muscle fiber and the autonomic innervation.

Heart rate- Increased heart rate increases the cardiac output which in turn increases the oxygen requirement. Heart rate is controlled primarily by the autonomic nerves, with sympathetic stimulation increasing the rate and parasympathetic stimulation decreasing the rate.

Afterload- The tension at which the load is lifted is called afterload. As the afterload increases, the heart has to work more in order to pump blood to the organs. This in turn results in increased oxygen requirement. It is dependent on the peripheral resistance. 

Drugs used in the management of angina either decrease the work done by the heart or increases the blood flow to the heart.

  • Nitrates- They increase the cGMP and cause venodilation. It mainly results in an increase in venous capacitance and a decrease in the ventricular preload. They might also increase coronary flow in some areas and in variant anginas.
  • Calcium channel blockers- Blocking the calcium channels leads to the relaxation of vascular smooth muscles and decreased impulses in the conduction system. This leads to decreased peripheral resistance, decreased blood pressure, decreased contractility, decreased heart rate, and decreased oxygen requirement of the heart.
  • Beta-blockers- They decrease the oxygen requirement by decreasing the heart rate, blood pressure, and contractility. Some drugs like carvedilol and nebivolol also cause vasodilation.

Newer antianginal drugs

  • Ranolazine- It inhibits the late sodium current and reduces the intracellular calcium concentration. It reduces diastolic tension, cardiac contractility, and work.
  • Trimetazidine- inhibits the fatty acid oxidation in the myocardium. It decreases the oxygen requirement of the heart.
  • Ivabradine- decreases the heart rate and decreases oxygen requirement.
  • Fasudil- It is a Rho kinase inhibitor. It is useful in coronary vasospasm.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A 34-year female patient presents to the clinic with the chief complaint of amenorrhea and eye pain. She is irritable and says, "I can't tolerate summer. I sweat a lot. Although, one thing I am happy about is I am losing weight without even trying". Physical examination reveals warm and moist skin with tremors of the hand. Eyes appear dry, red, and bulging with a starring appearance. Diagnosis is confirmed via biopsy findings shown in the picture. What is the drug of choice to treat this patient's eye findings?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of irritability, heat intolerance, sweating, exophthalmos, amenorrhea suggests the diagnosis of Graves disease. Glucocorticoid therapy is recommended to treat Grave's ophthalmopathy.  

The hyperthyroidism of Graves’ disease is caused by thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) that are synthesized in the thyroid gland as well as in bone marrow and lymph nodes. TSI antibodies cause stimulation of the thyroid gland causing features of hyperthyroidism in the presence of low TSH levels. Histopathology shows follicular hyperplasia with scalloped margins on biopsy.

Clinical features of Graves disease are hyperactivity, irritability, dysphoria, heat intolerance and sweating palpitations, fatigue, and weakness, weight loss with increased appetite, diarrhea, polyuria, oligomenorrhea, loss of libido, tachycardia; atrial fibrillation in the elderly, tremor, Goiter, Warm, moist skin, muscle weakness, proximal myopathy Lid retraction or lag. 

Graves Ophthalmopathy: It is due to increased volume of the retroorbital connective tissues and extraocular muscles because of marked lymphocytic infiltration of the retro-orbital space, accumulation of hydrophilic glycosaminoglycans such as hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate, and increased numbers of adipocytes (fatty infiltration). Corneal exposure, lid retraction, lid lag on downgaze, conjunctival injection, restriction of gaze, diplopia, and visual loss from optic nerve compression are cardinal symptoms.

This patient's eye pain (probably optic neuritis) with chemosis and proptosis is suggestive of severe Graves’ ophthalmopathy. Severe disease can be treated with IV methylprednisolone pulse therapy, i.e 500 mg of methylprednisolone once weekly for 6 weeks, then 250 mg once weekly for 6 weeks. Worsening of symptoms upon glucocorticoid withdrawal is common.

Topical lubricants, taping the eyelids closed at night, moisture chambers, and eyelid surgery are helpful to limit exposure of ocular tissues. Radiation therapy is not effective. Orbital decompression should be performed for severe, symptomatic exophthalmos or if the visual function is reduced by optic nerve compression. In patients with diplopia, prisms or eye muscle surgery can be used to restore ocular alignment in the primary gaze.

Other Options:

Option A: Propanolol is used in thyroid storm and initial stages of hyperthyroidism to control symptoms, not in the treatment of Graves ophthalmopathy

Option B: Propylthiouracil is the mainstay of treatment for Graves disease but it does not affect Graves ophthalmopathy.

Option C: Radioactive Iodine is also used as a treatment modality for hyperthyroidism in suitable patients but does not affect Graves ophthalmopathy.

questions.text: Given below is an instrument used for irrigation. In which of the following procedures will it not be used?
questions.solution:
The instrument is Rose’s sinus douching cannula. It is used in irrigation of the maxillary sinus, which should already have a nasoantral window due to intranasal antrostomy or Caldwell Luc operation. The direction of the tip is indicated by the hook outside.

Note:

Trephination (also known as trepanning or burr holing) is a surgical intervention where a hole is drilled, incised or scraped into the skull using simple surgical tools. Trephination of frontal sinus is done for acute frontal sinusitis if there is persistence or exacerbation of pain or pyrexia in spite of medical treatment for 48 h or if the lid swelling is increasing and threatening orbital cellulitis.

questions.text:
All of the following are true about the nasolacrimal duct, except:
  1. It is derived from the surface ectoderm 
  2. Its mucosa is lined by stratified squamous epithelium
  3. The duct opens into the middle meatus
  4. Its opening is guarded by Hasner’s valve
  5. It is approximately 18 mm long
questions.solution:
All of the above statements are correct, except for 2 and 3 only, which are incorrect statements.

The Nasolacrimal duct:

The epithelial lining of the lacrimal canaliculi and nasolacrimal duct is derived from surface ectoderm. The mucosa of the lacrimal sac and the nasolacrimal duct has a bilaminar columnar epithelium, which is ciliated in places. 

It runs downwards, backward, and laterally from the lacrimal sac. It is approximately 18 mm long and descends from the lacrimal sac to open anteriorly in the inferior meatus of the nose at an expanded orifice. It is bounded by a mucosal valve called the valve of Hasner in the inferior meatus.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the Intensified Mission Indradhanush Scheme?

choices.text: A total of 12 vaccines are included in this scheme.
Children and pregnant women benefit from this.
4 rounds of immunization are held for 7 days in each month.
Yellow fever and typhoid vaccine were added newly.

questions.solution:
Typhoid vaccine and yellow fever vaccine are not a part of the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. 

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme has been introduced to ensure full immunization (more than 90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days in each month (from the 7th-13th of each month):

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

And included recently:

  • Rotavirus diarrhea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • Haemophilus influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese encephalitis

This is a potential question under recent updates in PSM. 

The purpose of Intensified Mission Indradhanush is to reach each and every child under 2 years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunization coverage. It was launched by the Government of India in October 2017.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with complaints of fever with chills, sore throat, myalgia, and fatigue for 8 days. He recently traveled from rural India where he was working in a health camp. His SpO2 is 90%. Physical examination shows pallor. CT scan of the lung shows a CO-RADS score of 5. Blood work-up shows mild anemia. RT-PCR is positive for COVID 19 and rapid diagnostic test (RDT) with peripheral smear is positive for P. falciparum. Which of the following is the drug/drug combination recommended for the treatment of malaria in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of COVID 19 with malaria (P. falciparum) co-infection. The recommended drugs for P. falciparum co-infection in COVID-19 are Artesunate, Sulphadoxine, Pyrimethamine and Primaquine.

Clinical features of malaria as a co-infection :

  • Fever 
  • Headache
  • Vomiting
  • Anemia
  • Fits/convulsions
  • Loss of consciousness


Diagnosis is based on Rapid Diagnostic Test (bivalent) or microscopic blood smear examination.

Management :

  • Plasmodium vivax (Pv) : Chloroquine (25 mg/kg body weight divided over three days) and Primaquine (0.25 mg/kg body weight divided over for 14 days). Primaquine prevents relapse but is contraindicated in pregnant women, infants, and individuals with G6PD deficiency.
  • Plasmodium falciparum (Pf) : ACT (Artesunate 3 days + Sulphadoxine + Pyrimethamine 1 day) - Artesunate (4 mg/kg body weight daily for 3 days) plus Sulfadoxine (25 mg/kg body weight) and Pyrimethamine (1.25 mg/kg body weight) on day 1. Followed by a single dose of Primaquine (0.75 mg/kg body weight) on day 2.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy was brought with progressive right hip pain for 1 month. He had many episodes of pain and swelling of his hands. His brother had a stroke at age 6. Physical examination shows tenderness over the right hip with no gross skin changes. His blood smear shows the findings in the picture. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hip pain?

Vitals and Labs:

BP: 116/76 mm of Hg

Pulse: 80 bpm

Temp: 99 F

TLC: 5,000 /mm3
questions.solution:
The findings of dactylitis and family history of stroke at a young age, along with sickle cells in the blood smear, are suggestive of sickle cell disease (SCD).

This patient's hip pain in the absence of fever and normal leukocyte count is due to infarction or avascular necrosis (AVN) of the hip joint due to vaso-occlusion by sickle cells. The AVN of the hip may cause limp and leg-length discrepancies. 

Manifestations of sickle cell disease include:

  • Acute splenic sequestration due to venous obstruction, necessitating emergency transfusion/splenectomy
  • Painful ischemic crises due to vaso-occlusion in connective and musculoskeletal tissue
  • Renal papillary necrosis
  • Cerebrovascular strokes
  • Chronic lower leg ulcers
  • Priapism in males

The cardinal clinical feature of sickle cell anemia is acute vaso-occlusive pain, due to ischemia of the tissues. Vasoocclusive crisis can cause dactylitis, splenic infarction (shrunken spleen over time), AVN, etc. Most commonly, the femoral head is affected in AVN. Other sites affected include the humeral head and mandible.

Dactylitis referred to as a hand-foot syndrome, is often the first manifestation of pain in infants and young children with sickle cell anemia. Dactylitis often manifests with symmetric or unilateral swelling of the hands and/or feet.  

Other Options:

Option B- Septic arthritis manifests as fever, unilateral joint pain, and restricted motion. Although SCD patients have a higher risk of septic arthritis but no evidence of fever, joint swelling, and normal leukocyte count, rules out this diagnosis.

Option C- Patients with osteomyelitis often have a longer duration of fever and pain, swelling of the affected area, fewer or only 1 location of pain and tenderness, higher white blood cell counts, and an elevated C-reactive protein. Blood cultures, when positive, are helpful. Both Salmonella spp. and S. aureus causes osteomyelitis in children with sickle cell anemia, which is often in the diaphysis of long bones.

Option D-  Pseudogout or gout occurs due to crystal deposition in the joint. It also presents with unilateral joint pain. But there is also the presence of skin erythema and joint swelling with usually an acute onset. This patient has had pain in the joint for 1 month.

questions.text: A young man is diagnosed with hypertension. His laboratory studies reveal hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. He says that his mother was also diagnosed with hypertension at a younger age. Genetic testing revealed the presence of a mutation in ENaC gene. Which of the following drugs is commonly used in the treatment of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical, laboratory, and genetic features are suggestive of Liddle's syndrome. It occurs due to the increased function of epithelial sodium channels. Amiloride blocks these channels and is therefore commonly used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome.

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks epithelial sodium channels in collecting tubules. Therefore, it reduces sodium retention and potassium wasting. Triamterene acts similar to amiloride. However, it is less potent and more toxic than amiloride.

It is used to treat Liddle's syndrome, hypokalemia due to other diuretics, and lithium-induced polyuria. Its toxicity can cause hyperkalemic metabolic acidosis.

Liddle's syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that is caused due to the gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene which codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. Due to increased sodium retention, patients present with hypertension and hypokalemic alkalosis. They have normal aldosterone levels. They respond to treatment with amiloride.

Other options:

Option A: Furosemide is a loop diuretic and acts by inhibiting Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Therefore it is not used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome. A condition that mimics overdose loop diuretic is Bartter's syndrome. This syndrome occurs due to a defect in the Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Patients will have low blood pressure, polyuria, polydipsia, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, and normal to increased calcium excretion. 

Option B: Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist. Since the levels of aldosterone are normal in Liddle's syndrome, it cannot be used in the treatment of the condition. The toxicity of spironolactone can cause hyperkalemia and gynecomastia.

Option D: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic and acts by the inhibition of the Na+/Cl- transporter in the distal convoluted tubule. Therefore it is not commonly used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome. A condition that mimics an overdose of thiazide diuretics is Gitelman syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disease that causes a defect in the Na+/Cl- transporter in the distal convoluted tubule. Patients present with low blood pressure, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalciuria.

Loop diuretics  Thick ascending loop of Henle  Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter

Epithelial sodium channel inhibitors  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts   ENaC 
Aldosterone antagonists  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts  Mineralocorticoid receptors (indirectly ENaC)

questions.text: What is the attached structure in the marked area on the upper-end of the Femur?
questions.solution:
The image shows the femur, and the structure marked is the intertrochanteric crest, to which the Quadratus femoris muscle is attached.

Quadratus femoris: It is a flat, quadrilateral muscle lying between gemellus inferior and the upper margin of adductor magnus, from which it is separated by the transverse branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery. It arises from the upper part of the external aspect of the ischial tuberosity and inserts onto a small tubercle a little above the middle of the trochanteric crest of the femur and into the bone for a short distance below. It may be absent.

Relations: The muscle passes behind the hip joint and the neck of the femur, separated from them by the tendon of the obturator externus and the ascending branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery (which may cause troublesome bleeding if injured during the posterior approach to the hip). The sciatic nerve crosses the muscle posteriorly. A bursa is often present between the muscle and the lesser trochanter.

Vascular supply: Branches from the inferior gluteal artery and from the medial circumflex femoral artery.

Innervation: It is innervated by the nerve to quadratus femoris, L5 and S1.

Actions: It produces lateral rotation of the thigh. Lateral rotation is produced by gluteus maximus, obturator internus, superior and inferior gemelli, quadratus femoris and piriformis, and it is assisted by obturator externus and sartorius. Adduction is produced by adductors longus, brevis and Magnus and by gracilis assisted by pectineus, quadratus femoris and the inferior fibres of gluteus maximus. 

Testing: The short rotators cannot be tested individually, but the lateral rotation of the extended hip and abduction of the flexed hip against resistance test them as a group.

questions.text: In a 60-year-old chronic smoker with lung carcinoma, the radiological investigations reveal a centrally located tumor with the histopathology showing a characteristic Azzopardi effect as shown in the image below. Which of the following marker you would expect to be positive in the immunohistochemistry of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological image showing a characteristic azzopardi effect is suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung. Chromogranin is a marker of small cell lung carcinoma.

Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

Histology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.

Markers seen in small cell lung carcinoma includes,

  • Chromogranin,
  • Synaptophysin,
  • CD56

Note: Insulinoma-associated protein 1 (INMS 1) is a nuclear protein that serves as a transcription factor and has gained prominence as a neuroendocrine marker. Originally identified in insulinomas, INSM1 has been to be a reliable marker for various neuroendocrine tumors (NETs).

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency room with complaints of dyspnea. On examination, there was elevated jugular venous pressure, pitting type of pedal edema, and crepitations in the lungs. After a detailed evaluation, he was diagnosed to be the case of heart failure and was started on digoxin. Which other medication if added to this patient can lead to digoxin toxicity?
questions.solution:
Furosemide, if given along with digoxin can cause hypokalemia and lead to digoxin-induced arrhythmias. Hence, they should not be given together. Combination with other drugs does not cause life-threatening side effects.

Digoxin is the cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation/flutter.

It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter to increase intracellular sodium. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by the sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

The most common cardiac manifestations of digitalis toxicity are ventricular tachycardia, partial to complete A-V block, severe bradycardia, and atrial fibrillation/flutter. Gastrointestinal side effects, headache, fatigue, and sleeplessness may also be present.

Factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity are:

  • Hypokalemia - It increases the binding of the digoxin to the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. 
  • Drugs causing hypokalemia- diuretics, amphotericin B, corticosteroids
  • Drugs that decrease digoxin elimination (inhibitors of P-glycoprotein) like quinidine
  • Renal/hepatic failure
  • Thyrotoxicosis

Digoxin should be discontinued whenever toxicity is suspected. An effective antidote for digoxin toxicity is digibind, which is an antidigoxin antibody.

Other options:

Option A: Ranitidine is an H2 receptor antagonist. It irreversibly binds to H2 receptors on the basolateral membrane of parietal cells. Other available H2 receptor antagonists are cimetidine, ranitidine, famotidine, and nizatidine. It does not potentiate digoxin toxicity.

Option B: Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor. The important side effect is hypotension. Combining this with digoxin will not potentiate digoxin toxicity.

Option C: Nesiritide is a human recombinant B-type natriuretic peptide. It inhibits sodium transport in the proximal and distal tubule and promotes natriuresis. The important side effect is hypotension. It does not potentiate digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is the hormonal contraceptive in Norplant II?
questions.solution:
The hormonal contraceptive present in Norplant II/Jadelle is Levonorgestrel.

Norplant II/Jadelle is a subdermal implant with two rods, each containing 70 mg of levonorgestrel. The hormone is released at a rate of 50 mcg per day. It provides contraception for 3-5 years.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)?

choices.text: Over 50% left main coronary artery stenosis
One vessel disease without proximal LAD artery involvement

questions.solution:
CABG or PCI is not recommended in one vessel disease without proximal LAD artery involvement.

CABG is also not considered appropriate in asymptomatic patients who are at a low risk of MI or death.

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman experiences an increased frequency of micturition, with pain relieved by micturition and aggravated by overdistension of the bladder. Urine routine tests showed no pus cells; urine culture tested negative, and cystoscopy revealed fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa, with a characteristic appearance of ulcers, as shown in the image below. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable clinical diagnosis in the reported case is interstitial cystitis. The image shows Hunner's ulcers, which are characteristic of interstitial cystitis. 

Interstitial cystitis (i.e. a chronic pelvic pain syndrome or bladder pain syndrome) is a persistent, painful form of chronic cystitis, which occurs most frequently in women.

Clinical features

  • Severe suprapubic pain
  • Urinary frequency
  • Urgency
  • Hematuria
  • Dysuria without evidence of bacterial infection

Ulcerations of the mucosa occur in the fundus of the bladder (Hunner's ulcer). It is characterized by marked submucosal edema of the bladder with mucosal ulceration, which is seen in the late phase of interstitial cystitis.

In the cystoscopic examination, fissures and punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) are seen in the bladder mucosa.

Microscopy shows mucosal ulcers covered by fibrin and necrotic material and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells.

Late in the course, transmural fibrosis may appear, leading to a contracted bladder.

The pathologic findings are nonspecific, and the main role of biopsy is to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may mimic interstitial cystitis clinically.

Treatment is difficult and unsatisfactory. Hydrostatic dilatation under anesthesia may give relief for some months. Intravesical instillation of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) results in an improvement in some patients. Other treatments that have been considered in interstitial cystitis include intravesical heparin, oral ranitidine, and steroid therapy.

Other options:

Malakoplakia (Option B) is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It has the following features:

  • Chronic inflammatory reaction, commonly affecting the urinary bladder, is seen due to acquired defects in phagocyte function.
  • It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and CNS.
  • Malakoplakia is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species.  
  • Grossly, malakoplakia takes the form of soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques, often misdiagnosed clinically as malignancy.
  • Microscopically, they are composed of large, foamy macrophages mixed with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes.
  • The macrophages have an abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with undigested bacterial products.
  • In addition, intracellular deposition of calcium and iron within enlarged lysosomes forms laminated basophilic concretions, known as Michaelis–Gutmann bodies, pathognomonic of malakoplakia.

 The following image shows the Michaelis–Gutmann bodies marked in black arrows.


Tubercular cystitis (Option-C):

Tuberculous urinary infection is secondary to renal tuberculosis. Early tuberculosis of the bladder starts around the ureteric orifice or trigone, the earliest evidence being pallor of the mucosa due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen and, in long-standing cases, marked fibrosis is seen, and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced. 

Thimble bladder is classically seen in tubercular cystitis. 


Polypoid cystitis (Option D): 

  • Polypoid cystitis is an inflammatory lesion resulting from the irritation of the bladder mucosa.
  • Although indwelling catheters are the most commonly cited culprits, any injurious agent may give rise to this lesion.
  • The urothelium is thrown into broad bulbous polypoid projections as a result of marked submucosal edema.
  • Polypoid cystitis may be confused with papillary urothelial carcinoma both clinically and histologically.

The given image below shows polypoid cystitis showing broad polypoid growth, prominent blood vessels, and metaplastic urothelium in H&E stain.

questions.text: The device shown in the image is used in the treatment of-
questions.solution:
The image shows a mirror box used in the treatment of Phantom Limb Disorder.

The mirror box was invented by Vilayanur S. Ramachandran to help alleviate phantom limb pain, in which patients feel they still have a limb after having it amputated.

The  patient inserts his limb into one hole and the "phantom" limb into the other. When viewed from an angle, the brain is tricked into seeing two complete limbs.

The wider use of mirrors in this way is known as mirror therapy or mirror visual feedback (MVF).

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of ingestion of one uncrushed seed similar to that shown in the image below. He is asymptomatic at presentation. Which of the following can be anticipated in this case?
questions.solution:
The image shows seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica. No poisonous action is anticipated.

If swallowed uncrushed, the seeds of nux vomica have no poisonous action, as they are not dissolved in the gastrointestinal tract and are passed entirely in the feces.

Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postganglionic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. 

The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed. When crushed seeds are ingested, the symptoms are delayed for an hour or more.

Convulsions are produced as the reflex centers of the spinal cord are directly affected. The convulsions are first clonic but eventually become tonic.  Risus sardonicus results from the contraction of the jaws and facial muscles in which the corners of the mouth are drawn back. The convulsions are most marked in anti-gravity muscles so that the body typically arches in hyperextension, the posture known as opisthotonos. If the spasm involves the abdominal muscles, the body bends forward (emprosthotonos), or to the side (pleurosthotonos). If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature known as postmortem caloricity.

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

  • Convulsions - clonic-tonic type
  • Reflex increased
  • Awful taste
  • Mind is conscious
  • Pupils dilated
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

Strychnine plant

Strychnine seeds

questions.text: A 57-year-old lady presented with complaints of dyspareunia and vaginal spotting, despite attaining menopause 3 years back. She has no other complaints, is not on any medications, and has no family history of carcinomas. On examination, the vagina appeared pale with small petechiae. Transvaginal ultrasound revealed a 3 mm thick endometrium with no abnormality. Which among the following would be an appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of atrophic vaginitis, which should be managed with topical estrogen, the estradiol-releasing vaginal ring being the best answer among the given options.

Atrophic vaginitis is a common cause of post-menopausal bleeding due to low estradiol levels resulting in friability. Patients may present with dry vagina; dyspareunia; and a purulent, often slightly blood-tinged, discharge. The vagina appears pale, dry, and may contain petechiae. These symptoms are part of a constellation of signs and symptoms described under genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM).

Treatment of atrophic vaginitis involves topical estrogens in the form of creams, tablets, or rings. Estrogen replacement restores vaginal mucosal elasticity, vaginal fluid secretion levels, blood flow, and sensorimotor responses.

Options include

  • Conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally 
  • A continuous low-dose estradiol-releasing vaginal ring containing 2 mg estradiol 
  • A 10 μg 17β-estradiol tablet intravaginally
  • An oral estrogen may be considered for maintenance therapy
  • Vaginal lubricants and moisturizers may also provide symptomatic relief.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

Other options:

Option A: Pipelle biopsy is done if the endometrial thickness is >4 mm on the transvaginal sonogram.

Option C: Mirena intrauterine device (IUD) or levonorgestrel IUD is effective if there is endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. It is also used to control abnormal uterine bleeding in the reproductive age group and is an effective method of contraception. 

Option D: Hysteroscopy is generally performed if pipelle biopsy does not yield an adequate result or cannot be passed.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Kerley A lines?

choices.text: Radiate from the hilum of lungs
Runs perpendicular to the pleural surface and extend out to it
Short lines which do not reach the pleura

questions.solution:
Kerley A lines radiate from the hilum of the lungs.

Kerley lines are seen when the interlobular septa in the pulmonary interstitium become prominent. 

This may be because of lymphatic engorgement or edema of the connective tissues of the interlobular septa. They usually occur when pulmonary capillary wedge pressure reaches 20-25 mmHg.

Types of Kerley lines:  

  • Kerley A lines:
    • Thin, oblique lines(2-6cm long and thickness under 1mm), radiating from the hilum to the upper lobes. 
    • HRCT is the most effective imaging technique to identify these lines. 
  • Kerley B lines:
    • Thin, horizontal lines (1-2 cm long), seen at the lung periphery, usually near the bases. 
    • Run perpendicular to the pleural surface and reach it, representing thickened subpleural interlobular septa.
  • Kerley C lines :
    • Short, irregular lines with a spider web-like appearance. 
    • Unlike Kerley B and D lines, they do not extend to the pleura; unlike Kerley A lines, they do not radiate outward from the hila.
  • Kerley D lines - the same as Kerley B lines, except that they are seen on lateral chest radiographs in the retrosternal air gap
