questions.text: A young woman with atrial fibrillation is started on unfractionated heparin. After 6 days, she complains of reddening, swelling, and severe pain in her lower limbs. Her platelet count is 90,000/μL. Laboratory investigations reveal the presence of antibodies against heparin-platelet factor 4 complexes. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue unfractionated heparin and start warfarin
Discontinue unfractionated heparin and start lepirudin
Reduce the dose of unfractionated heparin and start with low molecular weight heparin

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis due to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. The next step in the management of this patient is to discontinue unfractionated heparin and start lepirudin.

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) results due to the formation of antibodies against heparin-platelet 4 complexes. These antibodies also bind to the platelet Fc receptors and promote thrombosis. Features of HIT are usually seen after 5-10 days of starting heparin and are more common in females than in males. The platelet count usually drops to less than ≤100,000/μL or decreases to ≥50% compared to the levels before the initiation of heparin. The patients can also show the features of deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, acute myocardial infarction due to extensive formation of thrombi.

Stop heparin immediately and start with parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as lepirudin, argatroban, or bivalirudin, or factor Xa inhibitors, such as fondaparinux or rivaroxaban. Do not give platelet transfusions. Warfarin is not given until the platelet count returns to its baseline level. Patients with HIT already have low levels of protein C. Giving warfarin to these patients without thrombin inhibitors further decreases its levels and causes skin necrosis. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) should also not be used to treat HIT patients because most HIT antibodies exhibit cross-reactivity with LMWH.

Heparin acts by activating antithrombin. The antithrombin inhibits thrombin and factor Xa. It can be given subcutaneously or by continuous intravenous infusion. Heparin therapy requires monitoring and can be monitored using the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) or anti-factor Xa level.

Important side effects of heparin are:

  • Bleeding- is the most common side effect. Recent surgery, trauma, concomitant use of antiplatelet or antifibrinolytic agents increases the risk. Serious bleeding due to heparin is treated using protamine sulfate.
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Osteoporosis
  • Modest elevations of hepatic transaminases.

2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2. He says that he does not prefer injections. He had 1 episode of pancreatitis 3 years back and has a history of colon cancer in his family. He also has been diagnosed with heart failure and has been taking medications. Which of the following drugs can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Glimepiride can be given to this patient. It belongs to the class called sulfonylureas.

Sulfonylureas act by closing the ATP-sensitive K channels in the beta-cells of the pancreas. This closure causes cell membrane depolarization and the release of insulin. They are readily absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and therefore can be given orally. Important sulfonylureas are glimepiride, glipizide, glyburide, etc.

Important adverse effects are hypoglycemia, vomiting, cholestatic jaundice, agranulocytosis, and aplastic and hemolytic anemias. They can also cause a disulfiram-like reaction. They should be used with caution in pregnancy, lactation, and significant hepatic or renal insufficiency (for the older forms).

Other options

Option A- Pioglitazone belongs to a class of thiazolidinediones. It activates the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ) and increases insulin sensitivity. Apart from weight gain, it also causes edema and fluid retention. It increases the plasma volume and is therefore unsuitable for heart failure patients.

Option B- Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist. It stimulates insulin secretion, inhibits glucagon release, delays gastric emptying, reduces food intake, and normalizes fasting and postprandial insulin secretion. It is given subcutaneously. It can also cause pancreatitis, and therefore is not used in patients with a history or risk of developing pancreatitis.

Option D- Teduglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2) analog. It enhances the growth of intestinal mucosa. It is used in the treatment of short bowel syndrome and not diabetes mellitus. It is administered parenterally and discontinued in patients with active gastrointestinal malignancy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female came to the physician after an episode of hemoptysis. Over the past 4 months, she has had non-productive cough, fatigue, and a 6 kg weight loss. She does not smoke. X-ray chest shows a 2.8 cm nodule with irregular borders in the left lung. CT findings are shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a female patient, who is a non-smoker, presenting after an episode of hemoptysis, and associated history of non-productive cough, fatigue, and 6 kg weight loss suggests lung carcinoma. CT scan showing an irregular lesion at the periphery of the lung with no hilar lymphadenopathy is suggestive of adenocarcinoma. 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common tumor of the lung in non-smokers. It is more common in women. Adenocarcinoma of the lung occurs in the periphery of the lung, frequently in areas of chronic scarring caused by chronic inflammatory changes. EGFR oncogene mutations are common in adenocarcinomas of non-smokers.

Clinical features include cough, chest pain, hemoptysis, and symptoms due to metastasis. Some are responsible for paraneoplastic syndromes.

Lung adenocarcinomas are now classified by their predominant pattern:

  • Lepidic pattern (best prognosis; tumors ≤3 cm or with ≤5 mm invasion has near 100% 5-year disease-free survival with complete tumor resection)
  • Acinar pattern
  • Papillary pattern
  • Solid patterns (poor prognosis)

Lung nodules should always be compared with previous films. A CT scan is done for further evaluation and a biopsy is done to confirm the diagnosis.

Other Options:

Option A: Squamous cell cancer most commonly occurs in smokers and is typically centrally located.

Option B: Small cell cancer is a highly aggressive cancer that metastasizes early. It is also often associated with smoking and is generally metastasized by the time it gets diagnosed.

Option D: Sarcoidosis can present with weight loss and non-productive cough. However, there is associated hilar lymphadenopathy, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true in the given graph?

1 – Drug A has more potency and efficacy when compared to drug B
2 – Drug C has the same efficacy as Drug A
3 – Drug B and D have the same potency
4 – Drug D has more efficacy but less potency than drug C
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 4 are true about the given dose-response curve. Drug C has the same efficacy as drug A. Drug D has more efficacy but has less potency than Drug C.

Potency is the dose or concentration of a drug required to produce 50% of the drug’s maximal effect. The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. 

Efficacy is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve. It reflects the capacity of the drug to bind a receptor and produce a cellular response.

In the above graph order of potency is A>B>C>D. Drugs A and C have same efficacy, and drug B and D have the same efficacy.

The slope of the DRC also has significance. A steep slope implies that a moderate increase in dose markedly increases the response. Thus, for such drugs, the dose needs individualization. A flat slope implies that over a wide dose range, only a little increase in response will occur. Thus, these drugs can be given in standard doses.

questions.text: A patient with chronic lymphocytic leukemia was started on fludarabine. After 36 hours of starting the therapy, she developed abdominal pain, hematuria, vomiting, and severe muscle cramps. The laboratory investigations reveal hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia. Which of the following is not done in the management of this condition?

choices.text: Aggressive hydration with normal or 1/2 normal saline

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) as the patient developed abdominal pain, hematuria, and muscle cramps with hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia following the administration of fludarabine. Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate is not done in the management of this condition.

Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate increases uric acid solubility, but a high pH decreases the solubility of xanthine, hypoxanthine, and calcium phosphate, and increases the likelihood of intratubular crystallization.

It is caused due to destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating cells. It is seen following treatment of Burkitt's lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, etc. TLS is also caused following the administration of fludarabine, glucocorticoids, hormonal agents such as letrozole and tamoxifen, and monoclonal antibodies such as rituximab and gemtuzumab.

Metabolic abnormalities in tumor lysis syndrome are 

  • Hyperuricemia-It occurs due to the increased turnover of nucleic acids. These may get precipitated in the renal tubules leading to renal failure.
  • Hyperkalemia- occurs due to the release of intracellular potassium ions
  • Hyperphosphatemia- occurs due to the release of intracellular phosphate stores
  • Hypocalcemia- occurs as a result of increased levels of phosphate
  • Acidosis may also develop.

Management of TLS consists of allopurinol and aggressive hydration with normal or 1/2 normal saline. Febuxostat and rasburicase are the other drugs that can be used in the management of high uric acid levels. If the patient develops renal failure, then hemodialysis is necessary.

questions.text: Match the following mammogram images with their diagnoses.

choices.text: 1- Duct ectasia  2- Malignancy  3- Traumatic fat necrosis   4- Fibroadenoma
1- Traumatic fat necrosis   2- Fibroadenoma  3- Malignancy  4-Duct ectasia
1- Fibroadenoma   2- Traumatic fat necrosis   3- Duct ectasia   4- Malignancy
1- Malignancy  2- Duct ectasia  3- Fibroadenoma   4-Traumatic fat necrosis

questions.solution:
The correct match is:

1- Traumatic fat necrosis 
2- Fibroadenoma 
3- Malignancy
4- Duct ectasia

Egg-shell calcification or lead pipe calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis. Usually seen with a  previous history of surgery or trauma. There are egg-shell calcifications in the wall of an oil cyst or as coarse dystrophic calcifications with scarring. 


Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma. These are the most common benign masses of the breast. On mammograms, they present as rounded or oval masses with coarse calcifications (popcorn calcifications) as shown in the image below.


Breast malignancies appear as ill-defined spiculated masses with microcalcifications as shown in the image below.


Duct ectasias present with broken needle calcifications. This occurs due to the calcification of debris within dilated ducts. Most of the time, these are bilateral.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with grand mal seizures. CT reveals a brain tumor. On the surgical table, it was noted that the tumor had spread in a sheet-like fashion along the dural surface. The gross pathology report mentions an encapsulated tumor with a polypoid appearance. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the gross pathology findings indicate the presence of a meningioma.

Meningioma:

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura, that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. Meningiomas may be found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.

Meningiomas are usually rounded masses with well-defined dural bases that compress the underlying brain but are easily separated from it. The surface of the mass is usually encapsulated by thin, fibrous tissue and may have a bosselated or polypoid appearance.

They may also grow en plaque, in which the tumor spreads in a sheetlike fashion along the surface of the dura.

WHO grading of meningiomas:

  • Grade I - Most meningiomas fall under this category. For example - Syncytial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcytic.
    • Simple surgical excision is the treatment.
  • Grade II - They are also called atypical meningiomas. These have a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive growth. For example- Clear cell and chordoid type of meningiomas.
    • These may require radiotherapy in addition to surgery.
  • Grade III - These are called anaplastic (malignant) meningiomas and are highly aggressive tumors - Papillary and rhabdoid meningiomas are examples. Surgical excision of the tumor and the tissue it has invaded is the mainstay.
    • Radiotherapy is an additional treatment. The recurrence rate is high even after tumor excision.

questions.text: The structure labelled as 'A'  in the given image penetrates the pericardium at the level of _______.
questions.solution:
The structure labelled as 'A' in the given image is the superior vena cava and it penetrates the pericardium at the level of the sternal plane. The horizontal sternal plane passes through the intervertebral disc between the T4 and T5 posteriorly and manubriosternal joint at the level of the second coastal joint anteriorly.

This plane also signifies:

  • Separation of the superior mediastinum and inferior mediastinum
  • Superior limit of the pericardium
  • Bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk
  • Origin of the arch of the aorta
  • The entry of the superior vena cava into the pericardium

questions.text: A cachexic man presented with a non-productive cough and shortness of breath. He was diagnosed with HIV 6 months ago but is non-adherent to ART. Serum LDH is 350 U/L. Giemsa-stained smears are seen below. At what CD4 count should the prophylaxis be started according to the CDC recommendation to prevent this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). The prophylaxis for PCP is started at <200/mm3 CD4 count according to the CDC recommendation. In PCP LDH is elevated and smear stained with Giemsa stain shows trophic forms with dot-like nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm as well as intracystic bodies of Pneumocystis jiroveci.

Primary prophylaxis of PCP:

Indications
  • CD4+ T cell count <200/uL ( CD4 cell %<15)
  • Recent oropharyngeal candidiasis and prior PCP
  • Any patient with unexplained fever for > 2 weeks.
Drug of choice

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX), one double-strength tablet daily. 

Alternatives- Dapsone/Pyrimethamine + Leucovorin or Atovaqone or Aerosolised Pentamidine

Note : TMP-SMX also provides protection against toxoplasmosis and some bacterial respiratory pathogens. The prophylaxis is discontinued in those patients treated with ART who maintain good suppression of HIV (<50 copies/mL) and CD4+ T-cell counts >200/ μL for at least 3 months.

questions.text: A study on the prevalence of diabetes was conducted and the sampling method shown below was used. Identify the sampling method used.
questions.solution:
In this study, the population is separated into homogenous sub-groups and from these, random samples are drawn. This sampling method is called stratified random sampling.

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents with dry cough and mild fever for 5 days and musculoskeletal pain for one week. Examination reveals increased respiratory rate and skin lesions all over her body as shown below. Other findings are given below. What is the most effective drug for this condition?

Temperature: 37.8 degrees

Pulse rate: 98 bpm

Blood pressure: 100/70mmHg

Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation

Bronchoalveolar lavage culture shows a fried egg appearance
questions.solution:
The given scenario point towards pneumonia whereas the constitutional symptoms, patchy consolidation on chest Xray and fried egg appearance on culture is suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Azithromycin is the most effective drug for the treatment of M. pneumonia.

Pneumonia due to M. pneumonia is also referred to as Eaton agent pneumonia, primary atypical pneumonia, and walking pneumonia. Other bacterial causes of atypical community-acquired pneumonia are Chlamydia pneumonia and Legionella.

Upper respiratory tract infection (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) and pneumonia are common pulmonary manifestations. Majority of patients with Mycoplasma pneumonia present with dry cough, sore throat and fever.

It is also can present with extrapulmonary manifestations including erythema multiforme/Steven-Johnson syndrome (SJS), cold agglutinin disease, Guillain Barre syndrome, and transverse myelitis, arthritis, myocarditis, pericarditis and encephalitis.

Investigations include PCR of respiratory secretions and chest X-rays. Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation with thickened bronchial markings and subsegmental atelectasis.

Culture shows a typical fried egg appearance (central opaque granular area of growth sorrounded by a flat translucent peripheral zone) on PPLO agar. The diagnosis is made by serology or by PCR. 

Azithromycin is the most effective drug for management. Other drugs used are doxycycline, clarithromycin, erythromycin, moxifloxacin, levofloxacin, gemifloxacin.

Other options:

Options A and B: Amoxicillin and Cefotaxime are beta-lactam antibiotics (cell-wall synthesis inhibitors), hence they are not effective on M.pneumoniae as they lack a cell wall.

Option D: Ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin are not recommended because of their high minimal inhibitory concentrations against M. pneumoniae isolates.

questions.text: A 36-year-old pregnant lady presents in her first trimester for a check-up. She mentions that she has a family history of the condition shown in the images below. Which of the following  can be used to screen for the condition during this visit?
questions.solution:
The images showing a child with oblique palpebral fissures, a depressed nasal bridge, and a single palmar crease are suggestive of Down's syndrome (Trisomy 21). Nuchal translucency (NT) is used to screen for it during the first trimester. 

Nuchal translucency is the maximum thickness of the translucent area between the skin and soft tissue over the fetal spine at the back of the neck. When the NT measurement is increased, it is a marker for fetal aneuploidy and struc­tural anomalies.

Combined first-trimester screening consists of serum human chorionic gonad­otropin (hCG), pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A), and the measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT) on ultrasound. It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation.

In fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester hCG level is increased, PAPP-A level is decreased, and nuchal translucency thickness is increased.

The ultrasound image below shows increased NT thickness and absent nasal bone of a fetus with Trisomy 21 at 11 weeks gestation:


Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) and unconjugated estriol are measured in the second trimester as part of the triple screening test. Inhibin A is measured as part of the quadruple screening test.

The screening test results associated with trisomy 21 are summarized in the table below:

Combined 1st trimester test Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test (2nd trimester)
Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased
PAPP-A decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased
NT increased MSAFP decreased MSAFP decreased
    Serum inhibin increased

    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers

  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy received an intravenous opioid for analgesia. A few minutes later, his heart rate decreased from 72/min to 58/min. Which among the following drugs is least likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Meperidine (pethidine) is least likely to be associated with bradycardia.

Intravenous meperidine produces tachycardia as it has a structure similar to atropine. Unlike other opioids, meperidine causes mydriasis due to its anticholinergic effect.

Other options-

Option (A, B, and C): Fentanyl, Sufentanyl, and Alfentanyl are all opioid agonists that produce bradycardia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presented to the dermatology OPD with the following facial features. A diagnosis of connective tissue disorder was made. All of the following auto-antibodies are associated with this disorder except?
questions.solution:
The connective tissue disorder shown in the image is Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis.

Anti-ds DNA antibody is not seen in scleroderma, but in SLE.

The auto-antibodies associated with scleroderma are as follows:

  • Anti topoisomerase (Scl-70) antibody
  • Anti ribonucleoprotein antibody
  • Anti centromere antibody
  • Anti polymyositis-scleroderma (anti-PM-Scl) antibody
  • Anti fibrillation (U3-RNP) antibody
  • Anti-U1RNP antibody
  • Anti Th/ To antibody
  • Anti- U11/U12RNP antibody 
  • Anti- Ku antibody

Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4: 1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features are seen in Scleroderma:

  • Severe pruritus
  • Initially, scleroderma patients experience puffiness and non-pitting edema of the fingers.
  • The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly.
  • Vasospasm and Digital ulceration
  • Around 90% of patients suffering from scleroderma have dysphagia; and GERD at the level of the esophagus.
  • The mask-like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles.

Image: Typical facial features: note the expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

Image:  Digital Ulceration

Image: Advanced‐stage sclerodactyly with contractures and vasculopathic ulcers over the bony prominences

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician due to redness in the eyes and tongue for the past 2 days. He also has a history of fever and swelling of his hands and feet during the past week. On examination, desquamative rash and cervical lymphadenopathy are observed. What is the underlying histopathology in this patient's condition?

choices.text: Segmental medial granulomatous inflammation with elastic lamina fragmentation
Segmental, thrombosing inflamation of the vessels
Segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation of large to medium-sized, and small vessels
Necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis involving the capillaries

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of this child is suggestive of Kawasaki disease. The histopathological picture corresponding to Kawasaki disease is segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation of large to medium-sized, and even small arteries.

Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) is a self-limiting illness of infancy or childhood. Approx 20% develop cardiac complications like aneurysms, MI, and sudden death. Treatment involves IV Immunoglobulin and aspirin.

The vascular damage in Kawasaki disease is mainly mediated by the T cells and also by monocytes/macrophages resulting in a dense transmural infiltrate. This histological picture is also seen in polyarteritis nodosa, and Churg–Strauss syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Segmental medial granulomatous inflammation with elastic lamina fragmentation is seen in temporal arteritis 

Option B: Segmental, thrombosing inflammation of the vessels is seen in thrombo-angiitis obliterans (Buerger Disease)

Option C: Necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis is seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

 

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival infection (90% of cases)

Related Pearl: Classification of vasculitis - Modified Chapel Hill classification

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of mental retardation and facial asymmetry. On examination, the child had stunted growth, a short neck, and cloudy cornea. The child also had coarse facial features, an enlarged abdomen, herniated umbilicus, and massive hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory examination shows an increased urinary level of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate. Which of the following is not a radiological finding seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of mental retardation, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea, and increased levels of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate are suggestive of Hurler’s syndrome and it is associated with macrocephaly.

Hurler syndrome is also known as MPS 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L Iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparin sulfate and dermatan sulfate.

Features of Hurler's syndrome

  • Mental retardation
  • Coarse facial features
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Cloudy cornea
  • Excrete excess dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate in the urine
  • The characteristic appearance of patients - “gargoylism.”

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

 

J-shaped sella

Oar shaped ribs

Phenotypical features of Hurler's syndrome and Hunter's syndrome are quite similar; however, Hunter syndrome is generally less severe than Hurler syndrome and can be clinically differentiated by a lack of corneal clouding. Hurler syndrome was formerly known as gargoylism, as the build-up of mucopolysaccharide leads to the coarsening of facial features.

questions.text: The below given image shows result of hair perforation test. The organism likely to show below given appearance is
questions.solution:
Image shows surface erosion of shaft caused by Trichophyton mentagrophytes.

Hair perforation test:

  • Done to differentiate Trichophyton rubrum from mentagrophytes.
  • A few strands of human hair are placed in a Petri dish with 20 ml of distilled water and autoclaved.
  • A few drops of sterile 10% yeast extract and a few fragments of the test fungus are added to the hair strands.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt abdominal trauma. On examination, he was hemodynamically stable. Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) showed splenic trauma with a subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area with ongoing hemorrhage. Angiography and embolization were done but failed to achieve hemostasis. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in management is splenorrhaphy. 

The non-expanding subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area is suggestive of grade II splenic injury. These patients are managed by angiography and embolization, and if it fails, the next step in management is a spleen-saving technique or splenorrhaphy.

Splenorrhaphy is a procedure done to preserve the spleen parenchyma. These involve all the surgical procedures done to save the spleen parenchyma while splenectomy is the entire surgical removal of the viscera. Splenorrhaphy should not be performed if the patient is unstable if there are multiple injuries or extensive splenic injury. 

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area) or laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (10-50% of surface area) or laceration, 1-3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Hematoma > 50% of surface area or expanding

  • Ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding Or
    Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving
    trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
or
A hilar vascular injury that devascularizes the spleen.

Management of splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries:

They are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively. Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals, hematocrit, and serial CECT.

If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis. If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable, then a splenorrhaphy is done.

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

Other options: 

Option A: Repeat angiography and embolization are unlikely to help as it has already failed once in this patient. 

Option B: Conservative management will not stop the ongoing hemorrhage that is present in this patient. It is useful in patients who are no longer bleeding. 

Option C: Splenectomy is not required in this patient as they have a grade II injury and are still hemodynamically stable.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A multiparous woman has a previous history of birth trauma with injury to the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. Which of the following is likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Uterosacral and cardinal ligaments form the level 1 support of the genital organs. Level 1 damage can lead to enterocele, uterine descent, vault descent.

DeLancey introduced three-level systems of genital tract supports,

  • Level I includes uterosacral and cardinal ligaments and its damage leads to uterine descent, enterocoele, and vault prolapse.
  • Level II includes pelvic fascia, paracolpos, arcus tendinous, pubocervical and rectovaginal fascia, and its damage leads to cystocele and rectocele.
  • Level III includes levator ani muscle and its damage leads to urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum.

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man came to the dermatology department with the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given image and the clinical history, the diagnosis is Berloque dermatitis.

Berloque dermatitis is a type of skin pigmentation due to an acute phototoxic reaction to perfumes applied to the skin.

Berloque dermatitis results from the potentiation of UV-stimulated melanogenesis by 5-methoxypsoralen (bergapten) in perfumes containing bergamot oil.

Deep-brown pigmentation follows the pattern formed by the trickle of the droplets of perfume over the skin from their points of application.

TREATMENT:

1) Avoidance of perfumes

2) Oral antihistamines

3) Parenterally administered epinephrine in case of anaphylactic reactions

OTHER OPTIONS:

A) Post-inflammatory hypermelanosis:

It is residual macular pigmentation resulting from prior skin inflammation.

B) Phytophotodermatitis:

It is an inflammatory and pigmentary reaction of the skin to light, potentiated by furocoumarins in plants.

D) Drug-induced hyperpigmentation:

It is localised or generalised hyperpigmentation caused by a wide range of medications or chemicals such as,

  • Amiodarone
  • Antimalarial drugs
  • Clofazimine
  • Busulfan
  • Hydantoin
  • Trifluoperazine
  • Tetracycline, etc.,

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient came to you with the complaints of swelling of the right lower limb. During the examination, you noticed that the edema was non-pitting, and you were not able to pinch the skin on the dorsum of the toes on the right foot, as shown in the image given below. The edema did not reduce upon elevation of the limb, however, there were no irreversible skin changes. What is the Brunner grading in this patient?
questions.solution:
Non-pitting oedema, which does not reduce on elevation, having a positive stemmer sign (as shown in the above image) with no irreversible skin changes would be classified as grade II according to Brunner's grading.

Stemmer’s sign is seen in lymphedema. When the skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched, the stemmer's sign is said to be positive. It occurs due to subcutaneous fibrosis.

Clinical classification of lymphedema: Brunner's Grading

Grade Clinical features
Subclinical (latent) No clinically apparent lymphoedema (excess interstitial ﬂuid and histological abnormalities in lymphatics and lymph nodes)
I Edema pits on pressure and swelling largely or completely disappears on elevation and bed rest.
II Edema does not pit and does not signiﬁcantly reduce upon elevation, positive Stemmer’s sign.
III Edema is associated with irreversible skin changes, i.e. ﬁbrosis, papillae.

questions.text: The procedure portrayed in the picture below is indicated for which of the following cases of basal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The given procedure shows "Moh’s microscopic surgery" which is indicated in recurrent lesions of basal cell carcinoma.

Moh’s microscopic surgery involves a process of initial surgical excision of the tumor, followed by repeated tissue sampling along lateral and deep margins. These tissue samples are examined immediately under frozen section control for evidence of tumor. This process is repeated until the clearance is finally obtained.

Moh’s microscopic surgery is indicated in:

  • Primary lesions of the ear or lip
  • Recurrent lesions
  • Primaries with perineural invasion
  • Lesions with diameters >2 cm
  • Poorly differentiated lesions

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the method of contraception shown in the image below.

choices.text: It cannot be used in the puerperal period
It is impermeable to cytomegalovirus, hepatitis B and HIV.
Male partner should use a condom to increase the efficacy
Should be fitted and removed only by a medical professional

questions.solution:
The image shows a female condom and it is impermeable to HIV, Hepatitis B, and cytomegalovirus.

The female condom, also known as femidom or femshield is a pre-lubricated polyurethane cylindrical sheath with a flexible ring at both ends. The outer open ring remains outside the vagina and the inner closed ring is fitted beneath the cervix. 

 

 

It can be fitted by the patient hours before intercourse, and easily removed soon after. It covers the cervix, vagina, and external genitalia and is protective against sexually transmitted diseases. It can also be worn in the puerperal period, unlike the cervical diaphragm.

The female condom should not be used along with a male condom because if worn together they may slip, tear, or become displaced.

Other barrier methods of contraception include:

  • Male condom
  • Cervical cap
  • Cervical diaphragm - used with or without a spermicidal agent
  • Vaginal sponge

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of bluish discoloration of the skin on the sun-exposed areas. He has been on medication for monomorphic ventricular tachycardia for the past 3 years. Which drug is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of blue man syndrome which is most likely caused by amiodarone.

One of the side effects of amiodarone is photosensitivity. In some cases, bluish discoloration of the skin is seen, predominantly in the sun-exposed areas. This could be due to the immune response in dermal layers by amiodarone or the accumulation of amiodarone in superficial layers of skin.

The symptoms are reversible on drug discontinuation. The syndrome is related to both dose and photosensitivity.

The side effects of amiodarone include:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
  • Torsades de pointes
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neuropathies
  • Photosensitivity
  • Thyroid dysfunction

Other such syndromes associated with drugs are:

  • Red man syndrome - Vancomycin
  • Gray baby syndrome - Chloramphenicol

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete underwent a LASIK procedure. His intraocular pressure was measured using this instrument. What is the name of the instrument?
questions.solution:
The above given instrument is Pascal tonometer.

This is a dynamic contour tonometer. Intraocular pressure (IOP) readings are not affected by central corneal thickness. Pascal is the tonometer of choice for post LASIK corneas.

questions.text: A man presents with tingling of lips and mouth, abdominal discomfort, nausea, and flushing. He gives a history of eating a mackerel fish about an hour back and that it had an unusually metallic taste. He responds well to treatment with intravenous antihistamines. Which of the following is not a causative organism for this form of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus is not a causative agent of this type of poisoning. The given clinical vignette of a man presenting with the above symptoms after eating improperly stored mackerel or scombroid fish, with symptoms subsiding on treatment with intravenous antihistamines is indicative of histamine or scombroid fish poisoning.

It is caused due to consumption of fish (mackerel, tuna, etc) that is not preserved or refrigerated adequately. This results in the formation of histamine, histamine phosphate, and histamine hydrochloride by the following bacteria Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, and Proteus species. The affected fish may have a normal look and flavor, or it can have a strong metallic and peppery taste.

Symptoms usually develop within 15–90 min of ingestion. In mild cases, patients exhibit symptoms like tingling of lips and mouth, mild abdominal discomfort, and nausea. In severe cases, there is flushing of the face, neck, and upper trunk with pruritis. If the patient is not treated promptly, complications like bronchospasm, diarrhea, hypotension, and cardiogenic shock may occur.

Treatment is directed at reversing the effect of histamine with systemic antihistamines.

Staphylococcal food poisoning manifests as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea about 2-6 hours after consuming food that is contaminated by a preformed staphylococcal enterotoxin. Common sources of food are poultry, potato, egg salad, mayonnaise, or cream pastries. The condition is self-limited.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following finding to the OPD. He says he works at an aquarium and handles the fish without protective equipment. He gives a history of sustaining an injury in the same hand about 2 weeks back. Which of the following best describes the causative organisms' growth characteristics?

choices.text: No pigment in the dark, become pigmented on exposure to light
No pigment production even on exposure to light
Rapid growth seen within seven days

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing granulomatous skin infection following a trauma to the skin with subsequent exposure to freshwater fish tanks is suggestive of "fish tank granuloma". It is caused by Mycobacterium marinum which is a photochromogen that is not pigmented in the dark but becomes pigmented on exposure to light.

Mycobacterium marinum :

  • It is a type of non tuberculous mycobacterium
  • It causes a granulomatous skin and soft tissue infection in a patient with pre-existing skin lesion, on exposure to water contaminated with the organism. This is also called as swimming pool granuloma/ fish tank granuloma.
  • Clinical presentation is typically that of a single, small violet papule or nodule confined to one extremity, which become verrucous or ulcerated over time.
  • The infection may even ascend more proximally along the lymphatics, resembling cutaneous sporotrichosis.
  • Surgical excision with antimicrobials is found to be an effective treatment.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease is tested positive for COVID-19. Which anticoagulation agent would you recommended for him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID-19 in a patient with end-stage renal disease. Unfractionated heparin is recommended for use in such patients.

Prophylactic anticoagulation is used in the management of moderate and severe COVID cases. A prophylactic dose of low molecular weight heparin or unfractionated heparin is used to prevent thromboembolism. In a COVID patient with end-stage renal disease, unfractionated heparin is the preferred agent.

questions.text: Romiplostim is a
questions.solution:
Romiplostim is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. It is used in the management of immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). Eltrombopag is also a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. It is used in the treatment of ITP and severe aplastic anemia.

Other options:

Option A- Epoetin alfa and darbepoetin alfa are recombinant human erythropoietin. They can be used in the treatment of anemias associated with surgery, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, prematurity, and certain chronic inflammatory conditions. 

Option B- Filgrastim is a recombinant granulocyte colony-stimulating factor. It increases neutrophil production. It is used in the treatment of neutropenia. Important adverse reactions include bone pain, local skin reaction, and cutaneous necrotizing vasculitis.

Option C- Oprelvekin is a recombinant human IL-11. It increases thrombopoiesis. It is used in the treatment of thrombocytopenia due to non-myeloid malignancies. Important adverse effects are fluid retention, tachycardia, palpitation, edema, and shortness of breath.

Sargramostim is a recombinant granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor. It stimulates myelopoiesis. Important adverse effects are bone pain, malaise, flu-like symptoms, diarrhea, dyspnea, and rash.

questions.text: You are a resident doctor in the anesthesia department. A 40-year-old obese male had come for pre-operative assessment for thyroid surgery. He is a known case of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for the past 12 years on irregular treatment. He smokes cigarettes daily. Which of the following is not a risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications in this patient?
questions.solution:
The age of this patient (40 years) is not a risk factor for the development of postoperative pulmonary complications.

Risk factors for postoperative pulmonary complications:

  • Potential patient-related risk factors: 
    • Advanced age
    • ASA-PS class 2 or more
    • Functionally dependent
    • Weight loss
    • Congestive heart failure
    • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
    • Impaired sensorium
    • Cigarette, alcohol use
    • Abnormal findings on chest examination
  • Potential procedure-related risk factors:
    • Aortic aneurysm repair
    • Thoracic surgery
    • Abdominal surgery
    • Neurosurgery
    • Head and neck surgery
    • Emergency surgery
    • Vascular surgery
    • General anesthesia
    • Perioperative transfusion
  • Potential laboratory test risk factor
    • Albumin concentration <35 g/L
    • Chest radiograph abnormalities
    • BUN concentration > 7.5 mmol/L (>21 mg/dL)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a technique used in adjustment of rates?
questions.solution:
Proportional mortality ratio or rate is a mortality ratio, not a standardization technique. 

It expressed the number of deaths due to a particular cause (or in a given age group) per 100 total deaths. Proportional rates are useful indicators within any population group of the relative 

importance of the specific disease or disease group, as a cause of death. 

Standardization/ adjustment of rates is done to allow for comparison of health statuses of two populations after adjustments for age, sex, etc. using a standard population.

A) Direct Standardization:

  • The direct method uses actual age-specific death rates on standard population.
  • It is feasible only if actual specific rates in subgroups of the observed population are available, along with the number of people in each subgroup.
  • The concept is summarized by the given diagram:

 

 

B) Indirect Standardization

  • The indirect method uses standard age-specific death rates on the actual population.
  • The concept is summarized by the given diagram:

 

  • One form of this is called the Standardized Mortality Ratio.
    • It is a ratio of the total number of deaths that occur in the study group to the number of deaths that would have been expected to occur if that study group had experienced the death rates of a standard population.
    • It is given as x 100.
    • If the value is >100, then greater mortality risk, and if the value is <100, lesser risk.
    • It does not need to know specific rates for adjustment, unlike the direct method.
    • It can be used for a disease as an event of an occurrence, rather than death.
  • Other indirect methods are life table analysis, regression techniques, and multivariate analysis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravid mother in her 34th week of gestation was transferred to a tertiary care institution with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. Her physical examination was unremarkable except for the presence of icterus. Lab investigations revealed elevated serum bilirubin and serum transaminase levels, leading to a suspicion of acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Which among the following parameters is likely to be increased in severe cases?
questions.solution:
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy leads to hemolysis, which causes leukocytosis, nucleated red cells, mild to moderate thrombocytopenia, and elevated serum levels of lactic acid dehydrogenase (LDH).

Acute fatty liver is a rare, potentially fatal complication that occurs late in pregnancy, most commonly in the third trimester or early postpartum period. It is usually associated with male fetuses and in the first pregnancy. Clinical features include

  • Persistent nausea and vomiting.
  • Progressive jaundice.
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypertension
  • Proteinuria
  • Edema
  • Moderate to severe liver dysfunction manifested by
    • Hypofibrinogenemia
    • Hypoalbuminemia,
    • Hypocholesterolemia
    • Prolonged clotting times.

Diagnosis:

  • Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised.
  • Hemolysis with coagulopathy
    • Decreased platelets and fibrinogen
    • Elevated d-dimers and prothrombin time
  • Biopsy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.
  • Imaging is not a reliable method of diagnosis.

Management

  • Intensive supportive measures
  • C-section to hasten delivery
  • Hepatic dysfunction resolves postpartum

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic due to pneumonia. She has had repeated episodes of pneumonia due to Staphylococcus aureus in the past. She also has a history of easy bruising. On examination, she has light skin, silvery hair, and light blue eyes. Multiple bruises are seen on her legs and arms in different stages of healing. On peripheral blood film, the following image is seen. Which of the following defects is present in this patient?

choices.text: Loss of function of LYST gene

questions.solution:
The given clinical features of immunodeficiency fit the description of Chediak Higashi syndrome. A defect in the LYST gene is implicated in the development of Chediak Higashi syndrome.

Chediak Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to loss of function of the LYST gene (Lysosomal trafficking regulator gene)- a protein required for the normal packaging and distribution of granules. This defect results in defective chemotaxis, phagolysosome fusion, degranulation of T-cells and NK cells, and ADP granule function in platelets. Due to the defective fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes, giant granules in the neutrophils are seen. Other features include albinism (due to abnormalities of melanocytes), nerve defects (nerve cell dysfunction), and bleeding (due to platelet dysfunction).

Other Options:

Option A: Defective CD40 ligand is seen in hyper IgM syndrome. In this, there are low levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE. Clinically, patients present with recurrent pyogenic infections, because the level of opsonizing IgG antibodies is low. No giant granules are seen on peripheral blood film along with no signs of albinism. 

Option B: WAS gene mutation is seen in Wiscott-Aldrich syndrome, an X-linked disease characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection. This patient has no history of eczema.

Option D: Defective NADPH oxidase is seen in Chronic granulomatous disease, which is characterized by defects in bacterial killing and renders patients susceptible to recurrent bacterial infection especially by catalase-positive organisms. It is not associated with albinism and platelet dysfunction.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the physician with the chief complaint of swollen fingers. She has been having a problem swimming for the past year because her fingers hurt and turn blue as soon as she got into cold water. On examination, the skin over her hands is shiny, taut, and thickened with non-pitting edema. Movement of the hand is limited and there appears to be some muscle weakness. There are numerous small, superficial dilated vessels at the tip of the fingers. Small bumps over the thumb as depicted in the picture are seen. Further evaluation will most likely show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Atony and decreased lower esophageal sphicter pressure
Fibrosis and increased lower esophageal sphicter pressure
Esophageal stricture and increased sphincter pressure

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with skin thickening, Calcinosis cutis(picture), Raynaud phenomenon, and Telangiectasia is suggestive of CREST syndrome.

CREST stands for:-

  • Calcinosis cutis(calcium deposits on pressure points)
  • Raynaud phenomenon(fingers turns blue on exposure to cold)
  • Esophageal dysmotility(atony due to fibrosis)
  • Sclerodactyly(thickening of the skin)
  • Telangiectasia(dilation of vessels of skin)

It is a subtype of systemic sclerosis, an autoimmune disorder of connective tissues. Anti-centromere antibodies are positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis(CREST syndrome)

Esophageal dysfunction attributable to esophageal fibrosis and its resultant hypomotility is present in more than 50% of patients. Eventually, destruction of the esophageal wall leads to atony and dilation, especially at its lower end.

Other Options:

Option A: Diffuse esophageal spasm is characterized by repetitive, simultaneous contractions of the distal esophageal smooth muscle. It is not a feature of CREST syndrome.

Option C: An increase in lower esophageal sphincter pressure is seen in achalasia cardia, due to defective nerves that fail to relax the LES.

Option D: Esophageal stenosis is caused by fibrous thickening of the submucosa. Stenosis may occur due to chronic GERD, irradiation or caustic injury. Some cancers may cause strictures. It is not a feature of CREST syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with ventricular septal defect is posted for corrective surgery. Which of the following is the inhalational agent of choice for induction in this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a child undergoing cardiac surgery, sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for induction.

Halothane and sevoflurane are non-pungent and are less likely to irritate the airway or cause breath-holding or laryngospasm during induction. Hence, halothane and sevoflurane are most suited for use in induction among pediatric patients.

Sevoflurane is less frequently associated with significant myocardial depression, bradycardia, and arrhythmias which are seen with halothane. Hence, sevoflurane is preferred over halothane, especially in all cardiovascular surgeries in the pediatric age group.

Halothane sensitizes the heart to catecholamines, therefore careful reduction in the epinephrine dose in local anesthetic solutions must be followed. 

Following induction, isoflurane and sevoflurane are the most commonly used inhalation agents for maintenance. 

Desflurane and isoflurane are pungent compounds that irritate the airway and may lead to increased airway resistance, breath-holding, and laryngospasm which make them a poor choice for induction.

questions.text: One of your relatives brought his friend's liver test report to get your opinion, as you recently completed your MBBS. The report, amongst other things, mentions the presence of Mallory-Denk inclusion bodies. You would suspect all of the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
Mallory-Denk inclusion bodies are not seen in acute viral hepatitis but Councilman bodies are seen.

Mallory-Denk bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies due to the aggregation of cytoskeletal intermediate filaments. They appear as clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes. They are seen in,

  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
  • Wilson disease
  • Chronic biliary tract diseases.

Note: 

A councilman body, also known as the councilman hyaline body or apoptotic body, is an acidophilic (eosinophilic) globule of cells that represents a dying hepatocyte often surrounded by normal parenchyma.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl was brought with an enlargement of the breast. On examination, her breasts were at Tanner stage 4 and her pubic hair was at stage 1. Ultrasound examination of the pelvis showed that the uterus was enlarged for age, with ovaries almost at the adult size. Which of the following investigations is least likely to be required in the workup of this case?

LH - Luteinizing hormone

FSH - Follicle-stimulating hormone

DHEAS - Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate

TSH - Thyroid-stimulating hormone

choices.text: Serum LH, FSH and estradiol levels

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of precocious puberty. Measurement of serum dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) levels is least likely to be required in the workup for this case, as there are no signs of virilization.

Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years. Precocious puberty in boys is the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 9 years. 

Precocious puberty with the secondary sexual characteristics of the patient's own gender is termed isosexual, while that with secondary sexual characteristics of the opposite gender (such as virilization in girls) is termed contrasexual. Virilization refers to features of hirsutism, clitoromegaly, hoarseness of voice, acne, breast atrophy, and male pattern of body contour and hair loss.

Classification:

  • Complete precocious puberty: Idiopathic, familial, sporadic, genetic, congenital/acquired lesions of the hypothalamic and pituitary glands, specific syndromes (McCune-Albright syndrome)
  • Incomplete precocious puberty: Premature thelarche, adrenarche, menarche
  • Pseudoprecocious puberty (GnRH independent): Ovarian tumors, adrenal hyperplasia/neoplasm, hypothyroidism, hepatoblastoma, iatrogenic-estrogen administration

Investigations in a case of precocious puberty:

  • Radiograph of the wrist for bone age
  • Measurement of serum FSH, LH, and estradiol levels
  • Measurement of serum TSH levels
  • Pelvic sonography
  • MRI of the skull

In girls with signs of virilization, all of the above investigations are done, in addition to measuring the levels of the following:

  • DHEAS
  • Testosterone
  • 17α-Hydroxyprogesterone
  • Androstenedione
  • 11-Deoxycortisol

The leuprolide stimulation test differentiates premature thelarche from true central and peripheral precocious puberty. Treatment includes injection of DMPA, cyproterone acetate, GnRH agonists, and calcium and vitamin D supplements.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme?
questions.solution:
Tolcapone acts by inhibiting the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme. 

The addition of carbidopa to levodopa prevents peripheral decarboxylation of  levodopa. However, levodopa can now be methylated by catechol-O-methyl transferase and get inactivated. This is prevented by catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) inhibitors tolcapone and entacapone. 

Parkinson's disease arises as a result of the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the striatum. Therefore the mainstay of treatment for this disease is to increase dopamine in this area.

Other options:

Option A- Amantadine is an antiviral agent. It is used in the prophylaxis and treatment of influenza A. It has antiparkinsonian activity. It alters dopamine release in the striatum, has anticholinergic properties, and blocks methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors. It can be used in mild disease, dose-related fluctuations, and dyskinesia.

Option B- Rotigotine is a dopamine receptor agonist. It acts on D1 and D2 receptors, whereas ropinirole and pramipexole act on the D2 and D3 receptors.  The duration of action of the DA agonists (8–24 h) is often longer than that of levodopa (6–8 h). They are effective in the treatment of patients who have developed on/off phenomena.

Option D- Selegiline and rasagiline are selective monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitors. Dopamine in the striatum is predominantly metabolized by the MAO-B enzyme. Inhibiting this enzyme will increase dopamine concentration in these neurons. They selectively and irreversibly inactivate MAO-B.

Note:

Other drugs used in parkinsonism are:

Levodopa is a prodrug. It crosses the blood-brain barrier. Levodopa is converted to dopamine by decarboxylation in dopaminergic neurons in the striatum. It significantly improves the signs and symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

An adverse effect of levodopa is the wearing-off phenomenon. After administrating levodopa, there is improvement in the symptoms for a period of 1–2 h, but rigidity and akinesia return rapidly after the effect of the drug reduces. Increasing the dose and frequency of administration can improve this phenomenon, but the patients often develop dyskinesia and excessive abnormal involuntary movements.

In the later stages of the disease, patients may fluctuate rapidly between being “off,” having no beneficial effects from their medications, and being “on” having some beneficial effects but along with side effects.

Levodopa, if administered alone will undergo decarboxylation by the decarboxylases present in the intestinal mucosa and other peripheral sites. This will lead to decreased concentration of the drug reaching the brain. In order to prevent this levodopa is always given with carbidopa. Carbidopa inhibits peripheral decarboxylase enzymes.  

Muscarinic receptor antagonists are used as adjuncts to dopamine therapy. Eg. trihexyphenidyl and benztropine. Diphenhydramine, an antihistamine is also used.

Apomorphine acts on D4 and mildly on D2, D3, and D5 receptors. It also has adrenergic action.

questions.text: A 62-year-old hypertensive male patient presents with dizziness and palpitations. On examination, his pulse rate is 132 per minute with an irregularly irregular rhythm. His ECG is given below. He does not have a history of diabetes milletus, congestive heart failure, cerebrovascular or other vascular diseases. What is his CHA2DS2-VASc score?
questions.solution:
The CHA2DS2-VASc score for the described patient is 1. The given clinical scenario and ECG features depict atrial fibrillation. 

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Anticoagulation is recommended if the score is ≥2. The following risk factors are considered during the calculation of the score:

Risk factors Score
Congestive heart failure 1
Hypertension 1
Age ≥75years 2
Diabetes mellitus 1
Stroke or Transient ischemic attack or embolus 2
Vascular disease 1
Age 65-75years 1
Sex- female 1 

The patient is a known case of hypertension with none of the above-mentioned features present. Hence, his CHA2DS2-VASc score is 1.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a type of cardiac arrhythmia characterized by disorganized, rapid, and irregular atrial activation. It is common in men and risk factors include underlying cardiac disease, hypertension, diabetes, family history of AF, obesity, and sleeping disorders.

Features include heart rate typically ranging from 110-160 beats/minute. It is irregular and rapid. Presyncope and syncope can be seen. Thrombus formation can occur and thromboembolic events can take place. Typically, ECG shows an absent P wave.

Management is mainly by control of rate and rhythm, avoiding the thromboembolism risk and modifiable risk factors.

Immediate cardioversion should be done when the patient presents within 48 hours and are at low risk for developing stroke whereas in patients presenting after 48 hours or if the duration is not known, there is an increased risk of thromboembolism. Therefore, anticoagulation should be done for 3 weeks followed by cardioversion and 4 weeks post cardioversion. 

The other approach is to start anticoagulation following transesophageal echo. Cardioversion can be done only if the thrombus is absent. The rate control strategy is achieved with calcium channel blockers/ beta blockers and digoxin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient has undergone cataract surgery in his right eye 2 years back. Initially, after the surgery, his vision was good but started experiencing a progressive diminution in his vision for the past 3 months. Examination of his right eye is shown below. Which of the following laser is used in managing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image are suggestive of a posterior capsular opacification (PCO). It is managed by Nd: YAG laser capsulotomy.

PCO, also called 'after' or 'secondary' cataracts, is the opacification that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. This happens because, some amount of lens particles are left in situ during surgery, which proliferates and gets opacified, resulting in the formation of an after-cataract. If the newly formed fibers are enclosed between the two layers of the lens, a dense ring is formed behind the iris. This is named 'the ring of Sommerring'.Instead, if the cells proliferate to form large-balloon-like cells, filling the pupillary aperture, they are called Elschnig pearls.

Management of after-cataract:

Management of an after-cataract depends upon its thickness. A thin one can be cleared by Nd: YAG capsulotomy. The thicker ones are managed by, cutting with a Ziegler knife and the cut fragments are aspirated by a vitreous cutter.

The given image below shows the presence of a white ring behind the iris with the likely diagnosis being Soemmering’s ring.

 

The below image shows Elschnig’s pearls which are vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells, clustered like soap bubbles along the posterior capsule of the lens.

questions.text: Consider the image given below showing hypertension in community. Number 7 in the image denotes________
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is not an objective of the GOBI-FFF program?

choices.text: Prevention of dietary deficiencies in pregnancy

questions.solution:
Food Fortification is not covered under the GOBI-FFF Strategy. Food Supplementation is an initiative under the GOBI-FFF scheme. 

The GOBI FFF strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF, originally known as United Nations Internation Children’s Emergency Fund). It was initiated to encourage 4 strategies for a child health revolution. Later, FFF- the maternal initiatives were introduced to make it GOBI-FFF. 

Food fortification is a public health measure aimed at preventing and controlling some nutritional deficiencies by reinforcing the usual dietary intake of nutrients with additional supplies. It involves adding nutrients to food in relatively small quantities to maintain or improve the quality of the diet of a group, community, or population. Examples- 

  • Fluoridation of water to prevent dental caries 
  • Iodization of salt to prevent endemic goiter
  • Vit A and D added in vanaspati, milk 

Criteria for food fortification- 

  • Food fortified must be consumed consistently as part of the regular daily diet by the relevant sections of the population
  • The amount of nutrient added must provide an effective supplement for low consumers of the vehicle, without contributing a hazardous excess to those consuming higher amounts
  • Fortification should not cause any noticeable change in taste, smell, appearance, or consistency of the food
  • The cost of fortification must not raise the price of the food beyond the reach of the population in greatest need.

Food fortification is a long-term measure for mitigating specific problems of malnutrition in the community and hence requires a system in place for surveillance and control. 

Food Supplementation is an initiative under the GOBI-FFF scheme. It involves supplementation of whole food, grains, meals, micro and macro-nutrients such as iron and folic acid tablets in pregnancy. It decreases the incidence of low birthweight babies and thereby a fall in the infant mortality rate. 

Components of GOBI FFF are given in the pearl mentioned below.

Related Pearl: GOBI–FFF Strategy

This strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)

  • G – Growth monitoring with growth charts
  • O – Oral rehydration therapy for diarrhoea and dehydration
  • B – Breastfeeding
  • I – Immunization of children
  • F – Family planning and birth spacing
  • F – Food supplementation
  • F ­– Female literacy promotion

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient came to the hospital with the following complaints as shown in the image below. She noticed that these nail changes started appearing 2 months ago. There is no significant occupation history. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing nail pitting and salmon patches in fingernails are characteristic of nail psoriasis.

Nail dystrophy may be associated with all types of psoriasis. They may occasionally be seen as an isolated feature. Nail pitting is the most frequent sign. Nail pitting is formed due to the involvement of the nail matrix.

The subungual oil drop sign or salmon patch is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil. It is a highly specific sign seen in psoriasis and involves the nail bed.

Other options:

Option A: Onychomycosis or Tinea unguium is defined as the infection of the nail plate by dermatophytes. A yellowish discoloration occurs, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail may get separated from its bed. It is shown below.

Option B: Mee’s lines are seen in nails in arsenic poisoning. Mees lines (transverse leukonychia) are single or multiple white transverse bands on the nail. They reflect systemic disorders like arsenic poisoning, thallium poisoning, chemotherapy, or septicemia. 

Option D: Lichen planus is an idiopathic inflammatory skin disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes, following a chronic course with relapses and periods of remission. Nail involvement is in the form of an exaggeration of the longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to slight thinning of the nail plate.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady had a missed abortion and was diagnosed with a partial mole. Which among the following represents its karyotype?
questions.solution:
Image 4 represents a partial mole.

Molar pregnancies arise from chromosomally abnor­mal fertilizations.

Partial moles are formed when two sets of haploid paternal chromosomes fertilize one set of maternal haploid chromosomes. This results in a triploid karyotype (69XX, 69XY, or rarely 69YY). The two sets of paternal chromosomes are contributed by dispermic fertilization or dispermy (two sperms fertilizing one egg).

 

 

Complete moles are formed when an ovum containing inactivated or absent chromosomes gets fertilized by a haploid sperm. The zygote then duplicates after meiosis resulting in a diploid karyotype. Complete moles result from androgenesis, which means that both sets of chromosomes are paternal. Less commonly, the ovum with inactivated or absent chromosomes may be fertilized by two sperms (dispermic fertilization).

 

 

Image 3 in the question represents the normal fertilization of a haploid sperm with a haploid ovum.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male who has been hemorrhaging due to a road traffic accident came to the emergency department. On examination, he had tachycardia, blood pressure of 60/40 mmHg. The attending physician ordered whole blood, however, unfortunately, it was not available in the blood bank. Which of the following would you administer to this patient to prevent shock?
questions.solution:
If the whole blood is not available then, plasma (FFP) transfusion is the recommended replacement therapy to prevent shock due to haemorrhage.

Replacement therapy:

The replacement therapy to prevent shock depends on the cause:

  • Whole blood is transfused in patients with haemorrhage
  • Plasma transfusion is indicated in patients with loss of plasma
  • Electrolyte solution is used for patients with dehydration.

However, in some cases the whole blood may not be available. Then, plasma transfusion is indicated to prevent shock due to hemorrhage.

  • Plasma transfusion increases the volume of blood and restores the haemodynamics.
  • Hematocrit is not restored by plasma transfusion. However, if the cardiac output is adequate, the body can adequately withstand the low levels of haematocrit upto half of the normal value.

If plasma is also not available, the next best approach is to transfuse plasma substitutes such as dextran solution.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents for advice regarding obesity. On multiple occasions over the past 4 months, she has eaten large amounts of food at night and felt disgusted, and guilty after. She is distressed about overeating but states that she can not control it. There is no history of vomiting. Her BMI is 35. Which of the following disorders is responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with a patient having recurrent episodes of uncontrollable binge eating for over 3 months, associated with distress and feelings of guilt in the absence of inappropriate compensatory behavior such as vomiting, is suggestive of binge-eating disorder. It is described as the consumption of unusually large amounts of food over a short period. People with this condition feel that they have no control over their eating. They are also concerned about their weight and eating habits. It is the most common eating disorder.

DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Binge-eating disorder:

A. Recurrent episodes of binge eating. An episode of binge eating is characterized by both the following:

1. Eating, in a discrete period, an amount of food that is larger than what most people would eat in a similar period under similar circumstances.

2. A sense of lack of control over eating during the episode (e.g., a feeling that one cannot stop eating or control what or how much one is eating).

B. The binge-eating episodes are associated with

1. Eating much more rapidly than normal.

2. Eating until feeling uncomfortably full.

3. Eating large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry.

4. Eating alone because of feeling embarrassed by how much one is eating.

5. Feeling disgusted with oneself, depressed, or very guilty afterward.

C. Marked distress regarding binge eating is present.

D. The binge-eating occurs, on average, at least once a week for 3 months.

E. Binge eating is not associated with the recurrent use of inappropriate compensatory behavior as in bulimia nervosa and does not occur exclusively during bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa.

 

Other options:

Bulimia nervosa: People with bulimia nervosa perform compensatory behavior such as vomiting, laxative abuse, or excessive dieting after binge eating. The person maintains a normal BMI.

Night eating disorder: It is characterized by a large amount of food consumption after an evening meal. They generally have a little appetite during the day and suffer from insomnia. They are not overly concerned with their body image and weight and the amount of food consumed is lower than binge eating done in bulimia and binge eating disorders.

Anorexia nervosa: People with Anorexia nervosa are underweight and have an excessive drive for thinness and intense fear of gaining weight.
