questions.text:
Which among the following products are produced by the intestinal bacteria
  1. Lithicholic acid
  2. Phyloquinone
  3. Short chain fatty acids
  4. Deoxycholic acid
  5. Urobilinogen
questions.solution:
Intestinal bacteria produce lithocholic acid, short-chain fatty acids, deoxycholic acid, and urobilinogen.

Role of bacteria

  1. Production of secondary bile acids- Cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid are the primary bile acids produced by the liver. These are converted to deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid by the action of colonic bacteria and are called secondary bile acids.
  2. They also deconjugate bile acids so that the unconjugated ones can be passively absorbed into the portal circulation. Eg. urobilinogen
  3. Formation of short-chain fatty acids- Colonic bacteria act on complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and other components of the dietary fiber present in the intestine into short-chain fatty acids.
  4. It forms menaquinone form of vitamin K in the intestine. Phyloqionone is acquired from the dietary sources.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a dense cataract has been posted for cataract surgery. Since fundus examination was not possible due to dense cataract, the surgeon advises getting an electrophysiological test to assess the retinal function. The record obtained is as shown below. Which of the following waves represent the metabolic activity of pigment epithelium?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a normal electroretinogram(ERG). The metabolic activity of pigment epithelium is represented by a C wave.

Electroretinography (ERG) is the record of changes in the resting potential of the eye induced by the stimulation of a flash of light.

Waves of normal ERG

  • a-wave is a negative wave possibly representing the activity of rods and cones
  • b-wave is a large positive wave that is generated by Muller cells. They represent the activity of the bipolar cells
  • c-wave is a positive wave representing the metabolic activity of pigment epithelium

ERG is used in the diagnosis and prognosis of retinal disorders like retinitis pigmentosa, Leber’s congenital amaurosis, retinal ischemia, and other chorioretinal degenerations.

It helps to assess retinal function when fundus examination is not possible like in the presence of dense cataracts and corneal opacity. It is also used to assess the retinal function of the children where possibilities of impaired vision are considered.

A subnormal B wave is seen in early cases of retinitis pigmentosa. 

An extinguished response is seen when there is complete failure of rod and cone function in advanced retinitis pigmentosa, complete retinal detachment, and central retinal artery occlusion. 

A negative response is seen when there is gross disturbances of retinal circulation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with new-onset seizures. Examination suggests raised intracranial pressure and the fundus is as given below. He had previously been diagnosed with cysts in his kidney. Which of the following intracranial tumors is the most likely cause for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given fundus image shows a retinal hemangioma indicated by the arrow. Retinal hemangioma in a patient with renal cysts and an intracranial tumor is suggestive of Von Hippel–Lindau disease. The associated intracranial tumor with this is Cerebellar hemangioblastoma

  • The major neurologic features of von Hippel–Lindau disease include cerebellar hemangioblastomas and retinal angiomas.
  • Cerebellar hemangioblastomas
    • Are erythropoietin-secreting tumors, which can lead to polycythemia
    • Usually present in early adult life with symptoms and signs of increased intracranial pressure
    • Typically appearing as a cystic cerebellar lesion with a vascular mural nodule on CT or MRI scan
    • Are treated with total surgical removal of the tumor, which is curative
  • Retinal angioma:
    • Small masses of thin-walled capillaries, usually located in the peripheral retina that is fed by large and tortuous arterioles and venules appearing as a fiery red vascular mass
    • Exudation in the region of the angiomas may lead to retinal detachment and visual loss
    • Retinal angiomas are treated with photocoagulation and cryo-coagulation

von Hippel–Lindau disease

  • Arises from an autosomal-dominant mutation of VHL gene on chromosome 3
  • Associations of VHL syndrome:
    • Cystic lesions of kidneys, pancreas, liver, and epididymis
    • Renal cell carcinoma (most common cause of death)
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
    • Retinal angioma

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman developed fever, malaise and a polymorphic rash during the 3rd month of gestation. The characteristic lesions are shown in the image below. Which of following features will not be seen in the infant born to this infected mother?
questions.solution:
The rash with vesicular lesions on an erythematous base is suggestive of varicella infection (Chickenpox) in the pregnant woman, and blueberry muffin rash is not a feature of congenital varicella syndrome.

Congenital varicella syndrome: Fetal varicella infection occurs if the mother gets infected during the first half of pregnancy. Clinical features include:

  • Cicatrix, a zigzag scarring in a dermatomal distribution
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cataracts
  • Cortical atrophy
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microcephaly
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Neurogenic bladder, swallowing dysfunction, and aspiration pneumonia
  • Hydroureter and hydronephrosis

Chickenpox or varicella is caused by the Varicella–zoster virus. Its incubation period is 10 to 21 days. Fever, malaise, anorexia, headache, and occasionally mild abdominal pain may occur 24-48 hr before the rash appears. The rash starts as intensely pruritic, erythematous macules that become papules and finally clear, fluid-filled vesicles. The lesions are polymorphic - simultaneous presence of rashes in various stages of evolution.

It is treated with acyclovir 20 mg/kg/dose for 5 days.

Complications:

  • Cutaneous: Secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin
  • Systemic: Acute cerebella ataxia, encephalitis, pneumonia etc.

Note:

Blueberry muffin rash is seen in congenital rubella syndrome. The rash is shown in the image below.

Congenital rubella syndrome:

    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

  • The rash appears on day 1

  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted to the hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed diarrhea and abdominal pain. Her temperature was 38.8 degrees Celcius. Her blood reports are given below. What is the most probable etiological agent?
  • Hemoglobin- 12 g/dL
  • WBC count of 18,000/mm3
  • CRP of 160 mg/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with hospital-acquired diarrhea (nosocomial) following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridium difficile. 

Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of infectious diarrhea in nosocomial infection. 

It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • Lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • Fever, leukocytosis
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis

Investigations:

  • Nucleic acid amplification tests, including polymerase chain reaction assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool 
  • Stool culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating toxin by cell cytotoxin cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy reveals a characteristic pseudomembrane.

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool, have now been approved for diagnostic purposes and appear to be both rapid and sensitive while retaining high specificity.

Oral vancomycin, metronidazole, and fidaxomicin are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

First choice treatment of C. difficile colitis:

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral vancomycin OR fidaxomicin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline) Oral vancomycin OR fidaxomicin
Severe, complicated (shock, ileus, toxic megacolon) Oral vancomycin + IV metronidazole ± Rectal vancomycin
Recurrent/ multiple episodes Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT)

Recent update: Harrison's 20th edition recommends the use of vancomycin over metronidazole in the treatment of initial episodes which are mild to moderate in severity. Metronidazole is recommended only if vancomycin or fidaxomicin is not accessible. Oral metronidazole is less effective than the other options and may necessitate a longer treatment course for a response.

Other options: Escherichia coli, Norovirus, Rotavirus are all causes of Traveller's diarrhea.

Other causes of Nosocomial diarrhea:

  • Clostridium perfringens,
  • Klebsiella oxytoca,
  • Staphylococcus aureus.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text:
A baby was born at 33 weeks of gestation by cesarean delivery. After 3 hours he was found to have cyanosis, tachypnea, and grunting. Auscultation revealed decreased air entry into the lungs. Chest radiograph was performed and it showed the following finding. Which of the following is true regarding the substance that is deficient in this baby?
  1. It is produced mainly by type I alveolar cells
  2. It contains phosphatidylcholine
  3. It also prevents pulmonary oedema
  4. Ceramide is the main component
  5. Steroids increase its production
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, and 5 are true regarding surfactant.

A preterm baby is showing features of respiratory distress along with the radiograph showing increased homogenous opacification of the lungs. This is suggestive of respiratory distress syndrome which occurs due to the deficiency of surfactant. 

Surfactant lines the alveoli of the lungs. It is secreted by the type II alveolar epithelial cells. It contains phospholipids, triglycerides, cholesterol, and fatty acids. Phosphatidylcholine is the major phospholipid. Other phospholipids are phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine (PE), sphingomyelin (SM), phosphatidylinositol (PI), and phosphatidylserine. Ceramide is not a major component of surfactants. Important proteins are surfactant protein (SP)- A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

The important function is to reduce the surface tension of the alveoli. The pressure required for the expansion of alveoli is directly proportional to the surface tension present over the alveolar sacs. Surfactant reduces this surface tension and thereby reduces the pressure required to expand lungs. It also prevents pulmonary oedema.

Surfactant production starts around 20 weeks of life and peaks at 35 weeks gestation. Therefore, any neonate less than 35 weeks is prone to develop RDS.

 Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS):

RDS is common in preterm babies less than 34 weeks of gestation. It occurs due to the deficiency of the surfactant in the alveoli. Decreased surfactant increases the surface tension over the alveoli which makes the alveoli to collapse easily. Therefore, the baby has to put more effort to expand the lungs. This results in respiratory distress and hypoxemia. Ischemic damage to the alveoli causes the transudation of proteins into the alveoli that form the hyaline membrane.

It usually occurs in the first few hours of life. The babies will have tachypnea, grunting, retractions, cyanosis and decreased air entry. Chest radiograph will show reticulogranular pattern, ground-glass opacity, low lung volume, air bronchogram and white-out lungs in severe disease.

Mild to moderate RDS can be managed with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). CPAP is a noninvasive modality of support where a continuous distending pressure (5-7 cm H20) is applied at the nostril level to keep the alveoli open in a spontaneously breathing baby. Severe cases will require mechanical ventilation.

Steroids increase the production of the surfactant and therefore steroids are administered antenatally to mothers with preterm labour.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis is as shown. What is the most probable underlying acid-base disorder?

pH- 7.24

pCO2- 60 mmHg

pO2- 52 mmHg

HCO3- - 27 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change.

Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis. 

Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula:

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 X Δ PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the patient is not acute)

Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L

Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L.

The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also.

But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate is being evaluated for severe generalised edema. On examination, his blood pressure is within normal limits. Investigations revealed hypoalbuminemia and hemoglobin of 14 gm/dL. Urine analysis showed foamy urine and protein 4+. What is the most likely cause of this patient's edema?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a 1-day-old baby with generalized edema along with proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia points toward congenital nephrotic syndrome.

Nephrotic syndrome manifesting at birth or within 3 months of life is termed congenital nephrotic syndrome. It may be:

  • Primary - due to inherited disorders caused by mutations in NPHS 1, NPHS 2, WT1, or LAMB2.
  • Secondary - due to in-utero infections like cytomegalovirus infection, toxoplasmosis, syphilis, HIV infection, hepatitis B virus or hepatitis C virus HCV infection, infantile systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), or mercury exposure.

Infants with congenital nephrotic syndrome most commonly present at birth with edema caused by massive proteinuria, and they are typically delivered with an enlarged placenta.

Severe hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and hypogammaglobulinemia occur due to the loss of filtering selectivity at the glomerular filtration barrier. 

The presence of elevated maternal and amniotic α-fetoprotein levels helps in prenatal diagnosis. A diagnosis of congenital nephrotic syndrome is made clinically in newborns or infants who demonstrate severe generalized edema, poor growth, and nutrition along with hypoalbuminemia, increased susceptibility to infections, hypothyroidism (from urinary loss of thyroxin-binding globulin), and increased risk of thrombotic events.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with nephritic syndrome classically present with tea- or cola-coloured urine due to hematuria, edema, hypertension, and oliguria. 

Option C: Neonatal haemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is characterized by a triad of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and impairment of renal function. It usually presents with severe anemia within a few hours after birth and progressively develops acute renal failure.

Option D: Hydrops fetalis can occur due to Rh incompatibility or other various non-immune causes ( infective causes include syphilis, parvovirus B19 infection, and intrauterine TORCH infections). These babies present with severe anemia.

questions.text: A young female patient is undergoing evaluation for infertility. The gynecologist collects the cervical mucus and spreads it on the microscope. It shows the following appearance. The patient had her periods 22 days back. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient?

choices.text: This finding occurs due to progesterone
She is in mid luteal phase

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding this patient is that she has not ovulated. The presence of a fern pattern of cervical mucus on the 22nd day of her menstrual cycle indicates that she has not ovulated. 

Estrogen makes the cervical mucus thinner and more alkaline to promote easy survival and transport of sperm. When the mucus is spread on the slide, it shows the fern pattern. After ovulation and during pregnancy, the levels of progesterone rise and this hormone makes the cervical mucus thick. The ferning pattern will no longer be seen. 

The mucus is thinnest at the time of ovulation due to the increased levels of estrogen. It can be stretched into a long, thin thread that may be 8–12 cm or more in length. This is called the spinnbarkeit phenomenon.

Before ovulation, the phase is known as the preovulatory phase or the follicular phase of the cycle. The uterus is undergoing proliferative changes, hence it is also known as the proliferative phase. After ovulation occurs, the corpus luteum secretes estrogen and progesterone and this phase is known as the luteal phase or secretory phase. In this phase, the uterus is vascular, and edematous with coiled glands.

 The tests for ovulation are:

  • The body temperature decreases during ovulation and increases by 1/2 to 1°F. This is due to the thermogenic action of the progesterone.
  • Endometrial biopsy- usually done 1-2 days before menstruation. The presence of secretory changes in the endometrium suggests that ovulation has occurred. 
  • Fern test- The appearance of a fern pattern is seen before ovulation. After ovulation, the progesterone thickens the cervical mucus leading to the loss of fern pattern.
  • Ultrasound- used to monitor the maturation of the Graffian follicle and ovulation.
  • Hormonal studies - Increased levels of plasma progesterone (~15 ng/mL) in the mid-luteal phase (22–23rd day) suggest that ovulation has occurred and determination of LH surge.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old female presents with painless haematuria. She has a travel history to Egypt a few weeks back. Urine microscopy revealed the following structure. Which of the following stage is not seen in the life cycle of the causative organism?
  1. Cercaria 
  2. Metacercaria 
  3. Miracidia
  4. Redia
questions.solution:
Eggs with a terminal spine and a history of painless hematuria are suggestive of infection with Schistosoma haematobium. Metacercaria and redia stages are not seen in schistosomes.  Metacercaria and redia are seen in trematodes such as Fasciola hepatica, Fasciola buski, Clonorchis sinensis.

Schistosoma haematobium is characterized by ovoid non-operculated eggs with a brownish-yellow transparent shell and a characteristic terminal spine at one of the poles.

Schistosoma haematobium primarily causes genito-urinary schistosomiasis. The adult worms live in the veins of the urinary bladder.

Cercaria larva are the infective form of schistosomes. Cercaria infects man by penetrating the skin which can lead to intense irritation and skin rash at the site of cercarial penetration (known as swimmer's itch).

After penetrating the skin, the cercariae lose their tails and become schistosomulae which travel through peripheral venules to the systemic circulation, to the inferior mesenteric veins, finally reaching the vesical and pelvic venous plexuses, where they mature and lay eggs. The eggs that are passed in urine are embryonated and hatch in water under suitable conditions to release the free-living ciliated miracidia.

Miracidia penetrates into the tissues of the snail and reaches its liver. Inside the snail, first and second-generation sporocyst stages are seen. Large numbers of cercariae are produced by asexual reproduction within the second-generation sporocysts and are released into the water. Metacercaria and redia stages are not seen in schistosomes.

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis.

The following are the unique features distinguishing schistosomes from other trematodes:

  • Only one intermediate host
  • They produce non- operculated eggs.
  • They have no redia stage in larval development
  • Mode of infection is by penetration of intact skin with the help of forked tails of cercariae

NOTE: 

Infective forms of most trematodes (Eg. Fasciola hepatica, Fasciola buski, Clonorchis sinensis) to humans are metacercaria larva.

Species differentiation of Schistosoma can be done based on the location of the spine on their eggs as follows.

  • Terminal spine: Schistosoma hematobium
  • Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni
  • Round with small lateral knob or Rudimentary spine: Schistosoma japonicum.

questions.text: What is the modified shock index of a patient who has a heart rate of 105 beats/min, systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 90 mmHg, and mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 70 mm Hg?
questions.solution:
The Modified shock index = HR/MAP = 105/70 = 1.5  

The shock index is a hemodynamic stability indicator. In patients with shock, it is a better predictor of mortality than blood pressure or heart rate alone. A shock index >0.9 is indicative of higher mortality.

Original shock index = HR/SBP 

The original shock index does not include the diastolic blood pressure (DBP) which is why the modified shock index was developed. The modified shock index is a more sensitive indicator of tissue perfusion than the original shock index. In critically ill patients, the DBP decreases earlier than SBP, hence, the modified shock index using MAP is better suited to assess the severity of shock.

questions.text:
A drug is instilled into the right eye of the rabbit, and the left eye is used as the control. The findings obtained after some time are shown in the table and image given below.
Reflex Right eye Left eye
Corneal reflex Present Present
Light reflex Absent Present

Which of the following drugs is likely to have been instilled?
questions.solution:
On instillation of the drug, there is mydriasis in the eye and loss of light reflex. The drug is likely to be atropine. It is an anticholinergic agent. It causes mydriasis, cycloplegia, loss of light reflex, and impaired accommodation.

Autonomic supply of the eye:

The radial muscle of the iris is controlled by α1 adrenergic receptor. Stimulation of this receptor causes mydriasis. 

The sphincter muscle of the iris is controlled by the M3 and M2 cholinergic receptors. Stimulation of these receptors causes miosis.

The ciliary muscle is supplied by the β2 adrenergic receptors as well as M3 and M2 cholinergic receptors. The β2 receptors cause relaxation of the ciliary muscle, which helps in far vision, while M3 and M2 receptors cause contraction of the ciliary muscle, which helps in near vision.

Lacrimal glands are supplied by the α receptors and M3 and M2 receptors. They increase lacrimal secretion.

questions.text: The maximum dose of PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage is ____.
questions.solution:
The maximum dose of prostaglandin F2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg.

Prostaglandins are paracrine/autocrine hormones and act locally at the site of production. Main sources for:

  1. PGF2α  - Decidua and promotes myometrial contractility
  2. PGE2 - fetal membranes (amnion) and induces labor and promotes cervical effacement and dilatation
  3. PGI2 - Myometrium 

Carboprost tromethamine (hemabate) is the 15-methyl derivative of prostaglandin F2 alpha. It is approved for the treatment of uterine atony at a dose of 0.25 mg IM. This dose can be repeated if necessary at 15- to 90-minute intervals up to a maximum of eight doses (2 mg).

It is the best drug to control PPH. ls also used an abortifacient in the second trimester.

Contraindications include asthmatic women and those with suspected amniotic fluid embolism, as they cause pulmonary airway and vascular constriction.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain and severe non-bilious vomiting. He was treated for severe upper abdominal pain 5 weeks ago.  CT scan shows a 7cm lesion near the pancreas. The diagnosis of a pancreatic pseudocyst in close proximity to the stomach with secondary pressure effects is made.  What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient would be to perform a cystogastrostomy since the size of the tumor is greater than 6 cm and in close proximity to the stomach.

Interventions in pseudocyst are required when:

  • Complicated by infection
  • Presence of a mass effect 
  • Diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm
  • Recurrence following the previous resection

Pancreatic pseudocysts are fluid-filled oval or round collections encapsulated in a relatively thick wall. They develop 4 weeks after acute pancreatitis and are frequently found on imaging during follow-up. The capsule of a pseudocyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. Hence, it is called a pseudocyst.

They may be asymptomatic or become large enough to cause mass effects such as gastric outlet obstruction, bowel obstruction, hydronephrosis, and biliary obstruction. They can present with an epigastric mass, pain abdomen, early satiety, nausea, and vomiting. Abdominal pain is the most common symptom.

Characteristic features of pancreatic pseudo­cysts include high amylase levels associated with the absence of mucin and low serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels.

Observation is the preferred treatment in:

  • Asymptomatic patients
  • Pseudocysts smaller than 4 cm in diameter (6 cm according to Bailey)
  • Located on the tail
  • No evidence of pancreatic duct obstruction or communication with the main pancreatic duct

Endoscopic drainage is usually curative and surgical drainage is done if endoscopy is contraindicated or if:

  • In close contact with the stomach: Cystogastrostomy
  • In close contact with the duodenum: Cystoduodenostomy

In cystogastrostomy, an anterior gastrostomy is performed. Once the pseudocyst is located, it is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach using a linear stapler. The defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers.

The image below shows the procedure involved in a cystogastrostomy-


Other options:

Roux-en-Y Cystojejunostomy (Option-B) is generally done for cysts that are neither in close proximity to the stomach nor to the duodenum.

Observation and symptomatic management (Option-D) cannot be the line of management for a case of pancreatic pseudocyst of size more than 6cm and especially when the patient has symptoms secondary to gastric obstruction.  

Percutaneous drainage (Option-C) to the exterior under radiological guidance is associated with a high recurrence rate and high incidence of pancreatic-cutaneous fistula. Hence, it is done only in septic patients with infected pseudocyst fluid.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy who is a football player comes to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football on the ground. There is no history of trauma or fall. He also gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding and also unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast enhanced CT scan of the head is taken which is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the Antral sign or Holman Miller sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here the tumour grows into the:

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

OTHER OPTIONS:

Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumour mass in glomus tumour, when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum. 

Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus - Antral sign or Holman Miller sign.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with a penetrating injury to his left eye for which he was treated with corneoscleral suturing and discharged a week later. He returns 2 months later complaining of diminished vision, associated with redness, pain, and photophobia in the right eye. Direct ophthalmoscopy revealed discrete yellow-white nodules in the fundus. He was treated with prednisolone but showed no improvement. How will you manage this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical case is suggestive of Sympathetic ophthalmitis, not responding to steroids for which immunosuppressive agents such as oral cyclosporin A may be used.

Sympathetic Ophthalmitis (SO) is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis occurring after penetrating trauma which usually begins 4–8 weeks after the injury to the eye (the exciting eye). It can also develop after surgeries, proton beam irradiation, Nd: YAG photocoagulation, and cryotherapy. It is an delayed hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T cells.

The exciting eye is often red and irritable, and the sympathizing eye may develop irritation, blurred vision, photophobia, and loss of accommodation.

Fundoscopy:

  • Multifocal choroidal infiltrates
  • Infiltrates corresponding to Dalen–Fuchs nodules are seen below the retinal pigment epithelium
  • Exudative retinal detachment, vasculitis, and optic disc swelling
  • Residual chorioretinal scarring gives a sunset glow appearance when the inflammation settles

Treatment :

  • Steroids are the basis of treatment.
    • High-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months.
    • Supplementary topical steroids and cycloplegics for anterior uveitis
    • Periocular and intraocular steroids, slow-release intravitreal implants may also be used
  • Immunosuppressives such as azathioprine, cyclosporin, and methotrexate are used in resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents. 
  • Enucleation of an eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury prevents the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmitis.

questions.text:
Which of the following structures are derived from the 4th aortic arch?
  1. Arch of aorta
  2. Pulmonary artery
  3. Brachiocephalic artery
  4. Right Subclavian artery
  5. Left Subclavian artery
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1 and 4 only.

The 4th aortic arch persists on both sides and forms different structures on either side:

  • Left side: Part of the arch of aorta between the left common carotid and the left subclavian arteries
  • Right side: Proximal segment of the right subclavian artery

The proximal part of the right subclavian artery is derived from the right 4th aortic arch. The distal segment of the right subclavian artery is derived from the right dorsal aorta and the 7th intersegmental artery.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the dermatology clinic with the following lesions over both the legs. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the given disease?

choices.text: Linear deposits of IgA at the dermal-epidermal junction
The major target antigen is the ectodomain of BP210
Cluster of jewels sign is not pathognomic to this disease
Dapsone and corticosteroids are part of the first line treatment

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 4-year old child with the lesions shown in the given image in a ‘string of pearls’ or ‘cluster of jewels’ sign, is characteristic of linear IgA disease. The main target antigens seen in this disease are BP180 and BPAg2.

Linear IgA disease/chronic bullous disorder of childhood (CBDC) is an immunobullous disease of childhood that clinically can present as an annular arrangement of vesicles. It arises more abruptly in children compared to adults. It has a bimodal onset, below the age of 5 years and between the age of 60 - 65 years.

Clinical features include:

  • Mucous membrane lesions like oral erosions and ulcers are commonly seen. Nasal crusting and genital lesions may also occur.
  • Tense blisters, vesicles and annular erythema are the characteristic triad of clinical features.
  • The blisters are arranged in a circular fashion, resembling a crown/cluster of jewels or a string of pearls appearance.
  • In young children, the distribution of lesions is perioral, perianal, and perineum.
  • In adults, the distribution is over the extensors and the trunk.

Note: The ‘string of pearls’ or ‘cluster of jewels’ sign, is characteristic of linear IgA disease and not pathognomic to this disease. 

The image below shows a string of pearls appearance in the Linear IgA disease.

Precipitating factors include:

  • Infections
  • Trauma
  • Vaccination
  • UV radiation exposure
  • Drugs like:
    • Vancomycin
    • Penicillin
    • NSAIDs

The main target antigens in this disease are BP180 and BPAg2 much more than BP230 or BPAg1.The mechanism of blister formation is due to the subepidermal splitting and neutrophilic infiltrate in the papillary dermis forming microabscesses. 

The image given below shows subepidermal blister formation and neutrophils infiltrate in the papillary dermis.

The diagnostic hallmark is the linear deposition of IgA deposits at DEJ identified by direct immunofluorescence.

Management involves:

  • First line:
    • Dapsone
    • Topical steroids with or without prednisolone
  • Second line:
    • Sulfa drugs like Sulfapyridine/ sulphamethoxypyridazine being alternatives for dapsone.
    • Anti‐inflammatory antibiotics like oxytetracycline, doxycycline with or without nicotinamide
  • Third line:
    • Mycophenolate
    • IVIG
    • Immunoadsorption

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with a history of amenorrhea and leakage of greyish white fluid from both her breasts for 2 months. The pregnancy test is negative. She used to have normal periods a few months back. She gives a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease that is refractory to proton pump inhibitors. On examination, no lump or tenderness is present on both breasts. MRI and lab findings of the patient are shown. Which gene mutation is responsible for this patient's condition?

Vitals and labs:

BP: 120/80 mm Hg

Pulse: 80/min

Temp: 99 F

Serum Ca: 13 mg/dl
questions.solution:
This patient features of pituitary adenoma (MRI scan shows adenoma and features are suggestive of prolactinoma), GERD refractory to PPIs (suggestive of gastrinoma), and high serum calcium (suggestive of parathyroid adenoma) point towards multiple endocrine neoplasia 1 syndrome (MEN) due to a loss of function mutation of MEN1 which codes for menin, a tumor suppressor gene.

Mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene lead to MEN 1, also called Wermer syndrome.  It is characterized by

  • Parathyroid hyperplasia or adenoma
  • Pancreas - endocrine tumors
  • Pituitary - the most common anterior pituitary tumor is prolactinoma

MEN type 2 is classified into MEN 2A and MEN 2B. 

MEN 2A is also called Sipple syndrome and characterized by

  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia.

MEN 2B is characterized by

  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Pheochromocytoma.
  • Mucosal neuromas of lips and tongue, intestinal ganglioneuromas, marfanoid habitus, and lax joints.
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia is absent. 

p53 tumor suppressor gene mutations can lead to Li Fraumeni syndrome. This is an autosomal dominant hereditary cancer disorder. Patients develop multiple cancers at a young age such as sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, and leukemias.

  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with intermittent hematuria and pain in the left flank. He is a chronic smoker and is under medications for hypertension. On examination, the patient appears weak and has a palpable mass in the left flank. His hemoglobin level is found to be 16.5 g/dl. Which of the following mutation will not lead to the condition that the patient has?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario (hematuria, palpable mass, flank pain along with polycythemia) is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). MSH2 mutation is not associated with RCC.

Renal cell carcinoma can be sporadic or inherited. Various mutations are implicated in familial cancers. The most common mutation is VHL mutation (clear cell RCC).

Other mutations that can cause renal cell carcinoma include MET mutation (Papillary type RCC), BHD mutation (Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome), Xp11 translocation (a subtype that occurs in young patients due to overexpression of TFE3 transcription factor).

MSH2 mutation results in DNA mismatch repair which causes colon cancers including familial hereditary nonpolyposis colon carcinoma and endometrial cancers.

questions.text:
Which of the statements are true about biomedical waste disposal in COVID-19?
  1. Vacutainers, Eppendorf tubes, and pipettes are disposed of in the yellow bin 
  2. Bags containing general waste are sprayed with 0.5% sodium hypochlorite solution before disposal
  3. The Hazmat suit and N95 masks are disposed of in the red bin
  4. Yellow bags should not be used to dispose of general solid waste 
  5. Masks from crematorium staff are collected and stored in bins for 72 hours before disposal as dry general solid waste.
questions.solution:
Yellow bags should not be used to dispose of general solid waste. General solid waste is to be collected and handed to the municipal waste collector. In the hospital, general solid waste is disposed of in black-colored bags. 

Masks from crematorium staff are collected and stored in bins for 72 hours prior to disposal as dry general solid waste. 

Vacutainers, Eppendorf tubes, and pippetes are disposed of in the red bin.

Bags containing general waste are sprayed with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution prior to disposal.

The Hazmat suit is disposed of in the red bin, and N95 masks are disposed of in the yellow bin.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic at 17 weeks of gestational age with a history of a lump in her left breast for the past 3 months. On examination, you find a lump of 2 X 2 cm in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. Which of the following investigations would you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present with a breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and can detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes.

USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 40 years) since breast tissue is dense in these populations.

Other options:

Option A) Mammography is less useful in young women due to the increased density of breast tissue.

Option B) MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in high risk cases where metastasis or spread to other breast is suspected.

Option D) Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not recommended in pregnant women. It is difficult to distinguish breast cancer from the normal cellular proliferation in the breast tissue due to hormonal changes.

questions.text:
Match the objective of each phase of a clinical trial with the phase.

    Column I                                                                               

  1. Indications are finalized and guidelines formulated                
  2. Drug interactions and long-term adverse effects assessed     
  3. Efficacy and dose-ranging are determined                               
  4. Assessment of safety and tolerability

    Column II

    A. Phase I

    B. Phase II

    C. Phase III

    D. Phase IV
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1- C, 2-D, 3-B, and 4-A.

The phases of a clinical trial and their objectives are as given below.

Phase 1 (first in humans) is carried out in 10-100 participants. It aims to test the safety and tolerability of the drug. Usually, healthy volunteers are chosen. Sometimes patients with an advanced or rare disease are also considered. It generally lasts for 1-2 years.

Phase 2 (first in patients) checks the efficacy and dose-ranging of the drug. 50-500 patient subjects receive the experimental drug. It lasts for 2-3 years.

Phase 3 (multisite trial) is carried out for confirmation of the efficacy tested in phase 2. The indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. A few hundred to a few thousand patient subjects receive the drug. It lasts for around 3-5 years.

Phase 4 (postmarketing surveillance) tests for adverse effects, or those that occur only after long-term use and drug interactions. It is done in patients already on treatment with the approved drug. There is no fixed duration for this stage.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: At an ophthalmology clinic, you witness the doctor covering one eye of the patient and asking the patient to read the smallest line on the near chart. He then shines a bright light into the eye for 15 seconds and asks the patient to read the same line, noting down the time taken for the patient to recover and read. He repeats the same with the other eye. Choose the correct statement about the test performed.

choices.text: Recovery time is prolonged in macular disease
Recovery time is delayed in normal individuals
Prolonged recovery time in those with optic nerve pathology
Normal recovery time in macular disease

questions.solution:
The test described above is the photostress test, and recovery time is prolonged in macular diseases.

The photostress test is used to differentiate between the disease involving the macula and optic nerve. In this test, one eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart. A bright light is then shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again, and the time taken to recover is noted. The test is repeated with the other eye.

In normal persons and in patients with optic nerve disease, the recovery time is not affected. Whereas, in patients with macular disease the recovery time is prolonged and is usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time. This is because, in macular disease, the photoreceptors are damaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process.

The test is of particular use in an early macular disease like central serous retinopathy.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought to the outpatient department for a facial defect. On examination, the following findings were noticed. The soft and the hard palate are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this child?

choices.text: Cleft lip repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a child with a cleft lip on the left side. The most appropriate management for this patient would be a cleft lip repair at 4-6 months.

Etiology of the cleft lip can include familial, protein and vitamin deficiency, rubella infection, radiation, chromosomal abnormalities, maternal epilepsy and drug intake during pregnancy (steroids/eptoin/diazepam)

Majority of the cases are unilateral and cleft lip alone is uncommon.

Millard Criteria (Rule of 10) is used to undertake surgery for cleft lip.

  • 10 pound in weight
  • 10 weeks old
  • 10g% Hemoglobin

Millard cleft lip repair by rotating the local nasolabial flaps is done.

The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months. 

According to Delaire timing of cleft surgery - unilateral cleft lip alone can be operated in one stage operation and is done at 4-6 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for hypertension. She is a known case of Type 2 Diabetes mellitus which is controlled with diet and exercise. She is currently on Furosemide, Amlodipine, and Telmisartan. Her hypertension is only partially responsive to medications. She has peripheral edema along with muscle weakness. Her ECG findings are shown. Which screening test is to be done for this patient's condition?

Vitals and Labs:

BP:170/120

Pulse: 70/min

Temp: 98.9 F

Serum K: 2.4 mmol/L

Serum Na: 140 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of weakness, low potassium, edema, and hypertension refractory to 3 medications are suggestive of Primary Hyperaldosteronism.

ECG features of low potassium are:

  • Increased P wave amplitude
  • Prolongation of the PR interval
  • Widespread ST depression and T wave flattening/inversion
  • Prominent U waves (best seen in the precordial leads V2-V3)

Excess aldosterone leads to increased sodium and water retention and potassium excretion resulting in hypokalemia, volume expansion, and hypertension. Serum sodium tends to be normal due to concurrent fluid retention. 

Diagnostic screening for mineralocorticoid excess is not currently recommended for all patients with hypertension. It is advised in those who exhibit hypertension associated with drug resistance, hypokalemia, an adrenal mass, or onset of disease before the age of 40 years.

The accepted screening test is the concurrent measurement of plasma renin and aldosterone with subsequent calculation of the aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR); serum potassium needs to be normalized before testing. ARR screening is positive if the ratio is >750 pmol/L per ng/mL per hour, with a concurrently high normal or increased aldosterone.

Diagnostic confirmation is done by saline infusion test, which involves the IV administration of 2 L of physiologic saline over a 4-hour period. Failure of aldosterone to suppress <140 pmol/L (5 ng/dL) is indicative of autonomous mineralocorticoid excess. Alternative tests:

  • oral sodium loading test (300 mmol NaCl/d for 3 days)
  • fludrocortisone suppression test (0.1 mg q6h with 30 mmol NaCl q8h for 4 days).

If plasma aldosterone concentration is more than >10 ng/ml after saline infusion test is suggestive of primary hyperaldosteronism. This has to be followed with a CT scan to find out the cause which may be bilateral adrenal hyperplasia or unilateral adenoma (Conn syndrome).

Resistant hypertension is defined by high blood pressure despite using three antihypertensive drug classes at maximum doses, often including a calcium channel blocker, a renin-angiotensin system blocker, and a diuretic. It may also apply to patients needing four or more medications to reach target blood pressure. 

Other Options:

Option A: Adrenal Vein Sampling is done before surgery to know which side is hyperactive.

Option C: The saline infusion test is the confirmatory test done if ARR is positive.

Option D: A CT Scan is used to find the cause after the diagnosis is established. It is not used as a screening test.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old male came to the emergency department because of fatigue and black tarry stools for the past 4 days. He also complains about weight loss over the last few months. There is a history of multiple epistaxis episodes for the past few weeks. He is a known case of Polycystic kidney disease and hypertension. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide, valsartan and furosemide. He also takes occasional NSAIDs for his joint pains. He neither smokes nor drinks. On physical examination, he appears thin and tired. The presence of pallor and excoriations on the legs is seen. Abdominal examination is normal. There is flapping of wrists when they are extended. What is the cause of this patient's bleeding?

Vitals and Labs:

BP: 110/70 mm of Hg

Pulse: 80 bpm

Temp 98.2 F

Hb: 9 gm/dl

Platelet: 1,10,000/mm3

MCV: 86

Bleeding time (BT): 10 min

Prothrombin time (PT): 13 sec

Partial Thromboplastin Time (PTT): 32 sec

Serum creatine: 7 mg/dl
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of uremia in the setting of kidney disease. 

The GI bleeding of this patient is most likely due to uremic platelet dysfunction in the setting of normal lab findings (normal PT, PTT, and platelet count) except increased bleeding time. It is multifactorial, but the resultant effect is defective platelet adhesion and activation. 

Uremia is defined as the accumulation of toxic substances due to decreased renal function.

Symptoms include:

  • Fatigue
  • weakness
  • nausea and vomiting
  • loss of appetite
  • Uremic fetor(ammonia-like breath)
  • Pruritis
  • Asterixis (flapping tremors)
  • Encephalopathy
  • Hematological symptoms include:
    • anemia(due to increased destruction as well as decreased production)
    • Increased bleeding tendency ( platelet dysfunction)
    • Increased infections due to leukocyte dysfunction.

Platelet function improves after the toxins are removed via dialysis.

Other Options:

Acquired factor VII deficiency: It will occur in liver failure, not in kidney failure. The polycystic disease also affects the liver but other lab values to support this diagnosis (prolonged PT) are not there.

Inhibition of COX enzymes: NSAIDs can cause GI bleeding but this patient's history of occasional intake is not sufficient to produce melena.

Impaired production of Thrombopoietin: It is also seen generally in liver failure because thrombopoietin is produced mainly in the liver.

questions.text: A young woman who is diagnosed with drug-sensitive tuberculosis is started with isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide. During the follow up it is found that she has light chain proteinuria. Which of the drugs could have been the cause?
questions.solution:
Light chain proteinuria is caused by rifampicin.

Rifampicin inhibits bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase and thereby inhibits RNA synthesis. resistance to this drug results from the mutation of rpoB gene.

It is bactericidal in nature and can kill organisms that are present intracellularly or in abscesses and cavities.

It can be used against the infections of mycobacterium, meningococcus, Hemophilus influenzae, etc.

Important adverse effects of rifampicin are

  • Flu-like symptoms
  • Imparts orange color to urine, sweat, and tears.
  • Light chain proteinuria
  • Hepatitis
  • Cholestatic jaundice
  • Rashes
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Nephritis

It induces most cytochrome P450 isoforms and increases the elimination of methadone, anticoagulants, cyclosporine, some anticonvulsants, protease inhibitors, some nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors or integrase inhibitors, contraceptives, etc.

Other options

Option A- Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis by inhibiting the enzyme beta-ketoacyl carrier protein synthetase. Important side effects of this drug are:

  • Fever, skin rashes
  • Drug-induced lupus
  • Isoniazid induced hepatitis
  • Peripheral neuropathy occurs as a result of pyridoxine deficiency. Isoniazid promotes pyridoxine excretion. It is likely to be seen in slow acetylators.

Option B- Pyrazinamide is converted to pyrazinoic acid. This disrupts the mycobacterial cell membrane metabolism and transport functions. Important side effects of this drug are:

  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Fever
  • Photosensitivity 
  • Hyperuricemia

Option C- Ethambutol inhibits mycobacterial cell wall synthesis by inhibiting mycobacterial arabinosyl transferases. An important side effect of this drugs is retrobulbar neuritis, resulting in loss of visual acuity and red-green color blindness.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient comes to the hospital with left lower abdominal pain which radiates to the back. He also complains of increased bowel movements, nausea, fever on and off for 2 weeks, and bloody stool occasionally. On examination, the abdomen is tender and rigid. A barium enema was performed and showed a partial filling of the lumen which has a sawtooth appearance. The classification used to describe the severity of the condition is ______.
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an elderly male patient with left lower abdominal pain radiating to the back, increased bowel movements, on-and-off fever occasional bloody stools, and sawtooth appearance on barium enema is likely to have diverticular disease. The tender and rigid abdomen suggest a perforation. The classification system used to describe the severity of such a condition is the Hinchey classification.

The Hinchey classification system is commonly used to describe the severity of diverticular disease complicated by perforation and is an additional tool that may be used to guide overall management. It consists of:

  • Stage I: Small, confined pericolic or mesenteric abscess
  • Stage II: Larger, walled-off pelvic abscess
  • Stage III: Generalized purulent peritonitis
  • Stage IV: Generalized fecal peritonitis

Diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. Colonic diverticulosis is primarily false diverticula as only the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated. They occur due to increased intraluminal pressure and thus are a pulsion type of diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common location.

The majority of patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic or present with distension, flatulence, and a sensation of heaviness in the lower abdomen.

The diagnosis is confirmed by a colonoscopy or an X-ray barium enema. The barium enema radiograph shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth (image below). In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

A high-fiber diet reduces the incidence of diverticulosis. Antispasmodics can be prescribed to reduce intestinal spasms. Most cases of bleeding are self-limiting. If persistent bleeding is present, surgical, endoscopic, or radiological interventions can be done to reduce the bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: Shimada classification describes neuroblastoma as either favorable or unfavorable histology based on the degree of differentiation, the mitosis–karyorrhexis index, and the presence or absence of Schwannian stroma.

Option C: Forrest classification is used for endoscopic findings and rebleeding risks in peptic ulcer disease.

Option D: Bismuth-Corlette classification is used for bile duct tumors.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient presents to the ENT outpatient department with decreased hearing in both ears, often associated with a ringing sensation for the past few years.  The Rinne test was negative and the Schwartze sign is seen on otoscopy. Which of the following will be seen in her tympanometry?
questions.solution:
The clinical history, negative Rinne test and positive Schwartze sign is seen in active otosclerosis. Tympanometry will show low compliance near ambient air pressure (As) graph in this case.

Tympanogram is a measure of the Tympanic membrane’s compliance or deflection to change in pressure. There are 5 types of graphs seen:

  • A: Normal individuals. It is the most common graph in the general population. 
  • As: Seen in otosclerosis/Thick TM.
  • Ad: Seen in ossicular discontinuity/Thin TM.
  • B: Seen in perforation of TM
  • C: Eustachian tube Obstruction

Otosclerosis is bony overgrowth involving the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It Is known to worsen during stress & hormonal variations like during pregnancy, menopause.

An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis Willisii.

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne (i.e. BC > AC).

Tympanometry shows As type of curve indicates that the pressure is normal but compliance is reduced. Pure tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz knows as Carhart's notch. 

Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

Stapedial reflex: As the otosclerosis matures, the stapes footplate gets fixed and becomes immobile. Therefore, the stapedial reflex is lost.

 

 
 

 

A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile.

questions.text:
A plastic surgeon is planning a split-skin grafting procedure. Arrange the following phases in the correct order during the take of the graft?
  1. Neovascularization
  2. Imbibition
  3. Adherence
  4. Inosculation
questions.solution:
The correct order of phases during the take of a split skin graft at a recipient site is: imbibition → inosculation → neovascularization → adherence.

During the first 48 hours following the placement of the graft on the recipient site, the graft survives by getting nourishment from the plasma exudate from the capillaries of the recipient bed. This is known as imbibition or plasmatic circulation. After 48 hours, the cut-ends of the blood vessels of both the graft and the recipient bed align together to form anastomoses. This phase is called inosculation. Neovascularization refers to the in-growth of the blood vessels from the recipient site into the graft. The organization of the graft begins immediately following the placement of the graft due to the formation of a fibrin layer. The graft becomes adherent to the bed by days 10-14.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).
